DOC.HEAD: Survey Finds Big Drop in Consumer Faith in Economy
DOC.TEXT: Consumer confidence in the economy plunged in October to the lowest level since 1981-82 recession, a prominent business research group reported Friday. The Conference Board's widely followed monthly index of consumer confidence tumbled more then 24 points, the biggest one-month drop in the 20-year history of the survey. ``We had a tremendous drop in confidence,'' said Fabian Linden, executive director of the Conference Board's Consumer Research Center. ``It was all pretty dreary.'' The index is based on a poll of 5,000 households nationwide conducted by National Family Opinion Inc. of Toledo, Ohio. The poll asks questions about spending on cars, appliances and homes, job security, and general economic conditions. It is scrutinized by economists because consumer spending is a crucial element in economic growth. The index dropped sharply in August and did not rebound in September, which Conference Board analysts attributed to anxiety over the Persian Gulf crisis. But there was nothing in the economic news to explain the September-to-October drop. Linden said the Conference Board had concluded that many consumers were appalled by the inability of Congress and the Bush administration to agree quickly on a budget package. ``An important factor in the decline was the great budget comedy,'' Linden said. ``It was a pretty disenchanting experience.'' The Conference Board, based in New York, is a business-funded economic research organization.

DOC.HEAD: Mother Charged With Leaving Child in Car Pleads Guilty
DOC.TEXT: State welfare officials will decide next week whether to reunite a moonlighting single woman with the 5-year-old daughter she locked in a car while she worked. Chante Fernandez, 24, of Elizabeth, says she couldn't find a baby sitter she trusted nor get government care services. Prosecutors agree she didn't neglect her daughter. Ms. Fernandez pleaded guilty Friday to a disorderly persons offense, was given a $100 suspended sentence and was spared probation. She had faced up to 30 days in jail and a $500 fine. ``I was only trying to get us out of the situation we were in,'' Ms. Fernandez told Superior Court Judge Robert Figarotta. ``I hope somehow you can understand.'' Ms. Fernandez was initially charged with criminal restraint and spent two days in jail before posting $5,000 bail. She faced up to five years in prison and a $7,500 fine, but Middlesex County Prosecutor Alan Rockoff reduced the charge after his office was flooded with calls from supporters of Ms. Fernandez. ``She has lost her child in the last several days, she has been in the trepidation of feeling she was destitute without a job,'' Rockoff said. ``I think that's punishment enough.'' Defense attorney Kenneth Weimer said Ms. Fernandez was ``desperate'' and did what she did ``out of love for her child.'' ``My client made a bad judgment call. She was up against the wall,'' Weimer said. After the hearing, Ms. Fernandez and Weimer said they were surprised by the lenient sentence and would concentrate on reuniting Ms. Fernandez with her child, Anjuli. Ms. Fernandez was arrested Saturday after police found her pajama-clad daughter in the back of her car at a shopping mall where she worked part-time on weekends. Ms. Fernandez said she left her daughter in the car because she couldn't find a trustworthy baby sitter nor get local or state child care services. She said she checked on her daughter during work breaks and left the rear seat folded down so Anjuli could sleep in the trunk area. Anjuli is being cared for by the state Division of Youth and Family Services. A hearing is scheduled for Oct. 30 to decide whether she should be allowed to go home. After her arrest, Ms. Fernandez was fired from a full-time at an Elizabeth lumber company. After hearing of her plight, that company offered to rehire her and her employer at the shopping mall offered her a full-time job.

DOC.TEXT: Here are the highlights of congressional developments Friday as the House and Senate pushed toward a likely weekend adjournment of the second session of the 101st Congress:
Democratic and Republican leaders sought support among rank and file members for a five-year, $250 billion deficit-reduction agreement that would embrace taxes affecting virtually all Americans.

The House passed, 401-25, a new clean-air law aimed at sharply reducing urban smog, acid rain and toxic chemicals released into the air by industry. The Senate scheduled a Saturday vote. The bills for meeting the new requirements eventually are expected to exceed $22 billion a year and affect virtually every segment of society.

The Senate vote 89-7 to approve a major overhaul of immigration law, with higher total legal immigration allowed and setting aside visas to reunite families and admit people with special skills. But the House sidetracked the bill on a procedural question and its future was uncertain.

A House-Senate conference committee agreed on the mild anti-obscenity restrictions for federal grants to artists contained in the House version of the Interior appropriations bill. It dropped the stricter provisions, including a ban on financing work that denigrates religion, in the Senate version.

The House approved by voice vote and sent to the president legislation to give consumers more nutrition information on the labels of the foods they eat. The bill also requires that bulk food in bins, raw fish and fruits and vegetables be displayed with a sign or brochure providing nutritional information.
The Senate gave final congressional approval to a $268 billion Pentagon budget for fiscal 1991, which was about $17 billion less than President Bush initially requested in January.

House and Senate negotiators agreed to give President Bush the debt relief he seeks for Egypt but at the same time defied the president in slashing aid to El Salvador. Both new provisions are part of a $15.5 billion foreign aid bill for the year that began Oct. 1, which includes economic and military support for America's friends and allies around the globe.

The House approved on a voice vote and sent to the Senate a bill toughening sanctions against banks and savings and loans convicted of money laundering for drug dealers. Federal regulators would be given authority to revoke the charter or appoint a conservator for any convicted institution.
The House passed by voice vote and sent to the Senate an extension of the McKinney Homeless Act, which established programs to house the homeless.

DOC.HEAD: Motley Anti-War Crew Converges on Baghdad
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A Japanese wrestler who once fought Muhammad Ali, a French daredevil pilot and an American Vietnam veteran are among the would-be peacemakers who have converged on Baghdad since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. ``I am here to try to stop a war,'' said Antonio Inoki, 47, of Tokyo. Inoki, a professional wrestler, lasted 15 rounds and took a draw in an exhibition freestyle fight with heavyweight boxing champion Mohammad Ali 16 years ago. ``Many Americans do not want war, and this is exactly what we are telling the Iraqi people and the government,'' said Rick Droz, of Pasadena, Calif., who said he lost his leg as a U.S. Marine during the Vietnam War. The peacemakers descend on Baghdad almost daily. Western diplomats have said they are being manipulated by President Saddam Hussein's government, whose ventures into international public relations in the past have backfired. Shortly after Iraq invaded its oil-rich neighbor on Aug. 2, Saddam was shown on Iraqi television with detained Westerners, whom he has called ``guests.'' Saddam's pat on the head of one Western child brought world outcry. His speeches to the West, broadcast worldwide, have often been rambling self-justifications couched in religious terms. His latest tactic appears to be welcoming foreign peace groups, lodged free of charge at five-star hotels and met by huge ``Welcome'' banners. ``None of them talk of who started it all,'' a Western diplomat said on condition of anonymity. ``It is like I insult you, I slap you, I rob you and then a neighbor comes and says `peace, peace.''' But most of the visitors speak earnestly of their desire to help avert war. They claim they are free to move around Baghdad, but almost none speaks Arabic so they need interpreters. In Iraq, an interpreter is often a secret service agent or a government official. Well-known public figures who have come to intercede on behalf of Western hostages include American civil rights activist Jesse Jackson, Austrian President Kurt Waldheim and former British Prime Minister Edward Heath. All succeeded in winning the freedom of limited numbers of their countrymen. Waldheim took home 95 Austrians; Heath was allowed to take 33 Britons; Jackson got out 55 Americans, and a few days ago an Iraqi-American group took with it 14 U.S. citizens. But thousands of Westerners are still detained in Iraq and Kuwait, and about 600 are being used as human shields at strategic installations to deter possible attack by U.S.-led multinational forces in the Persian Gulf. Saddam's government appears thrilled by the peace groups and occasional celebrities who drop in. ``We want peace as well,'' one Iraqi official said on condition of anonymity. The visits are well-publicized by Iraq's state broadcast and print media. ``I am here to represent the attitudes of 75 percent of the French people, all of whom know about war, its miseries and disasters,'' the English-language Baghdad Observer quoted French daredevil pilot Albert Maltret as saying. Maltret, whose professional name is Baron Noir - or the Black Baron - made headlines in 1988 when he buzzed Paris aboard an ultra-light plane. He took with him to Baghdad his 16-year-old daughter and 13-year-old son. The Iraqi News Agency ran a 400-word profile of Maltret, calling him a ``French national hero'' who ``says he is ready to fight and die for the values and principles of the peace-loving people of Iraq and their leader.'' A 20-member American group named the Fellowship of Reconciliation, brought children's paintings with peace-loving themes. ``These are all done by our kids back home, and you can make out how much they think of peace,'' said Evelyn Mattern, who identified herself as a Roman Catholic nun from Raleigh, N.C. Jim Lewis, a clergyman from Raleigh, walks around Baghdad in a long white robe, a cross hanging from one shoulder. ``Give peace a chance, please,'' he said in an interview. One Asian diplomat was less critical of the peace groups than his Western counterparts. ``You never know which of the peace groups may succeed in stopping a war,'' he said on condition of anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Businessmen Want Sanctions Against Vietnam Removed
DOC.TEXT: Some American businessmen are urging the U.S. government to end its trade ban against Vietnam because they say other foreign investors are gaining an upper hand. ``We think the trade embargo against Vietnam should be lifted,'' Thomas White, chairman of the Asia-Pacific Council of American Chambers of Commerce, said Friday. ``There is a tremendous interest to do business in Vietnam,'' said Mattie Genovese, an American businessmen in Hong Kong. American firms are interested in mining, agriculture, fishing and tourism there, he said. U.S. businessmen from the Asia and Pacific region have been meeting in Singapore for two days to discuss trade and investment. The businessmen said the trade embargo was causing them to lose out to other nations now entering a potentially lucrative market. The embargo was imposed on North Vietnam in 1964, and extended to the entire country after the Communists seized Saigon in 1975. Violators face penalties of up to $1 million and 10 years' imprisonment.

DOC.HEAD: Pan Am Airbus Makes Emergency Landing
DOC.TEXT: A Pan Am jet with 183 people aboard made an emergency landing in the Hebrides, west of the Scottish mainland, after one of the aircraft's engines began losing oil, the plane's captain said. The Airbus landed safely Friday at Stornoway Airport, on the Isle of Lewis, and no one was injured. The small airport had no suitable gangways so passengers were taken off in a basket rigged to a hydraulic lift, officials said. Arrangements were being made to fly the passengers on to London. The flight had been headed to New York from Vienna. The Isle of Lewis is the northernmost island of the Hebrides. The captain of the plane, Curtis Briggs, said he noticed the engine was losing pressure as the plane was about 50 miles south of Stornoway.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwaiti Oil Facilities Said Wired With Plastic Explosives
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi occupation forces in Kuwait wired all four of the Persian Gulf emirate's oil refineries with plastic explosives and carted off large chunks of Kuwait's oil industry equipment, U.S. government sources say. The explosives, if detonated, could knock out Kuwait's entire refining capacity, the sources said Friday. Explosives also have been placed at other vital oil installations, including pipeline pumping stations, oil processing centers, oil wells and loading terminals, said the sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity. They said the moves appear to be part of a ``scorched earth'' strategy by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to devastate Kuwait's economic base in the event his army is forced to withdraw by the U.S.-led multinational forces in the region. ``They're basically all wired up for destruction - even the refineries,'' said one source, who is involved in the administration's monitoring of developments inside Kuwait. Iraq also is removing large quantities of chemicals, pipes, meters and other oil-processing and production materials from storage areas in Kuwait for apparent use in Iraq, the sources said. There is no evidence, however, that the Iraqis are dismantling oil refineries by removing operational parts, they added. Representatives of the exiled Kuwaiti government have said their country's oil industry was being severely damaged by Iraqi forces, but few details had come to light. The threat of war against Iraq to force Saddam's army out of Kuwait has been a central reason for the rapid escalation of crude oil and gasoline prices over the past 10 weeks. Oil market participants fear that war would knock out many oil production facilities in Kuwait, Iraq and possibly Saudi Arabia, creating a global shortage. An administration source said U.S. spy satellites had provided photographic evidence of Iraqi forces moving Kuwaiti oil industry equipment and materials across the border into Iraq. ``It's a wholesale cannibalizing,'' said one American oil industry source. By capturing Kuwait in an Aug. 2 invasion, Iraq gained control of one of the Middle East's most advanced oil production and refining industries. Kuwait's four modern refineries - Mina Abdullah, Mina Ahmadi and Shuaiba near Kuwait City and the much smaller Mina Saud facility near the southern border with Saudi Arabia - had a pre-invasion capacity of nearly 900,000 barrels a day. The explosives attached to these facilities could, if detonated, knock out all of Kuwait's refining capability for at least six months, the sources estimated. It would take at least two years to get the facilities back to full capacity, they said. Details about the installation of plastic explosives at refineries and other Kuwaiti oil facilities have come from Kuwaiti exiles and from released foreign hostages, an administration source said.

DOC.HEAD: D.C. Mayor Says Jail Sentence Won't Affect Bid for Council
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry says he plans to proceed with his campaign for a city council seat even though he faces a six-month jail term for cocaine possession. ``For the next few months, I will manage the District (of Columbia) government and also continue my campaign for city council,'' Barry in a brief meeting with reporters after Friday's sentencing. Asked whether he should continue his bid for a city-wide council seat, Barry responded, ``Absolutely. Why not?'' He attributed the jail term to the inequities of ``the American injustice system.'' Barry is locked in a close battle for second place in an eight-way contest for a council job. The top two vote-getters will win council posts, and recent polls show that Democratic nominee Linda Cropp has a sizable lead. The final seat is expected to be won either by Barry or incumbent Hilda Mason of the district's Statehood Party. Barry dropped his Democratic party affiliation and registered as an independent to run for the seat less than two weeks after being convicted of the misdemeanor possession charge. He had ruled out running for a fourth term as mayor in advance of his drug trial. U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson could have merely sentenced Barry to probation as a first offender, but he said the mayor's ``breach of public trust alone warrants an enhanced sentence.'' The judge stayed the sentence, which also includes a $5,000 fine, pending resolution of an appeal filed by defense attorney R. Kenneth Mundy. Jackson also placed Barry on one year of probation and ordered him to submit to random drug tests during that period. And he ordered Barry to pay for the cost of his incarceration, which would come to $5,167 if, as is likely, he is sent to a minimum-security facility, according to Bureau of Prison figures. Barry's drug use ``contributed to the anguish that illegal drugs have inflicted on this city in so many ways for so long,'' Jackson said. ``Having failed as the good example he might have been to the citizens of Washington, D.C., and, in particular, to the young who are much more likely to respond to example than to admonition, the defendant must now become an example of another kind,'' the judge said. After the sentencing, Barry said, ``I should have been shocked and stunned, but I'm not. I understand that there are different sets of standards for different people, and that's the American injustice system.'' Mundy, who argued during the trial that Barry had been singled out for prosecution because he is a well-known black official, said the judge had made the mayor ``a whipping boy for all the ills that beset the District of Columbia.''

DOC.HEAD: Suspect in UTA Jetliner Bombing Arrested in Zaire
DOC.TEXT: Authorities have arrested a man suspected of making the bomb that blew up a French jetliner over Niger last year, killing 170 people, official sources said. The victims included the wife of the U.S. ambassador to Chad and a Chadian Cabinet minister. The government sources said Friday that Jean Bosco Ngalina, believed to be a citizen of either Zaire or Congo, was being held at Makala prison in Kinshasa, Zaire's capital. The sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Ngalina confessed to making the bomb. They did not say when he was arrested. The plane, on a flight in September 1989 from Brazzaville, Congo, to Marseille, blew up over the Tenere desert shortly after making a stop in N'Djamena, the capital of Chad. The Zairean government did not officially comment about the arrest reported Friday in the Kinshasa daily newspaper Elima. A French news magazine, Le Point, reported last month that investigators believed three Congolese dissidents carried out the bombings with the support of Libyan agents. A subsequent report in The Times of London said that Syria also was involved.

DOC.HEAD: Government Says it Will Again Accept Soviet Jewish Immigrants
DOC.TEXT: Germany will resume accepting Jewish immigrants from the Soviet Union, officials said, after a temporary halt that Jewish groups harshly criticized. Faced with record numbers of newcomers, the government stopped giving visas to Soviet Jews in mid-September. More than 10,000 applications had been filed in Kiev alone. Interior Ministry spokesman Willi Hausmann said in an interview Friday that the government will talk with Jewish groups in Germany and abroad about how to resume the immigration. German officials had expressed fears that rising anti-Semitism in the Soviet Union may force many of the estimated 2 million Soviet Jews to seek new lives in Germany. Germany's social services and housing have been strained to the limit by the arrival of about 200,000 asylum-seekers from the Third World and Eastern Europe this year, in addition to about 500,000 East Germans. Fewer than 40,000 Jews currently live in Germany, compared to 600,000 before the Holocaust.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Forbids Use of District Funds
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Top 2 grafs new with Senate action; picks up at pvs 2nd graf, ``It is;'' deletes pvs 5th graf, The Senate, outdated; CORRECTS 6th graf, The abortion, to make previous votes in the last week sted Thursday
DOC.TEXT: The Senate early Saturday completed congressional action on a bill to prevent the District of Columbia from using its own tax dollars on abortions for poor women unless necessary to save the life of the mother. The Senate approved the measure by voice vote several hours after it cleared the House, also by voice. ``It is a compromise that is necessary at this time,'' said Rep. Julian Dixon, D-Calif., chairman of the House Appropriations subcommittee on the District of Columbia. ``It is one that I certainly am not happy with.'' The restriction was included in the district's spending bill for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1. A similar provision was in last year's bill. The measure includes an appropriation of $548 million for city operations, of which $430 million is known as the federal payment, paid the city in lieu of taxes on federal property. The bill also approves the spending of $3.9 billion from the district's own treasury. The abortion restrictions were put in the bill by a House-Senate conference committee after the House rejected the bill twice in the last week y because it allowed the district to spend its own money on the procedure. Dixon said that when conferees went back to work on the bill after the rejections, they reduced it by $2 million to please some members of the House who also felt the federal government was giving the city too much money. He said the money came out of appropriations for the city's schools and administrative services. The original House and Senate bills prohibited the use of federal funds for abortion, except to save the mother's life and in cases of rape and incest, but were silent on the use of local funds. President Bush had said he would veto the legislation if it contained funds for abortion. He made the same threat last year and was succesful in forcing retention of a ban on use of local funds in last year's appropriations bill. ``It is the 11th hour,'' said Dixon. ``There is no alternative. For the first time the House is now mandating to the residents of the District of Columbia how they spend their own money.'' ``What this does is get it down to the White House,'' Dixon said of the abortion restrictions. ``It lets the District of Columbia get their federal payment and get on with business. I hope next year this house and the president of the United States will change their attitude.''

DOC.HEAD: Secretary to Visit Saudi Arabia, Probably Other Arab Countries
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and his top advisers will decide next week whether to expand the mission of Secretary of State James A. Baker III to Saudi Arabia to include other Arab countries, U.S. officials say. Egypt is almost certain to be added to the itinerary as Baker seeks to bolster the Arab coalition against Iraq. His stop in Saudi Arabia was announced Friday by White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. At the same time, Fitzwater said it was ``not true'' that Baker would ask leaders of the oil-rich monarchy to approve military action against Iraq to force its withdrawal from Kuwait. Later, speaking to reporters aboard Air Force One bound for Hawaii, Fitzwater said Baker and the Saudis would discuss ``the implementation of U.N. sanctions, the status of U.S. and multinational forces in the gulf, general defense needs, Arab unity and military options.'' Fitzwater announced the trip in Los Angeles, where Bush was making a campaign appearance. The president had talked by telephone on Thursday with Saudi King Fahd and with Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak. Fitzwater said Bush also talked to German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, Italian Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti, who will visit Washington next month; and Dutch Prime Minister Ruud Lubbers. Besides trying to hold the Arab coalition together, the administration wants to make sure the Western Europeans support the drive to force an Iraqi pullout. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said Thursday that up to 100,000 additional U.S. troops would be sent to the Persian Gulf in response to the continuing buildup and fortification of Iraqi occupation forces in Kuwait. Baker's trip to the region, for which no date was announced, will underscore U.S. resolve to end the 12-week-old occupation of the emirate. A decision to send Baker to Egypt and possibly other Arab countries will be made when Bush meets next week with his four principal advisers - Baker, Cheney, national security adviser Brent Scowcroft and Joint Chiefs of Staff Chairman Colin Powell - said the officials, who requested anonymity. Meanwhile, the State Department announced that Jordan was in compliance with U.N. sanctions against Iraq and suggested that wealthy countries such as Saudi Arabia help the stricken Jordanian economy. Although State Department spokesman Richard Boucher did not explicitly urge Saudi Arabia to end its oil cutoff and ease its icy stance toward King Hussein's government, the message was obvious. ``The Saudis have been very forthcoming and generous,'' Boucher said. Jordan fell into disfavor both in Washington and in Saudi Arabia when it hesitated on applying sanctions against Iraq after the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Fall Back America, to Standard Time Again
DOC.TEXT: Turn your clocks back an hour tonight. The official switch comes at 2 a.m., local time, when most of the nation changes from Daylight Saving to Standard time. That means it will get dark earlier at night, but there will be more light in the morning. Daylight Saving time returns on the first Sunday of April.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyer: Keating Glad to Testify if Granted Immunity
DOC.TEXT: Charles Keating Jr. might testify before the Senate Ethics Committee if guaranteed his words won't be used against him elsewhere, his lawyer suggested. Keating, the Arizona developer who controlled Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, is a central figure in the nation's savings and loan debacle. Experts say Lincoln may be the costliest failed thrift ever at $2 billion. Keating faces a multitude of civil and criminal charges. The Los Angeles Times reported this week that the Ethics Committee was considering giving him limited immunity to testify in its probe of five senators to whose campaigns and causes Keating gave $1.3 million. The report were subsequently denied. ``Mr. Keating has a wealth of information and insight,'' his attorney, Stephen Neal, said after a court session Friday in a Keating securities fraud case. ``If it were up to Mr. Keating, he would be talking to all of you about it. At the present time that is just not appropriate,'' Neal said. But he added: ``If I were an appointed or an elected public official ... I would think long and hard about ways to enable Mr. Keating to share the information and insights he has on all of the issues, including campaign financing.'' Asked if he was open to offers, Neal said: ``I certainly will receive or return a phone call.'' Keating, in his first court appearance since he was released from jail on bail last week, stood beside his attorney but declined to comment. The Ethics Committee is investigating whether Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., and four others improperly intervened with federal regulators on Keating's behalf. Also being scrutinized are Sens. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich., John Glenn, D-Ohio, and John McCain, R-Ariz. The judge at the hearing Friday said he will unseal transcripts of secret grand jury proceedings in the criminal case but delayed disclosure for a week to give lawyers the chance to appeal. Superior Court Judge Lance Ito rejected arguments by lawyers for the developer and his co-defendants, who said publicity surrounding such a disclosure would damage the chances of finding unbiased jurors for the trial. Ito accepted the position of lawyers for the Orange County Register and the Los Angeles Times, who argued that First Amendment case law supports free access to court records. The judge said he would excise from the 4,600-page transcript the prosecution's opening statement and closing argument, which he said were slanted against the defendants and might be prejudicial. Keating and three officials of his companies are accused of fraud in the sale of ``junk bonds'' at branches of Lincoln Savings, which he controlled through his American Continental Corp. The maximum penalty is 10 years. He has pleaded innocent. Keating's extravagant personal habits and investments in high-risk, high-yield junk bonds and risky real estate ventures have made him a central figure in the savings and loan crisis. He maintains he's being made a scapegoat by regulators and legislators hoping to avert blame for the debacle themselves. On a defense request, the judge delayed until Nov. 9 a hearing on motions to throw out the 42-count indictment on which the 66-year-old Keating was jailed for 33 days until he posted a reduced bail of $300,000 last week.

DOC.HEAD: Perry Points Finger at Hightower for Losing Fingertip
DOC.TEXT: Texas Agriculture Commissioner Jim Hightower's chopped-off finger is now an issue in his campaign. His Republican rival says Hightower is inept because he recently lost his fingertip in a lawn mower accident. ``This incident fully emphasizes his total lack of common sense,'' Perry said Friday. Hightower's campaign responded, saying, ``It's unbelievable Perry is trying to make this a campaign issue.'' ``It is an indication that Perry doesn't have serious programs and ideas to talk about,'' said Brigid Shea, Hightower's campaign spokeswoman. Last week, Hightower cut off the tip of his finger while mowing. After a news conference Thursday, Hightower quipped, ``I managed to put my finger under a lawn mower. If you'll check your manual and remember what your Mama said and what common sense tells us, is don't do that.'' Perry blasted Hightower, saying, ``It's probably a good thing Hightower is not a farmer, because there are machines much more dangerous than lawn owers on the farm, like shredders and bush hogs and balers.''
DOC.HEAD: O'Neill Disappointed With Tone Of Race To Succeed Him
DOC.TEXT: Retiring Gov. William A. O'Neill says he is disappointed by the negative tone of the campaign among the three men hoping to succeed him. O'Neill indicated he was glad he wasn't running again, recalling that one of the reasons he decided against seeking re-election was that he was afraid the campaign would get nasty. ``It's moving in that direction,'' O'Neill said. This week, Republican John Rowland and Democrat Bruce Morrison criticized Lowell Weicker for buying and selling of cable television securities while the Senate was voting on deregulating the cable industry. While the cable deregulation bill was before the Senate, Weicker accepted free plane flights from a cable television executive, Richard Treibick of Greenwich.
DOC.HEAD: Candidate Spends $3 Million on Senate Race
DOC.TEXT: Is a shot at a U.S. Senate seat worth $3 million? James Rappaport, a Republican running against incumbent Democratic incumbent John Kerry, has thrown more than $3 million of his own money into the race so far. Kerry has raised about $5 million without spending any of his own money. All of this for a job paying $98,400. ``Given the importance of paid media (advertisements) in campaigns today, it is sad but true that especially in a Democratic-dominated state it is virtually impossible to run a campaign against an entrenched incumbent unless one has significant personal means,'' said Rappaport campaign spokesman Richard Gaines. Rappaport's spending still pales in comparison to the $12 million in personal funds that Sen. Jay Rockefeller, D-W.Va., spent in 1984 to win his first race for the Senate.
DOC.HEAD: Candidates Take Out Petitions for Lukens Seat
DOC.TEXT: Four more people took out petitions to run for the unexpired term of former Rep. Donald Lukens, raising the possibility of a special election. Republican state Rep. Jim Buchy urged the governor to appoint the winner of the Nov. 6 general election to fill the unexpired term in western Ohio's 8th District. Lukens, a Republican, resigned Wednesday rather than risk being expelled in the final days of his term because of new allegations of sexual misconduct. Following Lukens' resignation, Gov. Richard Celeste signed an order requiring a special election to fill Lukens' unexpired term, which ends Jan. 3. Under the order, if only one Democrat and one Republican file for the interim seat, the district can scrap the primary and print just one extra ballot for a special election coinciding with the regular election Nov. 6. But if additional candidates file, the district must hold both a primary Nov. 6 and a special election Nov. 21. Four Republicans took out petitions Friday to run for the unexpired term. They join Republican John Boehner and Democrat Greg Jolivette, who have taken out petitions to run for the unexpired term and who will be the only two candidates running for the new term.

DOC.HEAD: Marines Enjoy First Day Off, Wear Gas Masks in Softball Battle
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Marines tossed horseshoes, batted volleyballs, ate grilled hamburgers and hot dogs, and jokingly played softball in gas masks as they enjoyed their first day off in more than two months. ``We'll be good to go for another couple of weeks after this,'' Sgt. Charles Owen, 35, of Mobile, Ala., said Friday. Owen said before the day off tempers had begun to flare and morale to sink among the 500 men in Combat Service Support Detachment 111, which handles supplies and maintenance for Marines in the northernmost sector of Saudi Arabia. The sports equipment and food were provided by American employees of Saudi ARAMCO, the kingdom's largest oil company. The civilians came to the unit's recreation area to mingle. ``We're really proud to have these people here,'' said Joe Serna, a former Marine who served in Vietnam, ``and we've come out here to give them a little bit of moral support.'' The civilians and their wives grilled the meat and dished up the baked beans, baked potatoes, potato salad and watermelon. The ARAMCO workers also played softball with the Marines, providing one of many teams taking to the diamond in a steady stream all afternoon. It was a test for the specially groomed sand surface that the Marines dubbed ``The Bob Hope Field of Dreams.'' It was a reference to Hope's trips to entertain troops and to a recent movie about a baseball field built in an Iowa cornfield. Members of one Marine unit bragged they play so well they could beat their opponents while wearing gas masks. They did so for one inning before giving up. Rivers of sweat coursed down their bodies as they shed their masks. The masks have been distributed because of threats from Iraqi President Saddam to use chemical weapons in war breaks out. The U.S. forces have come to Saudi Arabia to counter Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Before sending the men out to play games Friday, their commanding officers praised them for building the unit's facility in only seven weeks. In addition to the recreation area, the camp has a mess that cooks 10,000 meals a day, a repair center that fixes things from rifles to tanks, a medical treatment facility, and a PX that sells radios, snacks and sodas.

DOC.HEAD: William Paley Praised As Leader
With AM-, PM-Obit-Paley
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS in 3 grafs with Dan Rather statement; pick up 2nd graf pvs, ```Bill Paley . . .'.
DOC.TEXT: Colleagues of William Paley, the founder of CBS Inc. who died Friday at age 89, praised him as a creative and brilliant pioneer. ``He was a giant of 20th century business, a man committed to excellence,'' CBS News anchor Dan Rather said in a statement. ``Among his many accomplishments was being present at the creation of broadcast journalism, and he remained passionately interested in the news up to the time of his death,'' Rather said. ``Bill Paley was obviously one of the great giants in the broadcasting field,'' said Daniel Schorr, who worked for CBS from 1953 to 1976 and now works for National Public Radio in Washington. ``He created an atmosphere at CBS where one could feel that one doesn't have to worry about ratings or the cost of putting on the news and documentaries,'' he said. Laurence Tisch, president of CBS Inc., said: ``Bill Paley was an imposing leader who wove his boundless energy and taste into the very fabric of the company he created. He was a man of profound grace and intellect, as well as one of the most astute businessmen of our time.'' Fred Friendly, president of CBS News from 1964 to 1966, worked for Paley for 16 years. ``I think that broadcast journalism as it exists today would not be here if it had not been for Paley,'' he said. Friendly said Paley led coverage of three important eras at CBS: the rise of Hitler and the start of World War II, which was covered by up to 20 hours at a time of straight news; the McCarthy era in the 1950s; and the tumultuous 1960s. Paley helped make broadcasting ``what it was in the days before there were takeovers and people who were only interested in where the profits were,'' Schorr said. Schorr said when Edward R. Murrow told Paley in the late 1950s he was worried about whether his weekly documentary news show ``See It Now'' would make money, Paley told Murrow, ` ``We make our money from Jack Benny, don't worry about it.'''

DOC.HEAD: Italy Trying to Reinforce European Solidarity In Gulf Crisis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Meeting to begin 1 p.m. EDT; story likely to stand for PMs
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Worried by Iraq's attempts to divide the West, Italy wants to reaffirm a common stand on the Persian Gulf crisis at this weekend's European Community summit in the Italian capital. The two-day meeting that begins late today offers the 12 EC leaders their first chance to sit together to discuss the crisis caused by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Plans for European monetary, economic and political union are also on the agenda for the meeting. Italy is playing host to the summit as part of its six-month term as community president. A government spokesman, Pio Mastrobuoni, said Friday that Italy wants the summit to produce a renewed commitment of EC solidarity and coordination in the Persian Gulf. ``The EC must maintain complete cohesion if it wants to have credibility in the rest of the world,'' he said. Mastrobuoni said Italy is concerned by recent signs of ``discrepancies'' in the way West European countries have dealt with the situation of the hundreds of foreign hostages in Iraq and Kuwait. He said Iraq's decision to allow all French citizens to leave could give President Saddam Hussein the impression he can divide the multinational alliance lined up against him. ``The motto `all for one, and one for all' should remain,'' the spokesman said. ``We must stay united. We can't give the impression that the front has been weakened.'' Italian Foreign Minister Gianni De Michelis traveled to Cairo on Friday for talks with Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, who recently visited several countries in the Persian Gulf region. Officials said Mubarak's evaluation of the situation would be conveyed to the EC leaders. The summit is also expected to review the community's plans for integration in advance of mid-December meetings in Rome to formally institute the program. Mastrobuoni said Italy will propose that the leaders set Dec. 31, 1993, as the date for creation of a European central bank and a common currency. The idea s bound to upset British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who is against the proposals. The spokesman said Italy also hopes the summit achieves some consensus on the giving the EC a common foreign and security policy. The leaders are also expected to discuss the economic troubles of the Soviet Union, although no new aid offers appear likely. Negotiators in Luxembourg on Friday sought to keep the divisive issue of farm subsidies off the Rome agenda. Jacques Delors, president of the EC's executive body, said it could be ``disastrous'' if the agriculture and trade ministers are unable to break the deadlock before the summit. German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, whose government faces elections in December, is against a proposal for 30 percent cuts in farm subsidies over 10 years. His aides insist on special aid to offset any income losses suffered by farmers. France and Ireland back Germany in the dispute.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Industries Threaten Anti-Piracy Proceedings
DOC.TEXT: U.S. industries are threatening formal action to get the government to penalize Thailand for tolerating piracy of American movies, music, books, computer software and trademarks. Major copyright industry groups said Friday that unless the Thai government cracks down immediately on known pirates they will file a trade complaint on Nov. 15 that could lead to new penalty duties on Thai exports to the United States. The warning was issued in a joint letter to Thai Ambassador Vitthya Vejjajiva from the Motion Picture Export Association of America, the Recording Industry Association of America and the International Intellectual Property Alliance. The letter said industry representatives have provided the Thai government with ``the names and addresses of known pirates'' who operate ``blatantly and apparently without any fear that the Thai enforcement authorities would take any action.'' ``Unless the actions we have requested ... are taken immediately, the (groups) will ... file a formal trade complaint under Section 301 of the U.S. Trade Act of 1974,'' it added. The alliance estimated in a statement that piracy of records, tapes, videos, books and software in theSoutheast Asian country loses American originators more than $60 million a year. Calling Thailand ``the worst offender of intellectual property rights in Asia,'' Motion Picture Association Chairman Jack Valenti said, ``Thai pirates steal from our member countries $10-$15 million annually in potential revenues .... ``Illegal copies of American movies are on sale throughout Thailand within days of their release in the United States and well before their legitimate release in Thailand,'' he said. ``American movies are increasingly screened without license by illegal Thai cable TV systems outside of Bangkok.'' Recording Industry Association President Jay Berman said, ``We have worked closely with Thai officials and have been more than patient in awaiting promised government action to prosecute known audio pirates doing many thousands of dollars of illicit business daily ... the Thai government in blatant disregard of U.S. record companies and in violation of its international obligations has simply refused to prosecute these criminals.'' Eric H. Smith, general counsel of the property alliance, said in a statement that U.S. record and motion picture industry representatives have been threatened physically in Thailand when they seek enforcement of their rights. ``The Thai government has simply refused to move against the pirates ... despite repeated U.S. government and private sector entreaties,'' he said. At the time of Thai Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhavan's visit to Washington last June, it was reported in Bangkok that the prime minister might offer to step up the war against the flow of narcotics to the West in exchange for leniency on the intellectual property problem. In 1989, the U.S. government put Thailand on a ``priority watch list' because of the issue and withheld duty concessions on $165 million worth of Thai exports to the United States. No further action was taken, however, and Thailand enjoyed a $1.4 billion trade surplus with America for the year.

DOC.HEAD: Arts Conferees Agree on Mild House Obscenity Provision
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Lead prospects uncertain
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Congress Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Federal arts regulators must consider general standards of decency when awarding grants, under a mildly worded admonition against obscenity that neared approval in Congress today. A House and Senate conference committee agreed late Friday night to accept the House's compromise anti-obscenity provisions for the National Endowment for the Arts. It dropped provisions sponsored in the Senate by Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., that would have banned federal support for any works that denigrate religious objects or beliefs. The agreement came on a conference report on the nearly $12 billion Interior Department and related appropriations bill for fiscal 1991, which includes $175 million for the NEA. Also included was a three-year extension of the arts endowment - a reauthorization expected to lessen pressure on Congress for new anti-obscenity arts provisions next year. The aopted House language says that obscenity lacks artistic merit, is not protected speech under the Constitution and ``shall not be funded.'' It contains a disputed provision that instructs the NEA chairman to ensure that grants are awarded ``taking into consideration general standards of decency and respect for the diverse beliefs and values of the American public.'' The Interior spending bill was expected to go to the full House and Senate today. Conferees were meeting again today to resolve one remaining disagreement on an offshore oil-drilling moratorium in selected areas, which Sen. Bennett Johnston, D-La., wanted removed. Conferees sought the final agreement in hopes they could report full agreement on all elements, a move that would avoid amendments that could pick apart the package. Both the House and Senate decided earlier to scrap explicit anti-obscenity restrictions that Congress slapped on the NEA a year ago under pressure from Helms and other conservatives. Instead, both chambers would leave judgments of obscenity to the courts and require the NEA to get its money back from grant recipients whose federally subsidized works are ruled obscene in state courts. Senate Appropriations Committee Chairman Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., said the Senate conferees decided not to press for the religious denigration prohibition. The House chairman, Rep. Sid Yates, D-Ill., sought to have House conferees agree to drop the mild House obscenity language but lost on a 6-3 vote. At that point, Byrd said the Senate would go along with the House. ``I have my own viewpoint with respect to the arts,'' Byrd said. ``But I see no point at this juncture ... to continue to wrestle with that.'' The agreement apparently ends a long debate over the propriety of art receiving subsidies from the NEA, a controversy touched off by explicit homoerotic photographs by the late Robert Mapplethorpe that received indirect federal support.

DOC.HEAD: Israel's Temple Mount Report Fails to Silence Debate
DOC.TEXT: Israeli leftists and Palestinians are lambasting a government report that says police shot Arab stone-throwers in self defense earlier this month. Far-right leaders say the document hurts Jewish interests. Less-radical right-wing parties say the report released Friday bolstered Israel's earlier declarations that the rioters were chiefly to blame for the violence Oct. 8, in which police gunfire killed 20 Palestinians. The 59-page report, written by a three-man investigative committee appointed by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, drew immediate criticism from leftists and Arabs. ``The impression given by the first announcement of the report is that the committee sees the deaths of about 20 Palestinians and the injury of more than 100 Palestinians as a necessity that cannot be condemned,'' said legislator Yair Tsaban of the left-wing Mapam Party. ``If this is true, this report will create great dissension not only in the world, but in Israel,'' Tsaban said. In the Oct. 8 riot on Temple Mount in Jerusalem's walled Old City, more than 140 people were wounded by gunshots in addition to those killed, according to hospitals. Police initially listed 19 dead, but Friday's report increased the toll to 20. Police opened fire after Moslems on Temple Mount started throwing rocks at Jews praying at the Western Wall below. In an Oct. 12 resolution, the U.N. Security Council condemned the use of excessive force and ordered a U.N. team to investigate. Israel has refused to allow the inquiry. The United States joined in the condemnation and supported the inquiry, stirring Israeli anger. Washington is Israel's chief ally. Countering the U.N. plan, Israel has offered instead to submit its own report. But that idea has been rejected and ``has no chances of being accepted now,'' according to a senior government official quoted by Israel television. In Israel, two parties - the liberal Shinui and the Communists - have called on the government to cooperate with a U.N. investigation. The country's less-radical right-wing parties welcomed the report's conclusions. ``It was shown without doubt that there was a clear provocation on the part of (Arab) worshipers on the Mount. ... There was no other choice but to respond in this way,'' said Religious Affairs Minister Avner Shaki of the National Religious Party. The report said police were justified in resorting to live gunfire on stonethrowers. It said Palestinians started the riot. But it also said there was indiscriminate fire by police and leveled stinging criticism at senior police commanders for ignoring signs that rioting might break out in the tense atmosphere. Palestinian leaders criticized the investigating panel. ``It was only an editing committee that was just making a formula for the position of the Israeli government. I believe that we must have a neutral committee that can come from the United Nations,'' said Faisal Husseini, a prominent Palestinian leader from east Jerusalem. The report also drew fire from Israel's far right. Rabbi Moshe Levinger, a leader of the Jewish settlement movement, said the whole investigation was a ``most serious mistake'' that can harm Israel. Gershon Salomon, the head of a Jewish group widely blamed for provoking Moslems, said he was ``glad the committee put the responsibility on the Arab rioters and killers.''

DOC.HEAD: Editorial Employees Walk Out, Replacement Workers Deployed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf, `Cars and . . .', with two more arrests. Should stand for AMs.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY19, NR1
DOC.TEXT: About 800 Daily News editorial workers struck Friday rather than accept management's order to cross picket lines set up by eight other unions at the financially troubled tabloid. Management at the nation's second-largest city daily flew in the replacement workers to help circumvent a violent strike that began Thursday night when 1,800 employees walked out. Substitutes were imported from Tribune Co. newspapers in Orlando, Fla., and Chicago. Officials of the Daily News, which is owned by the company, said the paper would be on newsstands this weekend. Daily News director of labor relations Edward Gold said the paper would begin replacing workers if they failed to show up at work ``as soon as possible.'' The newspaper has 2,600 unionized employees. ``This is not a typical labor strike situation,'' said political reporter Frank Lombardi. ``They've declared an all-out war on the unions. They don't want negotiation, they want total capitulation.'' Union contracts expired in March. The News, using management and replacement workers, claimed it printed and distributed 611,000 copies of Friday's newspaper. The normal daily circulation is 1.18 million, second only to the Los Angeles Times among metropolitan newspapers. But deliveries of the single edition were spotty at best after firebombs, rocks and other projectiles were hurled at delivery trucks leaving plants in New Jersey, Brooklyn and Long Island. The Daily News was unavailable at rush hour at many midtown Manhattan newsstands, suburban railroad stations and other spots in the metropolitan area. The content was limited as well. The paper had just 48 pages, with just 7{ pages of local, domestic and international news articles. In comparison, last Friday's paper contained 116 pages. Sporadic violence was reported again Friday night. Cars and buses carrying replacement workers again were pelted with rocks as they drove from the Brooklyn plant. Two strikers were arrested on charges of reckless endangerment, police spokesman Mark Warren said. The News has lost about $115 million and seen daily circulation slip by about 700,000 in the past 10 years. The strike was good news for the Daily News' competitors in the battle for tabloid survival in the city. New York Newsday and the New York Post printed additional copies in an effort to pick up News readers. Outside the News' highrise headquarters on 42nd Street, pickets marched and union leaders told workers to head home for the day. Editorial employees from The Newspaper Guild initially honored the picket lines, then joined the strike at what was billed as an informational meeting Friday afternoon. Barry Lipton, the local Guild president, said the decision to strike was made after the News told union officials that replacement workers had already filled some editorial jobs. The News has taken a hard line in its negotiations with the unions, saying it must eliminate labor abuse to save $50 million to $70 million a year. The unions say the paper is trying to break them. Michael Alvino, president of the 700-member drivers' union, called the strike at about 10 p.m. after 60 drivers with the most seniority were fired and replaced with non-union workers. Union workers had walked out early Thursday after management ordered one worker to stand rather than sit on the job. The only one of 10 unions not involved in the strike is the New York Typographical Union, whose 200 members have lifetime guaranteed jobs. Late Thursday, replacement workers driving delivery trucks were attacked in New York and New Jersey. Eleven arrests and two minor injuries were reported. ``This vandalism and outright violence by the strikers is deplorable,'' said John Sloan, the News' vice president for labor relations. ``These are orchestrated and purposeful criminal acts.'' A truck leaving a Kearny, N.J., plant was firebombed at 3:10 a.m. in neighboring Harrison, N.J., although no one was injured. Two men were arrested shortly after the incident for possession of three Molotov cocktails, Kearny Police Lt. Michael Davitt said. Two trucks in Brooklyn were attacked, including one that crashed into two parked cars after it was pelted with debris. Similar incidents in Garden City led to six arrests for disorderly conduct at the plant there. There were two arrests in Brooklyn and one more in New Jersey. Sloan, in a statement issued by the News, also said the families of News executives were threatened overnight by union members.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd item to CORRECT in 3rd graf that Dan Costner said brother provided money, didn't say it was a loan.
DOC.TEXT: Actor Kevin Costner has put up nearly $1 million to help his big brother open a casino in Deadwood. Dan Costner, 39, plans to turn a clothing store on Main Street into a casino, restaurant and bar called the Midnight Star. Kevin, 35, and the clothing store's owners will be minority partners, Dan Costner said. Dan Costner said his brother, star of ``Field of Dreams'' and ``The Untouchables,'' provided most of the $1 million used to buy the property. The older Costner said he and his brother fell in love with the Black Hills last year during the filming of ``Dances with Wolves,'' which Kevin Costner stars in, co-produced and directed. Dan Costner moved from California to Lead to meet state requirements that majority owners of gambling operations be residents of South Dakota. He hopes to open the casino next year. Gambling was legalized in 1989 in Deadwood, the Black Hills gold rush town where Wild Bill Hickok was gunned down in 1876 while playing poker.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Lists Taboo Subjects For Troops In Saudi Arabia
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The ``Jewish lobby'' and provocative commercials for perfume and lingerie are among the subjects American troops stationed in Saudi Arabia are being advised not to discuss with their hosts. In a pamphlet written by the U.S. Central Command, the Pentagon is advising U.S. troops that those and other topics ``should be avoided or handled carefully. The pamphlet was printed for distribution to some of the estimated 200,000 American service men and women in and around Saudi Arabia. Topping the list of 15 ``sensitive'' items is ``articles and stories showing U.S.-Israeli ties and friendship.'' The pamphlet also suggests restraint in discussion of ``anti-Arab demonstrations or sentiments in the United States'' and of ``U.S. involvement in supporting Israel and Israel's current presence in Lebanon.'' The Pentagon, which advises troops to carry the booklet at all times, also suggests that the Americans avoid discussing or showing ``sensual advertisements for perfume, blue jeans, women's lingerie, gambling, alcohol, etc.; ads for pork or shellfish (which are forbidden by Islam).'' Other out-of-bounds topics include: -``Discussing the `Jewish lobby' and U.S. intelligence given to Israel.'' -``Referring to the Arab blacklisting of U.S. companies that do business with Israel or the Arab boycotting of companies that have strong Zionist representation in executive positions.'' Jewish groups have protested the list, first published in the November issue of Harper's Magazine. The World Jewish Congress said in a letter to Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney that it wanted to convey ``our sense of distress at what appears to be a capitulation to bigotry and a surrender of our democratic values ....'' The letter, from WJC Vice President Kalman Sultanik, urges withdrawal of the material from circulation. The American Jewish Committee, expressing to Cheney its ``deep sense of hurt and anger,'' said U.S. troops should not be asked to ``submerge entirely those values of tolerance, pluralism, and open-mindedness that have made the U.S. a unique democratic society.'' The Pentagon and State Department, mindful of the vast cultural and religious differences between Saudis and Americans, have issued a number of booklets setting out ``dos and don'ts'' since the troops began arriving in the Persian Gulf in August. Most of the pamphlets include a brief history of Saudi Arabia and its monarchy, and explanations of the strict Moslem code which governs Saudis' behavior. Alcohol is out for Moslems and for foreign troops; so is socializing with Saudi women. Other guidelines for Americans found in the pamphlets are: women should cover their legs and arms when out in public; women and men should not show affection in public; Americans should not show the soles of their feet to a Saudi (by sitting with their legs propped on a table, for example) because the gesture is considered an insult; Americans shouldn't ask Saudi men about their wives; Americans shouldn't offer their rations to Saudis because they might contain pork, which is forbidden by Islam. But the Central Command pamphlet goes beyond the social and cultural mores to include political topics. In forging the international anti-Iraq coalition of Western and Arab nations, the United States has been careful to avoid emphasis on its strategic and historic relationship with Israel, the largest recipient of American foreign aid. Saudi Arabia and its allies in the Arab world, who have fought five wars with Israel since it gained independence in 1948, have traditionally accused the United States of being biased toward the Jewish state. The Central Command pamphlet was originally written several years ago for American troops taking part in the biannual ``Bright Star'' maneuvers with Egypt, said Pentagon officials. That version contained several additional guidelines which have been removed from the booklets distributed for Operation ``Desert Shield,'' said the officials. The omitted material includes discussing ``films or newsclips featuring pro-Zionist actors and actresses (e.g. Barbara Streisand, Liz Taylor).'' But Pentagon spokesman Lt. Commander Ken Satterfield said that material was not included in the new booklet.

DOC.HEAD: Immigration Bill OK'd by Senate, Snagged in House
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Lead prospects uncertain
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Congress Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Sponsors are putting on a final drive for approval of the first overhaul of legal immigration in 25 years, designed to reunify families and bring more skilled workers to America. ``We are providing a charter on how future Americans will become future Americans,'' Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., said Friday night as the Senate approved the compromise measure, 89-8. Hours later, however, the bill snagged in the House, where critics said the increase in visas for families was inadequate and condemned a pilot program for testing identification card security. They said it would lead to a national I.D. card similar to ones used in a police state. The bill failed, 235-186, on a preliminary House vote late Friday. Sponsors made technical changes and said they would try again later. The measure would allow into the United States more people from countries in Western Europe and elsewhere that have been traditional sources of immigration, but less so in recent years. Legislation designed to curb illegal immigration was approved by Congress in 1986. But the current bill represents the first major reworking of the nation's legal immigration system since 1965. It would allow visas for 700,000 individuals annually, starting next Oct. 1 and for three years thereafter. It would allot 465,000 visas for families of American citizens and permanent resident aliens and 140,000 for immigrants with special job skills. It would earmark 40,000 admissions for people from countries such as Ireland, Poland and Italy that traditionally had been major sources of immigrants earlier in the nation's history. And 55,000 visas would be set aside for spouses and children of aliens legalized under the amnesty provisions of the 1986 legislation. The original House version of the bill would have allowed an estimated 800,000 immigrants a year compared, with the current 500,000. The Senate version would have resulted in an estimated 630,000. From 1995 onward, the bill would earmark 480,000 visas for family members, 140,000 for those with special job skills and 55,000 for those from nations that have been traditional sources of immigrants. Under the bill, the limit on immigration from Hong Kong would climb to 10,000 a year and after 1994 to 27,000 a year. The provision was inserted in the bill at the urging of American companies that do business there. The companies have been suffering a loss of key employees as the time approaches when control will pass from Britain to China in 1997. The bill aims to assure Chinese employees they will have plenty of opportunity to come to the United States later and that there is no need to get out now. An estimated 30,000 Irish living in the United States illegally also would effectively receive amnesty. In the Senate roll call, the opponents were Sens. William Armstrong, R-Colo.; Dale Bumpers, D-Ark.; Robert Byrd, D-W.Va.; James Exon, D-Neb.; Jesse Helms, R-N.C.; Trent Lott, R-Miss.; William Roth, R-Del.; and Warren Rudman, R-N.H. Not voting were Sens. Rudy Boschwitz, R-Minn.; Mark Hatfield, R-Ore.; and David Pryor, D-Ark.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmaers Erase Last Trace of Bush Proposals in Crime Bill
With PM-Congress Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers striving to rescue an omnibus anti-crime bill before Congress goes home performed emergency surgery, cutting death penalty provisions and curbs on semiautomatic assault weapons. ``This is a farce,'' Rep. Henry J. Hyde, R-Ill., said Friday after House and Senate negotiators also erased the last traces of the anti-crime proposals sent to Congress by President Bush two years ago. The cutting was designed to make the measure more acceptable all around. Liberals took a dim view of the death penalty, while conservatives were cool to restrictions on assault weapons. Early today, House and Senate conferees were still trying to figure out a way to preserve one controversial provision - which would allow the government to seize the homes of those accused of savings and loan fraud. Provisions remaining in the bill were ones that had not caused fireworks. ``It's a mini crime bill now,'' said Sen. Strom Thurmond, R-S.C. Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Joseph R. Biden Jr., D-Del., said the bill should have contained death penalty and assault weapons provisions. As passed, the Senate bill prescribed the death penalty for crimes ranging from presidential assassination to murder of a federal egg inspector. The House version was similar. The Senate version also would have imposed curbs on nine semiautomatic assault weapons. Lawmakers said both provisions were guaranteed to cause filibustering that would kill the bill. ``It still has a number of significant provisions,'' Biden said of the compromise version. Details were still being settled. But lawmakers were aiming for a bill including grants for treatment of abused children, tightening curbs on chemicals used in drug manufacture and a program to set up ``boot camp'' prisons. Other provisions would address victim rights, juvenile justice, prisoner drug testing and a host of other issues. The bill would authorize additional FBI and drug enforcement agents as well as more federal prosecutors. Lawmakers erased language that would have allowed courts to consider evidence gathered with flawed warrants. Also eliminated was a ``racial justice'' provision that would have allowed death row inmates appealing their sentences to use statistical evidence of racial bias on the part of the court. Biden said that while he would have preferred additional provisions, it was necessary to be realistic about the support available for the bill. ``It signifies that when you are in a situation where you have a determined minority in the Republican and Democratic parties that say they're going to filibuster everything, they can do it,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: New Economic Decrees Allow 100 Percent Foreign Ownership
DOC.TEXT: Foreign investors will be allowed to own companies in the Soviet Union under a new set of decrees issued by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to help move the Soviet Union to a market-based economy in two years. The decrees issued Friday also sharply devalue the ruble. They were announced as Gorbachev opened a three-day state visit to Spain, where he hopes to obtain further economic aid and increase trade with the West. The national legislature voted last month to give Gorbachev far-reaching power to order economic changes by decree. Although the legislature has not yet approved a detailed blueprint for the transition from a centrally planned economy to a market one, it has generally agreed on the concept. One decree announced Friday says foreign investors can establish enterprises in the Soviet Union, either in joint ventures with Soviet firms or with 100 percent foreign ownership. In the past, Soviet firms had to retain majority control. The decree also permits Soviet citizens to buy shares in enterprises, purchase bonds and hold other securities, either singly or in registered groups, the official Soviet news agency Tass reported. Profits of foreign investors can be reinvested or transferred abroad under rules promulgated by the Soviet legislature, the decree said. It did now say when the new rules would be announced or when they would take effect. ``Foreign investors on Soviet territory will enjoy legal protection, and conditions cannot be less favorable than the corresponding conditions for the property of Soviet organizations, enterprises and citizens of the U.S.S.R.,'' the decree said. The decree on stock ownership will have little immediate impact, because the Soviet Union does not yet have a stock exchange. However, officials have been discussing opening an exchange and recently sought advice from visiting representatives of the New York Stock Exchange. The new commercial exchange rate for the ruble will go into effect on Thursday, cutting the value of the Soviet currency by nearly 70 percent to spur exports and reduce imports. Ivan Ivanov, deputy chairman of the state Foreign Economic Commission, had warned this month a devaluation was coming. It will ``make exports more profitable for Soviet producers and facilitate the streamlining and restriction of imports, which have been growing rapidly since Soviet enterprises were granted the right of free access to the foreign market,'' he said. Devaluation of the ruble, though, affects only one of the two official exchange rates. The new exchange rate for international commercial transactions will be 1.8 rubles per U.S. dollar, compared to the current .56 rubles to the dollar. This is the rate used by Soviet and foreign companies. The rate for foreign tourists exchanging money in the Soviet Union will remain unchanged at 6 rubles to the dollar. The Soviet government introduced the tourist rate this year largely to combat black market activity. Both rates are set artificially by the Soviet government, and neither reflects the real worth of the ruble, either to companies trading commodities or tourists trying to buy Soviet wares such as a Matryoshka doll. On the black market, a dollar can fetch 15 to 30 rubles. Many international companies get around the artificial exchange rates by bartering goods, such as Pepsi for Stolichnaya vodka. Still, the new exchange rate is somewhat more realistic than the old one and should make some transactions easier. On Thursday, Gorbachev ordered government-run banks to pay higher interest rates on ruble savings accounts beginning Nov. 1, as a move to persuade depositors to keep their money in banks, despite the devaluation. Soviet banks now pay 2 percent or 3 percent annual interest on savings accounts, depending on the term of the deposit. Under Gorbachev's decree, Soviets will earn 5 percent to 10 percent interest on their money, depending on how long they promise to leave it on deposit.

DOC.HEAD: Skinny-dipping Allegations Dog Minnesota Governor Candidate
DOC.TEXT: Gubernatorial candidate Jon Grunseth admitted during a televised debate that he had ``wild years,'' but denied swimming nude with girls. As Grunseth debated two challengers Friday, fellow Republicans pressured him to quit the race, fearing his troubles could drag them down to defeat. ``I can't say, Jon, you have to get off the ticket. . . . I don't have that kind of power,'' said U.S. Sen. Rudy Boschwitz. ``But I can talk to him and tell him I think he has a future and he should not endanger that future by running in a three-man race and coming in third.'' Grunseth is trying to unseat incumbent Gov. Rudy Perpich, a Democrat seeking an unprecedented fourth term. State Auditor Arne Carlson, who lost to Grunseth in the Republican primary, began a write-in campaign after Grunseth became entangled in the nude-swimming allegations. During Friday night's debate, Grunseth said he went through a ``wild years'' period a decade ago when he was separated from his first wife and later divorced. But he said the allegations he swam nude with teen-age girls at a 1981 pool party are untrue. ``The legend of Jon Grunseth has been grossly exaggerated,'' he said. ``There are things I've done in my life I wish I hadn't done. That's not unlike most of us.'' Perpich blasted Grunseth during the debate for having said the governor was behind the allegations two young women brought against Grunseth. The women said in sworn statements that Grunseth invited them and two other teen-agers to join him for the nude swim. They said they declined but that Grunseth and the other girls took off their clothes. One of the women also said Grunseth tried to pull down her bathing suit top and touch her breast. ``People who know me know that I wouldn't even think of this,'' Perpich said. ``Why would I want to hurt your family or you? Why would I do that? ... This is an outrage.'' Grunseth has called Perpich the ``supreme liar'' for denying any connection, but has admitted he has no proof Perpich was involved. Boschwitz, seeking re-election to the U.S. Senate, said Grunseth's troubles are hurting the campaigns of all Republicans in Minnesota. ``It has an impact on dozens of people who are running for the state Legislature who are out there knocking on doors and working their hearts out, and I really don't want to see those people hurt, nor myself,'' he said. But Grunseth isn't quitting, his campaign director, Elam Baer, said Friday. Grunseth called a news conference Thursday to announce he was dropping out of the race, but decided at the last minute to stay in. ``Last night, we slammed the door shut, nailed a couple of spikes in it and locked the deadbolts and he is in this race until Nov. 6,'' Baer said.

DOC.HEAD: Pilots Relieved at Length of Sentences
LaserPhoto MP6
DOC.TEXT: Three former Northwest Airlines pilots, the first to be convicted of flying a commercial jetliner while intoxicated, said they're relieved they didn't get longer prison sentences. ``It's less than what I expected,'' Capt. Norman Lyle Prouse, 51, of Conyers, Ga., said after being sentenced Friday to 16 months in prison. First Officer Robert Kirchner, 36, of Highland Ranch, Colo., and flight engineer Joseph Balzer, 35, of Antioch, Tenn., each were sentenced to 12 months in prison. U.S. District Judge James Rosenbaum also ordered three years of probation for each man after release from prison, but levied no fines. While on probation, the pilots can't fly planes with passengers. Kirchner and Balzer were freed pending appeals of their convictions. Prouse didn't ask to be freed pending an appeal, but the judge gave him five days to file a request. ``Gentlemen, you are good men who have done a bad thing,'' the judge told the three. ``Who can comprehend an entire crew alcohol impaired?'' Rosenbaum said. ``It is a crime against our sense of security. In that sense, all of us are a victim of this crime.'' Bruce Hanley, attorney for Balzer, said the judge may have been influenced by a tide of letters urging leniency. The letters, which the judge talked about in court, came from friends and families of the pilots. There were no letters from passengers of the flight or others who might have been outraged, the judge said. ``People were not writing, `Crucify these people,''' Hanley said after sentencing. Rosenbaum said the risks of ``piloting innocent civilians to their untimely deaths must be weighed against pain of (the pilots') families.'' Peter Wold, attorney for Prouse, said he feared Rosenbaum would sentence his client to six years or more in prison. William Mauzy, attorney for Kirchner, said he was ``relieved'' the sentence was at the low end of the federal guidelines recommending 12 months to 18 months in prison. The maximum penalty is 15 years in prison and a $250,000 fine. ``I'm very willing to do what the judge has said,'' Balzer told reporters. ``It's been a pressure cooker for a long time. I go from here.'' ``I'm grateful,'' Kirchner said. Each of the defense attorneys argued for prison terms of less than 12 months. They said a pre-sentence investigation report erroneously found that each of the defendants had not taken responsibility for his actions. The prosecutor, Elizabeth de la Vega, said, ``I think overall it was an appropriate sentence. . . . I think it sends a message to pilots.'' It was the first federal prosecution under a 1986 law making it a felony to operate a commercial airplane under the influence of drugs or alcohol. The three on March 8 flew a Boeing 727 from Fargo, N.D., after a night of heavy drinking at a bar. The plane, carrying 91 people, flew smoothly and landed safely at Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport, where the pilots were arrested. ``What difference does it make that you landed the flight safely?'' Rosenbaum said. ``The danger was there.'' Prouse admitted to drinking more than 15 rum-and-cola drinks at the bar. Balzer and Kirchner shared at least six pitchers of beer. Northwest fired the pilots. The Federal Aviation Administration stripped their licenses.

DOC.HEAD: Widow Of Iwo Jima Flag-raiser Faces Eviction
DOC.TEXT: The widow of one of six U.S. servicemen immortalized as they raised the American flag on Iwo Jima during World War II faces eviction from the home the war hero helped build 40 years ago. Pauline Gagnon had planned to turn the home, which includes her travel agency, into a museum for her husband's pictures, war medals and a flag that flew over Iwo Jima. But she ran into financial trouble and the house was sold at a foreclosure auction during the summer. She's been living there while she fights in court to overturn the sale. Her troubles are the latest for the family of war hero Rene Gagnon, who died of a heart attack at age 54 in 1979. Gagnon, who once said being a war hero was a blessing and a curse, was troubled by alcohol abuse throughout his life. His drinking got him fired from one job on Memorial Day 1978. In an interview Friday, Mrs. Gagnon said her husband was proud of the home and would be heartbroken to see it taken from her. The photograph of her husband and his companions struggling to raise the flag still is on display in the one-story, three-bedroom house. Mrs. Gagnon said her husband, a Marine, never overestimated his wartime contribution, despite the celebrity it brought him. ``He said he just did his job,'' she said. ``They just said, `Go do it,' and he did.'' According to accounts from Iwo Jima, three Marines were trying to hoist the makeshift flagpole on Feb. 23, 1945, but it was too heavy. Two more joined in, and then someone called Gagnon. As the six raised the pole, Associated Press photographer Joe Rosenthal took what became the most famous photograph of the war. It became the model for the Iwo Jima Memorial near Arlington National Cemetery in Virginia. The memorial commemorates the 5,931 Marines who died taking the Pacific island. Gagnon was buried at Arlington, but only after his widow argued for two years with officials who said he didn't qualify for interment at the crowded cemetery. Mrs. Gagnon, who declined to give her age, blamed her current plight on the slow economy and an overzealous buyer. She mortgaged her home when her business slowed, saying she planned to pay off the mortgage by selling some of the land. She couldn't win approval of her plans to subdivide it. She maintains in court that Resource Financial Group, which sold the mortgage, and two women who bought it took advantage of her plight. She has asked the court to reverse the sale and release her from the mortgage. On Wednesday a judge gave her 10 days to post a $100,000 bond or face eviction. The bond is in case she loses her court fight. Rene Gagnon was 19 when he fought on Iwo Jima. After the war he took a brief fling at a movie career, playing himself in the John Wayne film ``Sands of Iwo Jima.'' That was the extent of his acting career. Mrs. Gagnon told him to choose between acting or marriage, and marriage won. He was fired from his job as a night manager of a Manchester hotel in 1978 because of his drinking. The firing came on Memorial Day and created a furor.
