He once said all the people who wanted to buy a war hero a drink helped fuel his alcohol problems. ``That's the basis of society,'' he said in 1978. ``It thinks the biggest thing it can offer you is a drink.''

DOC.HEAD: Tourism Worried About ncephalitis Impact
DOC.TEXT: Tourism officials worry about a possible economic disaster this season as visitors cancel Florida trips because of an outbreak of sometimes-fatal St. Louis encephalitis. The industry already was vulnerable before the mosquito-borne disease hit, said John Rutherford, spokesman for the Orlando Visitors and Convention Bureau, which serves the Walt Disney World area. ``They're dealing with a triple whammy - there's a slow economy, high gas prices and now mosquitoes,'' Rutherford said. He said hotel occupancy and airport arrival rates in the Orlando area have shown flat growth or a slight downturn in the past few months. As of Friday, there were 63 confirmed encephalitis cases, 66 suspected cases and 28 presumed cases. Three people have died. St. Louis encephalitis is a virus carried by birds and spread to humans by the bite of a particular mosquito, primarily at night, health officials say. Historically, St. Louis encephalitis is most common in August, September and October and drops off in colder weather. But tourism officials say they can't wait. ``We may have a disaster in the making for the Florida tourism industry,'' Ronald Rose, executive director of the Jensen Beach Chamber of Commerce, wrote to the state Commerce Department. Rose accused the state health department of ``causing a statewide panic.'' Representatives from the Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services are stressing that the outbreak isn't a medical epidemic. ``An epidemic puts it in the public's mind as something that's out of control and requiring Draconian procedures,'' said Dr. Robert Calder, head HRS epidemiologist. ``The situation isn't out of control by any means. People are actually changing their vacation plans due to St. Louis encephalitis, which is not called for at all.'' The last encephalitis outbreak struck Florida in 1977, infecting 110 people and killing eight. The Commerce Department started playing a public service ``hot line'' message Oct. 17, telling prospective tourists that incidence of encephalitis is ``considered very low'' and affecting only ``five people in a million.'' The Division of Tourism distributed more than 7,000 pamphlets about St. Louis encephalitis and tips on how to avoid mosquito bites. But tourists should not be lulled into a false sense of security, health experts say. Dr. Charles Mahan, head HRS health officer, said that although St. Louis encephalitis is easily avoidable, ``You can't pooh-pooh it. It's a serious disease, and people have died from it.''

DOC.HEAD: U.N. To Adopt New Anti-Iraq Resolution Demanding Reparations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To be topped after vote scheduled sometime after 11 a.m. EDT.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Security Council prepared to adopt a resolution today holding Iraqi officials liable for war damages and economic losses caused by its invasion of Kuwait, diplomats said. There will be ``a large vote in favor,'' said the council president, British Ambassador Sir David Hannay. The new resolution, set for a vote at midday today, was the 10th since the invasion on Aug. 2. In previous resolutions, the 15-member council has isolated Iraq with an economic embargo and permitted U.N. member countries to use flotillas of warships in the Persian Gulf to enforce it. The council also has demanded that Iraq withdraw from Kuwait and release all hostages. The draft resolution, supported by at least 13 nations, invites nations, companies and individuals to document their damage and losses for the council, but does not establish a system for making claims against Baghdad. The proposal also demands that Iraq stop taking hostages and ``mistreating and oppressing Kuwaiti and third-state nationals.'' It also moves toward establishing Iraq's responsibility for war crimes, inviting nations to collect information on serious abuses of civilians contrary to the Fourth Geneva Convention of 1949 and to share it with the council. The convention, which Iraq signed, protects the rights of civilians in wartime or in military-occupied territory, outlawing summary execution, torture, deportations and hostage-taking. Although the new resolution holds Iraq liable for war damages, it does not provide for punitive reparations. Kuwaiti Ambassador Mohammad A. Abulhasan estimated that Iraq has less than $800 million in assets in the United States, which will pay $22 billion more in energy costs in a year due to the rise in oil prices following the invasion. The draft resolution also says Iraq must allow the immediate provision of food, water and basic services to diplomats and foreigners in diplomatic missions in Kuwait City. Iraq says Kuwait is now a province of Iraq and that the diplomats must move their operations to Baghdad. It has cut off water and electricity to the embassies. The U.S., British and French compounds are the last Western holdouts. The proposed resolution asks Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar to use his influence to see that the demands are met, and he is encouraged to be available to assist ``in reaching a peaceful solution to the crisis.'' The draft threatens Iraq with unspecified new punishment under Chapter 7 of the U.N. Charter if it doesn't obey all its resolutions. Chapter 7 allows punitive action up to, and including, collective use of military force. Western diplomats conceded they have few new major actions they can take to pressure Iraq, aside from severing telephone, fax and cables services and retaliating against Baghdad's embassies. In coming resolutions the council could establish the mechanisms for making economic claims against Iraq, and could take concrete steps toward establishing a war crimes tribunal. Iraqi Ambassador Abdul Amir al-Anbari said the latest resolution was a preparation so that someone can eventually say `` `Well, we have exhausted all possible resolutions of the Security Council's authority, it is now time now to use force.' ''

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Council Prepares to Vote on Another Resolution Against Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with diplomats saying Security Council to vote overwhelmingly for the resolution; vote expected at 11 a.m. EDT. ADDS Gorbachev's first name in 19th graf pvs, `French President...' Pickup 20th pvs, `Gorbachev, opening...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY6
DOC.TEXT: The United Nations put the final touches today on a resolution demanding Iraq pay reparations for its invasion of Kuwait. Baghdad indicated a willingness to negotiate and prepared to free more than 300 French hostages. U.S. Secretary of State James Baker III is to visit Saudi Arabia next month to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis, the White House said Friday. The United States has sent more than 200,000 troops to Saudi Arabia and the region to deter any further aggression and plans on sending up to 100,000 more. Also Friday, Kuwait's exiled prime minister said the time had come for a military strike to force Iraq from his homeland. The U.N. Security Council was expected to overwhelmingly adopt a resolution today holding Iraqi officials liable for war damages and economic losses caused by its invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, said diplomats, including the council president, British Ambassador Sir David Hannay. Nations, companies and individuals suffering losses would be able to apply to the Security Council for damages. The proposal also invites nations to submit information on abuses of Kuwaitis and other civilians contrary to the Fourth Geneva Convention. It threatens Iraq with unspecified new punishment under the U.N. Charter if it doesn't stop mistreating and oppressing Kuwaitis and release foreign hostages. Iraqi Ambassador Abdul Amir al-Anbari said the draft resolution was ``a preparation so that someone can eventually say `Well, we have exhausted all possible resolutions of the Security Council's authority, it is now time now to use force.' '' The United Nations already has condemned Iraq for its invasion and ordered an international embargo on Iraqi trade to force Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to withdraw his forces from Kuwait. Saddam prevented thousands of foreigners from leaving Iraq and Kuwait after the invasion. Hundreds have since been released as Saddam apparently tries to pry concessions from Western governments in exchange for their citizens' freedom. Iraq has said French nationals would be free to leave beginning today. France insisted no deal was struck to win their freedom. Two Irishmen flew home from Iraq on Friday saying Saddam Hussein granted them permission to leave as thanks for good work on his new palace. Western diplomats in Baghdad said Iraqi troops had seized two American men who had evaded capture in Kuwait for weeks. They were identified as Uwe Jahnke, 47, of Washington Depot, Conn., and John Stevenson, 44, of Panama City, Fla. The diplomats, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the two were brought to Baghdad on Monday and taken to a hotel where scores of other foreigners are being held. Iraq on Friday gave new indications it might be willing to negotiate a settlement. Saddam told Channel 3 radio of Algiers, Algeria, ``When the greater interest demands it, everything is open to consideration.'' But he went on to rule out ``ceding our rights.'' There were also reports from Washington that Saddam has adopted a ``scorched-earth'' strategy if his troops are forced out of Kuwait. Administration sources said Friday that Iraq had used American and other hostages to wire Kuwait's four oil refineries with plastic explosives capable of knocking out the emirate's entire refining capacity. Iraq invaded Kuwait in a dispute over oil, land and money. French officials denied any knowledge of a letter Saddam reportedly sent to French and Soviet leaders offering to discuss Mideast problems. French President Francois Mitterrand and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev are to hold two days of talks in Paris beginning Sunday. The French television network La Cinq said Saddam told the two leaders he was open ``to all ideas'' in resolving the gulf crisis. Gorbachev, opening a three-day visit to Spain, said Friday: ``We favor taking advantage of all possibilities for a politicial solution. Nevertheless, no one should take the search for these joint or bilateral solutions as a sign of weakness, or for vacillation over implementation of U.N. Security Council resolutions.'' President Bush has asked Baker to visit Saudi Arabia early next month for discussions on the Persian Gulf standoff, the White House said Friday. Press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said news reports that Baker would ask the Saudi government to approve military action against Iraq were ``not true.'' Most nations, including the United States, have said the international economic boycott should be given time to work before a military attack is contemplated. Kuwaiti officials also have agreed with those declarations. But now Kuwait's exiled prime minister, Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah, has appealed for a military strike to reclaim his own homeland, even if it meant leaving the emirate in ruins, a Saudi newspaper reported Friday. ``As a citizen and a responsible official, I am ready to sacrifice everything for the sake of regaining my land,'' the Saudi daily Asharq al-Awsat quoted him as saying. In other developments: -The Pentagon is advising U.S. troops to avoid discussions about U.S.-Israeli ties with their Saudi hosts. Also on a list of taboo subjects are sensual commercials for perfume and lingerie. -The European Community meets this weekend and Italy said it will seek to reaffirm the EC's united stand on the gulf crisis.

DOC.HEAD: Plea Bargain Costs Man Freedom
DOC.TEXT: The plea bargain turned out to be no bargain. Rather than take chances on a jury verdict, Russell Barnes accepted a prosecutor's offer and pleaded guilty to one count of aggravated robbery in a mugging. In return, five other charges were dropped. The decision cost him at least 3{ years in prison: Moments earlier, the jury had found him innocent of all charges. James Campbell, a Ramsey County District Judge, said he decided to let the jury read its verdicts Thursday night for the benefit of attorneys who argued the case and to make a court record in case of appeal. The judge asked Barnes whether he wanted to hear the verdicts. He did. By then, the judge had accepted the guilty plea and it was too late to withdraw it. ``It was like O. Henry meets Alfred Hitchcock,'' said Richard Coleman, Barnes' public defender. Coleman said Barnes ``went into shock, and so did his lawyer.'' His client's mother burst into tears. A juror, misinterpreting the tears and the defendant's reaction as relief, came up to congratulate Barnes, 19, of St. Paul. Coleman said his client acted against his advice. ``My position had been to stick with the jury verdict, but I can understand his fear.'' If convicted of all six charges, Coleman said, Barnes would have faced up to 20 years in prison, about a third of the time off for good behavior. Under the plea bargain, he is to be sentenced to five years and four months, and is expected to have to serve at least two-thirds of it. Barnes was charged in an August incident in which he and others allegedly beat a St. Paul woman, her two sons and a friend and robbed them of $600. Jurors, who began deliberating Tuesday, twice said they were deadlocked, and Campbell decided to declare a mistrial at 9:30 p.m. Thursday if there was no verdict. But at 9:30 the jurors said they were making progress and wanted to continue deliberating. About 10:45 p.m., Coleman said, he called Campbell's chambers to say his client had decided to accept the plea agreement prosecutors offered earlier. Three assault charges and one each of burglary and simple robbery were dropped in exchange for the plea to aggravated robbery. Coleman then found out jurors had just told the bailiff they had a verdict. But Barnes stuck by his decision and entered his plea about 11 p.m. He entered a special plea under which he did not admit committing the crimes but conceded that he could be convicted based on the evidence.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf at a Glance
DOC.TEXT:
Here, at a glance, are the latest developments in the Persian Gulf crisis:
Iraqi occupation forces in Kuwait wired all four of the Persian Gulf emirate's oil refineries with plastic explosives and carted off large chunks of Kuwait's oil industry equipment, U.S. government sources say. Iraq also is removing large quantities of oil-processing and production materials from storage areas in Kuwait for apparent use in Iraq, the sources said. --- Iraq is giving new indications it might be willing to negotiate a settlement. President Saddam Husdsein told Channel 3 radio of Algiers, Algeria, ``When the greater interest demands it, everything is open to consideration.'' But he went on to rule out ``ceding our rights.'' --- The U.N. Security Council scheduled a vote today on a proposed resolution that would hold Iraq liable for damages caused by its invasion and occupation of Kuwait on Aug. 2. ---- French President Francois Mitterrand and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev are to hold two days of talks in Paris beginning Sunday. The French television network La Cinq said Saddam told the two leaders he was open ``to all ideas'' in resolving the gulf crisis. --- The Pentagon is urging American troops in Saudi Arabia to avoid discussing the ``Jewish lobby'' and other subjects to avoid offending their hosts. The World Jewish Congress said in a letter to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney that it wanted to convey ``our sense of distress at what appears to be a capitulation to bigotry and a surrender of our democratic values ....'' --- U.S. Secretary of State James Baker III will visit Saudi Arabia next month to discuss the Persian Gulf risis. The United States has sent more than 200,000 troops to Saudi Arabia and plans on sending up to 100,000 more.

DOC.HEAD: Diarrhea Kills 60 Children in East Timor
DOC.TEXT: At least 60 children have died of diarrhea in an outbreak of the disease that started late last month in East Timor, a news report said today. The English language daily Jakarta Post said the children died because they were either hospitalized too late or received no medication. ``Most of those dead were children under five years of age who were undernourished. Patients who were referred to clinics have survived,'' the newspaper quoted Carlos Pareira, a local health official, as saying. Pareira said the epidemic, which struck four districts, has affected more than 600 others, mostly children. East Timor, about 1,200 miles southeast of Jakarta, was a former Portuguese colony that Indonesia annexed in 1976. The Health Ministry said diarrhea and cholera have claimed more than 210 lives and affected about 191,000 people in Indonesia in the first eight months of the year.

DOC.HEAD: CBS Founder William Paley Dead at 89
LaserPhotos NY9, NY12, NY16; LaserColor NY10
DOC.TEXT: William S. Paley, who founded CBS, the media giant that brought such diverse programs as Edward R. Murrow documentaries and ``I Love Lucy'' into millions of homes, has died at age 89. Paley, who had been ill with pneumonia, died Friday night at his Manhattan home, said CBS spokewoman Ann Morfogen. A cigarmaker's son, Paley bought a fledgling radio network for $400,000 in 1928 and turned it into the $3 billion-a-year communications conglomerate known as CBS Inc. The broadcast pioneer controlled the Columbia Broadcasting System for more than half a century as president or board chairman of its radio and television networks and its film, publishing, recording and other subsidiaries. ``He was a giant of 20th century business, a man committed to excellence,'' CBS anchorman Dan Rather said in a statement. ``Among his many accomplishments was being present at the creation of broadcast journalism, and he remained passionately interested in the news up to the time of his death.'' Years after normal retirement age, Paley continued to run his media empire from his sumptuous office atop ``Black Rock,'' the black marble-faced tower in midtown Manhattan that houses CBS headquarters. ``It's like having a child,'' he once said. ``It's pretty hard to jerk yourself away from that entirely.'' Paley's CBS brought viewers such distinguished journalists as Murrow, Walter Cronkite and Eric Sevareid, as well as such hugely popular shows as ``I Love Lucy'' and ``All in the Family.'' ``He gave the public exactly what it wanted,'' said former programming chief Mike Dann. ``He wasn't the least bit interested in creating new forms. He believed in building the best mousetrap.'' Born in Chicago on Sept. 28, 1901, grandson of a Russian lumber magnate, Paley studied at Western Military Academy in Alton, Ill., and the University of Chicago. He received a Bachelor of Science degree at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School in 1922. He then joined his father's firm, the Congress Cigar Co. of Philadelphia, as vice president and secretary. He became interested in radio when he discovered the pull of radio ads for the firm's La Palinas cigar. With money borrowed from his father, Paley in 1928 bought the year-old United Independent Broadcasting Corp., changed its named to Columbia and began building his broadcasting empire. In 1990, according to Forbes magazine, he was worth $460 million. In April 1983, he turned the reins of CBS Inc. over to Thomas H. Wyman, only the second chairman in the company's history. But Paley stayed on as a consultant, director and chairman of the board of directors' executive committee. When CBS's biggest stockholder, Loew's Corp., became unhappy with Wyman's policies, Paley teamed with Loew's Chairman Laurence Tisch in 1986 to retake control. Paley again became chairman, with Tisch as president and chief executive officer. Paley also became a partner in 1982 in Whitcom Investment Co., which has wide-ranging communications holdings, including joint ownership of the International Herald Tribune. He became co-chairman of the Paris-based newspaper in 1983. Despite his reputed 80-hour work weeks at CBS, Paley became a patron of New York City's cultural life. He was a trustee of the Museum of Modern Art for 53 years and was one of the nation's leading collectors of post-Impressionist masterpieces. In 1976 he founded the Museum of Broadcasting in Manhattan, where the history of his network and others is enshrined. Paley also left a memorial to his father and a boon to Manhattan office workers in Samuel Paley Park on East 53rd Street, just off Fifth Avenue, the city's first ``vest-pocket'' park. Before awarding the hot-dog concession for the tiny park, Paley tasted dozens of varieties of hot dogs and ended up having them made to order, fatter than usual. He also ordered the cooking method - steam first, then grill. Paley became a fixture in New York's high society with the help of his second wife, ``Babe,'' the former Barbara Cushing, daughter of a famed Boston neurosurgeon, Dr. Harvey Cushing. During 31 years of marriage before Mrs. Paley's death from cancer in 1978, the couple entertained lavishly in their apartment in the St. Regis Hotel and on an 85-acre estate in Manhasset on Long Island's North Shore. During World War II, Paley served with the Office of War Information abroad and, with the rank of colonel, as deputy chief of psychological warfare for Gen. Dwight Eisenhower's Supreme Headquarters, Allied Expeditionary Forces. For his war service he received the Legion of Merit and Medal for Merit of his own country and the Legion of Honor and Croix de Guerre with Palm of France. Some of his other honors included personal citations in two Peabody Awards to CBS; the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences' Governors Award for ``steadfast commitment to quality'' in broadcasting; and the Robert Eunson Award of the Associated Press Broadcasters Association. Paley had two children, Jeffrey Paley and Hilary Paley Califano, by his first marriage to Dorothy Hart Hearst, from whom he was divorced; two by his second marriage, Kate Cushing Paley and William Cushing Paley; two stepchildren, Stanley G. Mortimer 3d and Amanda Burden; and eight grandchildren. Funeral plans were incomplete.

DOC.HEAD: Development Could Bring Cure for Baldness
DOC.TEXT: Scientists have grown hair in a test tube, a development they say could lead to a cure for baldness within a decade. ``This is the real thing,'' Dr. Terence Kealey, head of a research team at Cambridge University's Department of Clinical Biochemistry. ``We have for the first time succeeded in getting hair to grow in vitro,'' the balding scientist said Friday. Kealey stressed in a BBC radio interview that growing hair in a test tube ``is not in itself a cure for baldness.'' But, he added, it provides the perfect medium for experiments and could lead to effective treatment within 10 years. The results of the research, in which the hair was grown in a synthetic blood product, are to be published in the Journal of Cell Science next month. Experts welcomed the achievement, saying it could lead to preventing hair loss in men genetically disposed to baldness. ``Any knowledge of how hair grows and metabolizes could have various offshoots in preventing baldness from happening,'' said Dr. Ken Maxted, a dermatologist with the Glasgow Health Board who went bald at 18. ``Whether it is a cure for people who are bald, I'm not quite sure. I think it's rather nice having a waterproof head,'' he said in an interview. Dr. John Firmage, a consultant at the Scalp and Hair Hospital in London, said the research was an important first step to understanding what affects hair growth and loss. ``Until now, it has been very difficult to know what happens'' except that the process of balding is hereditary, Dr. Firmage said. ``Hence the many lotions and potions which are produced.'' Dr. John Romano at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center in New York said scientists would be able to test new chemicals on test-tube hair without worrying about injuring someone's scalp. ``Researchers can use many more different chemicals because they don't have to worry about toxicity,'' he said in a telephone interview. Kealey said the next step is to find out why many middle-aged men suffer a disruption in the normal mechanism that triggers the growth of new, replacement hair. ``I hope that within 10 years we could come up with a cure for baldness,'' he said. The successful growth of test tube hair came after a team member, Dr. Michael Philpott, devised a method for extracting hair follicles from the skin without damaging the roots, Kealey said. This is done by carefully slicing away the top two layers of skin to remove hair follicles with fine tweezers. The follicles then are grown in a synthetic blood substitute maintained at body temperature, he said. Watching hair growing in a test tube is ``an amazing sight,'' Kealey said. ``It grows absolutely identical to normal hairs - at the same rate of 0.012 inches a day and in the same shape.'' The research was funded by the Anglo-Dutch consumer giant Unilever and Britain's Science and Engineering Research Council, he said. Kealey said the research also could lead to a more effective depilatory for removing unwanted hair. Hairs grow for about two years and then spontaneously shed, he said, adding that a natural depilatory would result if the shedding process could be hastened. ``In fact, what we can do now in the laboratory is persuade hairs to shed in this very natural manner and so we hope that we might quite quickly start trying to work on improved depilatories,'' Kealey said. Cambridge University is known for its contributions to scientific research, including discovery of the electron, the neutron and the structure of DNA, the building blocks of genetic material. Kealey said that although he was ``thrilled'' at the team's breakthrough, as an intellectual achievement ``it has to be viewed as rather trivial.'' Nevertheless, many men will find the breakthrough welcome news since, Kealey said, the onset of balding can be ``intensely traumatic - maybe because it is the first visible sign of advancing age.'' ``I am myself bald, but I don't think it's something that bothers me very much,'' he added.

DOC.HEAD: Ferries May Provide Only Link To Hatteras For Months
DOC.TEXT: Hatteras Island residents may have to use ferries for up to six months after the only bridge to the island was hit by a dredge, toppling a 369-foot section into Oregon Inlet. Tourism officials worried that island businesses could lose millions of dollars. ``We estimate that, if the bridge is out three months or more, it will cost us between $18 and $20 million,'' said Gene O'Bleness, executive director of the Dare County Tourist Bureau. ``October and November are prime surf-fishing months on Hatteras.'' The bridge could be out for five to six months, said Clayton Jenson, superintendent of McLean Contracting of McLean, Va., which built the 26-year-old Herbert C. Bonner Bridge. A gale tore the dredge Northerly Island from its moorings, slamming it into the Bonner Bridge early Friday. A section f the span collapsed an hour later. No one was injured. The bridge carries telephone and power lines to Hatteras, and the accident left some of those lines dangling over the inlet. Power was out on Hatteras and on much of nearby Ocracoke Island, south of Hatteras in the barrier island chain that forms North Carolina's coastal Outer Banks. Electric and telephone companies were waiting for weather conditions to ease before trying to restore service at Hatteras, but most of Ocracoke's power was restored by mid-afternoon Friday. Water supplies also were limited on the islands, state officials said. Gov. Jim Martin declared a state of emergency after flying to the coast to survey the situation. ``From what I've seen, things are pretty well organized. What can be done is being done and plans are being made for the future. I'm pleased and impressed,'' Martin said after a briefing by county officials. Transportation Secretary Thomas Harrelson said the state was looking at landing points for ferries and its options on setting up a temporary crossing of the bridge. He estimated the work could cost $3 million. Ferries carrying up to 40 vehicles could be in service in about three weeks after ferry docks and access roads are constructed, he said. Authorities said three landing craft would be available by Monday to ferry supplies, such as food and fuel, and people across the inlet. The island's estimated 5,000 residents and an unknown number of tourists have had no way off the island. Ferry connections to Ocracoke couldn't be used because winds were gusting to 60 mph, creating waves of 5 to 7 feet in Pamlico Sound. There is no bridge to Ocracoke, where about 500 people live. Among those waiting for a ride off Ocracoke was David Carper of Ramseur, and he wasn't looking forward to the trip. ``I've never ridden a ferry. I have motion sickness so it wouldn't be real fun,'' Carper said as he and his wife, Barbara, waited at the ferry lounge. ``But rather than live here until the bridge is repaired, we thought we'd take the ferry when we could.''

DOC.HEAD: Americans Reported Missing After Ship Explosion
DOC.TEXT: An apparent gas leak caused an explosion aboard a tourist ship off the Galapagos Islands, injuring 11 people and leaving six others missing, authorities said. The Ecuadoran Navy and U.S. Embassy in Quito said there were reports that the missing in the blast early Friday included five Americans and an Ecuadoran crew member. There were conflicting reports that two Australians and three Americans were among the missing. The 71-foot ship Bartolome II was on an eight-day cruise of the islands 600 miles west of Guayaquil, Ecuador, when the explosion occurred at 4:15 a.m. The vessel, based in Quito, caught fire and quickly sank eight miles off the isle of Seymor, authorities said. Eleven people on board were rescued and were taken to the mainland for hospitalization and treatment. Most were believed taken to Quito, authorities said, but details remained sketchy late Friday. Four of the 11 were seriously hurt, they said. The remote islands, visited by the explorer Charles Darwin, are a popular tourist site replete with rare birds, fish and flora.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``The impression given by the first announcement of the report is that the committee sees the deaths of about 20 Palestinians and the injury of more than 100 Palestinians as a necessity that cannot be condemned.'' - Israeli legislator Yair Tsaban of the left-wing Mapam Party, criticizing a government report that says police shot Arab stone-throwers in self defense. --- ``Gentlemen, you are good men who have done a bad thing.'' - U.S. District Judge James Rosenbaum, who sentenced three former Northwest Airlines pilots to 12 months in prison for flying a commercial jetliner while intoxicated. --- ``There's a dilemma with that Smithsonian thing. It's like the song by The Who. `You want it? You want it? You caaaaaaan't have it.''' - Author Ken Kesey, who may or may not donate his famous psychedelic bus to the Smithsonian Institution.

DOC.HEAD: The Early Bird Gets the Ticket Dismissed
DOC.TEXT: Burleigh County jailers were puzzled when Patrick Kellar showed up for a court appearance at 4:30 a.m. But Kellar knew exactly what he was doing. According to an account in The Bismarck Tribune, the Bismarck man arrived at the courthouse, which also houses the county jail, five minutes early on Thursday and showed jailers a notice ordering him to appear in court on a contested speeding ticket at 4:30 a.m. The jailers told Kellar there would be no hearing at that hour. They wrote a note to the county clerk saying that Kellar had been there and sent him home. Some court employees wondered why Kellar hadn't called the office beforehand to correct what obviously was a typographical error on his summons. They discovered his motive when Kellar called the office later in the day. He read to the clerk the section of state law that says that if a defendant shows up in court at the appointed time and the prosecutor doesn't, the case has to be dismissed. Judge Gail Hagerty dismissed the ticket.

DOC.HEAD: State Department Warns Against Possible Terrorist Ship Attack
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf pvs, bgng Terrorists have, to CORRECT Achille Lauro hijacking to October 1985 sted December. Pick up 8th graf pvs, bgng One of.
DOC.TEXT: Terrorists could be planning to attack a passenger ship or aircraft ``at any time,'' the State Department says. The agency said Friday night that the attack could come on a passenger ship in the eastern Mediterranean Sea or an aircraft in Europe or the Middle East. ``The risk of acts of international terrorism in Europe and the Middle East is increasing,'' said a statement from the department's deputy spokesman, Richard Boucher. He said the department had received ``specific and credible'' information about a threat to ships in the eastern Mediterranean, and added, ``Such an operation may be undertaken at any time.'' He added, ``We note that civil aviation remains a particular target.'' The department's warning came after the unusual hour of 8 p.m., in part because,``It's important that we share the threat information with the American people as they plan their travel,'' said another spokesman, Adam Shub. Terrorists have attacked ships before. In October 1985, a group led by Abu Abbas hijacked the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro as it left an Egyptian port, holding it for two days before surrendering to Egyptian authorities. One of the hijackers shot to death an American passenger, Leon Klinghoffer, who was confined to a wheelchair. A particular reason for concern Friday was threats by the Abu Nidal Organization, which ``has repeatedly threatened to attack U.S. interests'' if Mahmoud Atta, a 37-year-old U.S. citizen and member of the organization, is extradited to Israel, the department said. Atta, who als uses the name Mahmoud El-Abed Ahmad, is wanted in Israel on charges of participating in the April 1986 machine gun attack on a bus carrying Jewish settlers in the occupied West Bank. The driver was killed and a passenger wounded. Arrested in the United States three years ago, Atta fought extradition in the courts but lost his last appeal in the U.S. Supreme Court on Aug. 31. The department has two months from that date to decide to turn him over to Israel, and Friday night Shub repeated earlier statements that it would do so. ``The United States takes these threats very seriously in view of the ANO's notorious history,'' Boucher said. Shub said the Nidal group was believed responsible for more than 90 terrorist attacks since 1974. Using the cover name ``Black September,'' it arranged the September 1970 hijacking of four airliners to an abandoned airfield in Jordan, he said. Among its attacks were bombings of the airports in Vienna and Rome in December 1985, the hijacking of a Pan Am airliner to Karachi in 1986 and the attack on the day excursion vessel City of Poros in Greece in July 1986, the department said.

DOC.HEAD: Smelly Monkeys Stolen From Zoo Returned
DOC.TEXT: Thieves may have thought they were getting cute house pets when they broke into a zoo and made off with two squirrel monkeys. Wrong. Squirrel monkeys weigh a few pounds each and look adorable. But they have a habit humans may find hard to stomach: ``They rub their urine onto their hands and feet and tails so that while they run around they're marking territory every time they touch something,'' said Ken Rudman, general curator of the Sedgwick County Zoo. ``They really do smell awful at times. Actually, that's most of the time,'' Rudman said. They're also aggressive, he said. Many zoo visitors think the South American monkeys would make great pets, Rudman said. ``I'd guess that whoever stole these was planning on having a neat pet to impress the friends with.'' Whoever took Spock and Mowgli by cutting through a security fence and crossing a moat in the zoo on Monday night has since reconsidered. On Thursday, someone checking into a motel about two miles from the zoo found an odd-smelling box in his room. Inside were Spock and Mowgli. ``Zoo Monkeys,'' read the label on the box. ``Return to the zoo.''

DOC.HEAD: Dog Doesn't Count in Car Pool, Judge Rules
DOC.TEXT: A judge turned down a motorist's argument that his dog should count in a car pool because the animal watched for cars and warned his master, whose eyesight is fading. Sherman Hill of San Francisco argued that Queenie was being trained as a ``seeing-eye driver'' and was learning to bark at the sight of cars. But San Jose Municipal Judge John Pasco said Queenie doesn't count as a rider. Vehicles with two riders may use car pool lanes in Santa Clara County. Pasco fined Hill $115 for driving solo in the commuter lane.

DOC.HEAD: Beleaguered Prime Minister Facing Party Revolt
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister V.P. Singh called a public rally today to try to contain a rebellion in his party and put a lid on growing pressure on him to resign. Environment Minister Maneka Gandhi quit Singh's Cabinet on Friday and released a letter accusing the prime minister of failing to keep his pledge of ``honesty and efficiency in government.'' Mrs. Gandhi was the first Cabinet minister to break openly with Singh since Tuesday when a Hindu-Moslem dispute over rights to a holy site ballooned into the worst political crisis of the 10-month-old government. Other dissidents of the governing Janata Dal party pressed for a change of leadership, arguing that dumping Singh could avert the government's collapse and the need for an immediate national election. Singh was scheduled to speak today at a rally outside his home in New Delhi, the capital. At least 93 people have been killed this week in rioting between Moslems and Hindus and in police efforts to quell the disturbances. The two latest deaths were reported today from a clash between police and a mob late Friday in Ranchi in the eastern state of Bihar. Police clamped an overnight curfew on Ayodhya, site of the disputed holy place, and on the neighboring town of Faizabad on Friday. Thousands of police reinforcements have been sent to the Hindu holy town 300 miles southeast of New Delhi. Hindu fundamentalists have vowed to build a temple at the site which they say is birthplace of Lord Rama, an important Hindu god. A Moslem mosque has stood there for 460 years. Police said they have detained 51,000 people in Uttar Pradesh state and seized more than 35,000 tribal spears, tridents and other weapons from Hindus on their way to Ayodhya. The Uttar Pradesh government has banned entry into the state by leaders of the Hindu political movements behind the temple project. The right-wing Bharatiya Janata Party withdrew its support for the government when Singh opposed the temple and arrested the party's leader, who was on a cross-country march to rouse support for the construction. The party's move deprived the National Front coalition of its majority in Parliament. Singh faces a no-confidence motion in a special session of the legislature Nov. 7. Barring a last-minute compromise or a realignment of political forces, he seems certain to lose. In addition to Mrs. Gandhi, four other Parliament members once considered close to Singh joined the call for him to step down even before the vote.

DOC.HEAD: Cold Weather in the East, Dust Storm in North Dakota
DOC.TEXT: The East had clear, cold weather early today, with temperatures dropping into the upper 20s in some regions. Skies were also clear in the South and Midwest. Winds of up to 50 mph caused a dust storm in northwest North Dakota on Friday night, cutting visibility to near zero in the Williston area. Eleven people were hospitalized with injuries sustained from traffic accidents, a nursing supervisor from Mercy Hospital said. No one was seriously hurt. Only the chance of showers in the northwest tip of Washington threatened a forecast of sunshine for the entire nation today. Winds were expected to die down in the East after gusting to 40 mph and higher Friday and temperatures should reach the 50s and 60s. High pressure in Nebraska was expected to bring warm air into the Rockies, raising temperatures to the 60s and 70s, and the Plains were looking for continued mild weather with highs in the 60s. Temperatures were expected to reach the 60s in the Northwest, the 70s and 80s in the South and the 90s in the Southwest. The high temperature for the nation Friday was 101 degrees at Borrego Springs, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Anti-Ershad Demonstrators Block Streets, Train Tracks
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of demonstrators blocked streets and train tracks today, halting most traffic in the capital to press their demands for President Hussain Muhammad Ershad to resign. Stores and offices closed, apparently out of fear of attacks, when what was intended to be a blockade of transport turned into a general strike. Groups of about 50 demonstrators staged sit-down strikes at about two dozen rail and road intersections in and around Dhaka, a city of 7 million people. Many people walked to work. Even bicycle-powered rickshaws, Dhaka's chief mode of transport, stayed off the streets. Protesters paraded through the streets shouting ``Down with Ershad!'' and ``Days of Autocracy Are Over!'' United News of Bangladesh said 4,000 police and paramilitary troops were deployed in Dhaka. There were no reports of violence by midday. The blockade was the latest tactic in the campaign by opposition parties to force Ershad to quit. At least eight people have been killed by police since the current round of protests started Oct. 10. ``We are happy to see that the blockade has turned into a hartal (general strike). This shows popular support for our cause,'' said Suranjit Sengupta, a top leader of the Democratic Party. It is one of eight parties in an alliance headed by the Awami League led by Sheik Hasina, one of the country's main opposition politicians. Ershad has dismissed the campaign against him as ``the work of a handful of violence-mongers who are out to destabilize Bangladesh.'' He was an army general when he seized power in a bloodless coup in 1982. He later resigned from the military and was elected president in 1986 in balloting that opposition parties, foreign diplomats and journalists said was rigged. He plans to seek another five-year term in elections scheduled for next year. The opposition parties say they will boycott the vote unless Ershad resigns and hands over power to a caretaker government.

DOC.HEAD: 44 Die in Floods, Landslides in South Indian Hills
DOC.TEXT: Floods and landslides caused by heavy monsoon rains have killed at least 44 people in the hills of southern India, Press Trust of India said today. Most of the deaths occurred Thursday and Friday in the Nilgiris, or the Blue Hills, 1,085 miles south of New Delhi. The news agency said 26 bodies had been recovered, and 18 other people were officially listed as dead. Large areas of Coimbatore in Tamil Nadu state were without tap water today because of damaged pipes and a breached water tunnel, the news agency reported. Weather forecasts said the heavy rains were expected to continue for at least two more days. Up to 3{ inches of rain fell Friday in parts of Tamil Nadu, the news agency said.

More Than 160,000 Gallons of Kerosene Spill in Hudson River, Coast Guard Says
DOC.TEXT: A barge ran aground in the Hudson River and spilled more than 160,000 gallons of kerosene, the Coast Guard said. The barge Hygrade 42 grounded and sprang a leak at 10:30 p.m. Friday about one mile south of here, said Bill Falk, a U.S. Coast Guard spokesman in New York. Workers apparently halted the leak this morning, but not before more than 160,000 gallons of kerosene had spilled, he said. The Coast Guard Pollution Response Team was at the scene, he said. The barge's New York City-based owner, Hygrade Operators, had hired a private company to help the cleanup, he said. Work boats, vacuum trucks and about 3,000 feet of containment boom were brought to the scene. The barge was heading north to Rensselaer, N.Y., when it ran aground, Falk said. While the cause of the grounding had not been determined, he said, high winds and choppy waters may have been a factor. The barge was carrying a total of 30,000 barrels of kerosene, or 1.26 million gallons, Falk said. Environmental damage caused by the spill was not immediately determined, Falk said, adding that kerosene evaportates easily, minimizing chances of major damage. The spill posed no threat to nearby residents. The site of the spill is about 50 miles north of the Statue of Liberty. Kerosene, an oil usually used to fuel lamps and furnaces and as a solvent, has a pungent odor. The Coast Guard said any spill of more than 100,000 gallons is considered major.

DOC.HEAD: Kesey Fires up Psychedelic Bus for Trip to Smithsonian
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `Ed McClanahan...', to CORRECT song lyric quotation.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto PD1
DOC.TEXT: Wake up, America. Ken Kesey has assembled a bunch of the old Merry Pranksters for a cross-country trip to deliver his psychedelic bus to the Smithsonian Institution. But here's Kesey's latest prank: When he gets there he might not really give them the bus. ``They did ask for (the bus) a long time ago,'' said Kesey, sitting at his kitchen table in his red long underwear after taking the bus for a spin past his neighbors' farms. ``This was going to be a swan song. But suddenly, the swan is up and dancing, and doing rap. ``There's a dilemma with that Smithsonian thing. It's like the song by The Who. `You want it? You want it? You caaaaaaan't have it.''' Now 55, Kesey was a young literary lion roaring with success from his novels ``One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest'' and ``Sometimes a Great Notion'' when he bought the bus to take a bunch of friends to the 1964 World's Fair in New York. Along the way the Pranksters became heroes of the free-love, acid-rock, turn-on, tune-in, drop-out 1960s, largely through Tom Wolfe's book, ``The Electric Kool-Aid Acid Test.'' Ed McClanahan - a writer pal of Kesey's who missed the first trip, but is coming along to chronicle the current one - figures the bus inspired The Who's ``Magic Bus'' song - the one with the lyrics ``I want it, I want it, I want it ... - You caaaaaaan't have it'' - and the Beatles' ``Magical Mystery Tour'' movie. ``That trip was a seminal moment in American culture,'' McClanahan said. The painted psychedelic swirls that made the bus a cultural icon originally were applied to keep it from looking like a school bus, said Kesey's wife, Faye. Over the next 25 years, the designs mutated and evolved into a mural that embodies Kesey's vision of the bus as a rallying symbol for saving the Earth. On the right side is Michelangelo's Adam from the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel. Dorothy, Tin Man, Scarecrow and Cowardly Lion skip up to the Emerald City, where a northern spotted owl is perched. On the left is a totem pole. Fish swim on the flanks. The hood ornament is a bronze jester. Over the windshield is its name, Further, worn like a crown to proclaim the bus' destination. The idea for this trip grew out of Kesey's latest book, ``The Further Inquiry.'' The book originally was conceived as a play staged on the bus, where the soul of Neal Cassady is put on trial. Cassady was the basis for the hero of Beat writer Jack Kerouac's ``On The Road,'' as well as the charismatic man behind the wheel of Further. On that first trip he laid down a free-association rap-babble that still makes Kesey shake his head in wonder and joy when he watches old home movies. Kesey wanted the book to include a movie of Cassady, printed one frame to a page, so that they moved as the pages were flipped. ``It's important to see how he jabbers and jumps,'' Kesey said. His publisher, Viking, agreed to include the flip pictures if Kesey would drive Further to a book fair in Las Vegas. He had so much fun that he planned a cross-country trip to ease Further into its grave at the Smithsonian and promote his new book. The latest trip won't be as wild as the others. ``We're grandparents now,'' Kesey said. He is scheduled to take Further to a book signing in Portland on Sunday. On Monday, he heads south to California, hoping to reach Berkeley by Halloween to help counterculture pal Wavy Gravy collect for UNICEF and campaign for City Council. After that, the schedule gets dim, though Kesey hopes to pick up LSD guru Timothy Leary and gonzo journalist Hunter S. Thompson along the way. But getting back on the road has given Kesey second thoughts about turning over the bus to the Smithsonian. ``This is why I would hate to see it laminated and stopped,'' Kesey said. ``It was just going good again.''

DOC.HEAD: Diplomats Leave London to Reopen Embassy in Tehran
DOC.TEXT: Five diplomats who will reopen the British Embassy in Tehran left London today saying they were giving priority to seeking the release of an imprisoned British citizen and Western hostages in Lebanon. Five Iranian diplomats were expected in London over the weekend to reopen their embassy, the Foreign Office said. David Reddaway, who will be charge d'affaires when the embassy opens, said he would seek an early visit with Roger Cooper, a 54-year-old businessman arrested five years ago on espionage charges. Reddaway expects to present his credential early next week, but there has been no word from the Foreign Office on when an ambassador will be posted to Tehran. ``Getting the hostages out of Beirut is a very high priority, as is securing the release of Roger Cooper,'' Reddaway said. ``I shall be asking to see Mr. Cooper as soon as I can after my arrival in Tehran.'' Iranian authorities have said Cooper has been tried and convicted, but the sentence has never been made public. Reddaway credited Iran with making ``its best humanitarian efforts'' to seek release of the 13 Western hostages in Lebanon. Most are believed held by factions of Hezbollah, or Party of God, a fundamentalist Shiite Moslem group that gets considerable financial support from Iran. The hostages include four Britons and six Americans. Longest-held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press who was kidnapped on March 16, 1985. Iran and Britain agreed to restore diplomatic relations last month. Ties were broken 18 months ago over British author Salman Rushdie, accused of blaspheming Islam in his novel, ``The Satanic Verses.'' The late Iranian leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini issued a death call on Rushdie in February 1989. The Indian-born novelist has been in hiding ever since.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Arrest Nine; Three Suspected Terrorists Killed
DOC.TEXT: Government troops arrested nine people in connection with a violent nationwide strike, and authorities today said the suspects were Communist rebels. Also today, soldiers killed two suspected terrorists in a car chase and in Manila, and a suspected terrorist was killed when a bomb he was holding went off, the military said. In the southern Philippines, rebels burned a bus, officials said. The walkout by leftist unions, which began Wednesday and was suspended Friday, has been marked by attacks on public transport. Marxist leaders, speaking to reporters, claimed responsibility for the burning of five of nine vehicles in the Manila area last week, but accused the military of carrying out the other attacks to discredit the strike. The rebels also denied killing Oscar Lazaro, a leader of a major transport organization, two days before the strike. The military has also blamed leftists for the murder. In another development, about 5,000 workers marched to Mrs. Aquino's presidential palace in central Manila for the second day, but no incidents were reported. The rally ended peacefully. Col. Agerico Kagaoan, chief of the Constabulary Security Group, said the suspected rebels were arrested in the Manila area in the past week. He said troops seized several sticks of dynamite, handguns and C-4 plastic explosives from the group. Kagaoan said those captured were members of the outlawed Communist Party of the Philippines, and said they were believed responsible for orchestrating strike-related violence. The suspects, who were presented briefly to reporters, denied involvement in any attacks. Police Col. Romeo Pena said in suburban Pasig, a man tried to throw an explosive device at a pumping station but it blew up in his hand, killing him instantly. He said the ictim carried no identification. Four hours later, another police patrol spotted a car with fake license plates and ordered it to stop, said Capt. Mario Cruz, an officer of the Constabulary Highway Patrol Group. He said the car's occupants immediately opened fire, hitting the police car. After a chase and an exchange of more gunfire, two of the suspected terrorists were killed, he said. Two others escaped in a backup car. The government has granted a 70-cent increase in the daily minimum wage, significantly below the $1.50 increase demanded by the unions. Striking workers announced they would settle for a $1 increase and said they were suspending the walkout to wait for the government to reply to their new offer.

DOC.HEAD: Wayward Pilot Pleads No Contest to 364 Securities Charges
DOC.TEXT: Thomas Root pleaded no contest to 364 counts of fraud and conspiracy but said he was chrged only because of his notoriety as the wounded pilot whose plane mysteriously crashed into the ocean last year. Under a plea bargain, Root agreed Friday to a 15-year prison sentence and a $5,000 fine in exchange for the no-contest plea. He also agreed to testify against others indicted in an alleged securities scam involving Sonrise Management Services and Telemedia Inc. Ninety-one other charges against him were dropped. His prison sentence, which won't be imposed until January, will run concurrently with any federal sentence he receives. He pleaded guilty to five federal securities charges in June and is awaiting sentencing. ``I accept the offer with great misgivings that people will believe that I am admitting to breaking the law in North Carolina,'' Root said. ``I did not break the law in North Carolina.'' He said he thinks his name was included in the indictment ``not because of my culpability but rather because (of) my notoriety,'' he said. The 37-year-old Washington attorney said he passed out in the cockpit of his single-engine plane during a flight from Washington to Rocky Mount in July 1989. The plane continued on to the coast of Florida before it crashed. Rescuers who pulled Root from the ocean discovered he had been shot in the abdomen. He said a pistol he kept in the plane discharged during the crash, but authorities questioned that explanation. A Nash County grand jury in June returned 24 indictments containing 2,695 counts against Root and other officials of Sonrise Management Services and Telemedia Inc. Sonrise helped form partnerships to apply for federal licenses for low-power FM radio stations with religious programming. Authorities said only a handful of Sonrise's 1,600 investors received licenses, although the organization allegedly took in more than $16 million from people in 25 states.

DOC.HEAD: Moore Concedes Defeat, Conservatives Win Landslide Victory
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf pvs, `Moore ... people' to DELETE incorrect population figure. Pick up 13th graf pvs, `In a...'
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Mike Moore conceded defeat today as the conservative National Party appeared headed for a landslide victory in parliamentary elections, ending six years of Labor rule. National Party leader Jim Bolger, who seeks better relations with the United States, was expected to assume a three-year term as the country's new prime minister. Moore, whose center-left party suffered from a faltering economy, phoned Bolger less than 2{ hours after the polls closed. ``I wish you well,'' he told a beaming Bolger, the 54-year-old son of Irish immigrant farmers. ``You worked hard for it.'' Final, unofficial results indicated National was likely to win 68 seats in the 97-member Parliament to 28 for Labor and one for New Labor. A handful of seats were close enough that they still could be decided by absentee ballots. Sveral Cabinet ministers were among the Labor casualties. National polled 49 percent of the vote to 35 percent for Labor. The Green Party, a relatively new political group that as part of its policy has no official leader, was third with 7 percent, with 5 percent for New Labor. Of the 2,158,966 registered voters, 1,636,184 - 76 percent - cast ballots. Labor had a 56-40 majority in the outgoing Parliament. The New Labor Party held the remaining seat. Both the Nationals and Labor pledge to continue barring nuclear-powered ships and ships with nuclear weapons from making port calls, a policy that has angered U.S. officials. But the National Party seeks some sort of reconciliation with Washington, and Bolger was welcomed in the U.S. capital at a time when other top New Zealand officials were not. Moore took over as prime minister two months ago when Geoffrey Palmer resigned with polls indicating Labor trailing by 21 points and heading for a landslide loss. Moore, 41, made a desperate last-minute bid Friday for support from environmentalists. In a country where pride in the environment runs high, Moore said any vote for the small Green Party actually would be a vote for the Nationals, whom he tried to paint as anti-conservationist. Greens' backers come primarily from Labor's traditional base. Moore had held out hope for an upset because the final polls indicated nearly a quarter of the electorate undecided just days before the election. Before Palmer resigned, Moore's backers were predicting Labor would retain only 15 of its seats in Parliament. Moore, the former external affairs and trade minister, worked hard to eat away at the government's budget deficit. He consistently ranked well above Bolger when voters were asked who they favored for prime minister. But Labor was dragged down by a sagging economy and its unpopular privatization efforts, which National branded as ``selling off the state silver to pay the bills.'' Unemployment is running at 7.9 percent, the highest level since World War II, and topped voter concerns in this South Pacific island nation of 3.5 million people. The country's policy against nuclear vessels and weapons, initiated in 1984 under Labor Prime Minister David Lange, kept U.S. warships from making port calls because the Pentagon refuses to divulge whether any are carrying nuclear weapons. In response to the policy, the United States in 1986 cut high-level contacts with New Zealand and dropped the country from the ANZUS military alliance, which also includes Australia.

DOC.HEAD: Breandan O hEithir, Irish Writer, Dead at 60
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Name of author, novel cq
DOC.TEXT: Breandan O hEithir, a keen social critic and author of the first Irish-language novel to lead the country's best-seller list, had died. He was 60. O hEithir, who divided his time between Dublin and Paris, was admitted to St. Vincent's Hospital last week and was diagnosed as having cancer. He died Friday. His novel ``Lig Sinn i gCathu,'' published in 1976, was the only Irish-language book ever to top the nation's hardback best-seller list. Translated in English as ``Lead Us Into Temptation,'' the book was set in a university town in 1948, the year Ireland declared itself a republic and withdrew from the Commonwealth. The book was also translated into German, and the accumulation of royalties in East German marks encouraged O hEithir to travel in that country. O hEithir was born Jan. 18, 1930 at Inishmore in the Aran Islands. His maternal uncle was the distinguished Irish writer Liam O'Flaherty. In 1957, O hEithir joined the Irish Press as Irish language editor and remained with the newspaper until 1963. He then lived for a time in Germany and married a French citizen, Catherine von Hildebrand. Returning to Ireland, O hEithir worked as a freelance scriptwriter for RTE, the national television service. He also wrote film scripts for Gael Linn, the Irish cultural organization, and was a regular columnist with The Irish Times. Other books included ``Over the Bar,'' ``The Begrudger's Guide to Irish Politics,'' ``This is Ireland,'' and ``Willie the Plain Pint agus An Papa.'' In ``The Begrudger's Guide,'' published in 1986, O hEithir identified begrudgers as the nation's largest faction. They were distinguished, he wrote, by ``a deep and abiding doubt about our ability to run our own affairs as well as others might run them for us.'' He continued: ``Even the most idiotic of Irish politicians would have to admit that the country has not actually flourished since independence was granted to us, 65 years ago. It would have to be admitted that the begrudgers in our midst have increased mightily and filled the land with their plaintive cries and lamentations.'' He is survived by his wife, three sons and a daughter. The funeral service will be held Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: 20 Tamil Rebels Killed in Air Attack
DOC.TEXT: Air force planes and helicopter gunships destroyed a major Tamil rebel base and killed 20 guerrillas in northeastern Sri Lanka, military officials said today. They said 10 buildings and a network of underground concrete bunkers, communication trenches and tunnels were destroyed in the attack Friday at Veragal village in the Trincomalee district. There was no independent confirmation of the report because of poor communications with the Veragal area, 130 miles northeast of Colombo. In the northern Jaffna Peninsula 185 miles northeast of Colombo, one soldier was killed when the Tamil Tiger rebels fired rockets and mortars at troops in a Hindu temple Friday, the officials said, speaking on their usual condition of anonymity. At least 14,000 people have been killed since 1983 when rebels from the Tamil minority started a violent separatist campaign against the Sinhalese majority. Sinhalese make up 75 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people and control the government and the military. Tamils, who comprise 18 percent of the population, say the Sinhalese discriminate against them in jobs, education and use of the Sinhala language.

DOC.HEAD: Belgium To Withdraw Troops On Nov. 1
DOC.TEXT: Belgium will withdraw its troops from Rwanda on Nov. 1, the prime minister said. He spoke one day after central African nations agreed to supervise a cease-fire in the war-torn nation. Prime Minister Wilfried Martens said the 500 paratroopers sent to Rwanda on Oct. 4 to protect Belgians living there would help evacuate civilians who wanted to leave the country, before pulling out. Ugandan-based rebels from Rwanda's minority Tutsi tribe invaded last month and advanced to within 40 miles northeast of Kigali, the capital. The rebels want to overthrow President Juvenal Habyarimana's government. They accuse Habyarimana, a Hutu, of corruption and say they seek a democratic government in which all ethnic groups can participate. The presidents of Rwanda, Uganda, Zaire and Burundu agreed Friday on measures to enforce the cease-fire established between Rwandan troops and rebels earlier in the week. The truce has already been broken several times. In a communique issued Friday after a meeting in Gbadolite, Zaire, the leaders of the four African nations agreed on the immediate formation of a three-nation military observer team to monitor the cease-fire. The communique also directs Yoweri Museveni of Uganda - chairman of the Organization of African Unity - to establish a peacekeeping force to be sent to Rwanda. The size and make-up of the force was not mentioned. Belgium, the former colonial ruler of Rwanda, will help set up the African peace force to monitor the cease-fire and will supply it with money and equipment, Martens said. The prime minister said, however, safety of Belgian civilians in Rwanda remained a priority and measures would be taken to evacuate them quickly if necessary. About 1,600 Belgians work in Rwanda, and most are missionaries, nuns, doctors and teachers. Two Belgian military transport planes will be stationed in a country neighboring Rwanda to evacuate Belgians if the need arises, Martens told a news conference. He did not specify which nation.

DOC.HEAD: Ruling Party Says It Will Accept Multiparty Democracy
DOC.TEXT: Angola's ruling Marxist party has outlined plans to accept a multiprty political system by March and hold pluralist elections within three years in the southern African nation. The announcement Friday evening by the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola, or MPLA, could speed negotiations to end 15 years of single-party rule and civil war with U.S.-backed UNITA rebels. The party's central committee said after an extraordinary meeting Friday that Angola's constitution should be fully revised within one year after preliminary changes planned for the next several months. In a speech Thursday, President Jose Eduardo dos Santos also hinted his party may soon drop its adherence to Marxism. The party said multiparty elections by direct universal suffrage could be held three years after a truce is reached. It said that would allow time to develop a climate of peace and conduct a census of the population. The party also recommended clearing minefields throughout the country and creating a single national army not tied to any political party. Peace talks between government and rebels are expected to resume within days in Portugal. The two sides met last month under Portuguese mediation for the fourth time this year. Portuguese officials said the opponents had reached broad agreement on adoption of multiparty democracy. In Washington last week, Congress approved a mechanism to quickly suspend military aid to UNITA if the Angolan government accepted a reasonable timetable for free elections, a cease-fire, a halt to shipments of Soviet weapons and other conditions. Angola's civil war has killed more than 350,000 people, caused widespread migrations and worsened the effects of a drought that has left about two million hungry this year, according to the government. UNITA, the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, has been fighting since independence from Portugal in 1975 to force the Soviet-backed MPLA to share control.

DOC.HEAD: Territories May Reopen Sunday, Shomron Expects Increase In Attacks
DOC.TEXT: Palestinians in the occupied territories may be allowed to re-enter Israel as soon as Sunday but will face tougher security measures, Israeli army chief of staff said today. More than 1.7 million Palestinians in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip have been confined to the territories since Wednesday following a wave of Arab-Jewish street violence. The chief of staff, Lt. Gen. Dan Shomron, said the situation in the occupied areas and within Israel now appeared quiet. ``If it continues to be quiet we will open the territory ... soon, maybe even on Sunday,'' he told Israel radio. Israeli government officials say the final decision is expected Saturday night. The closure cut off about 110,000 to 150,000 Palestinians, among them laborers who have no work permits, from jobs in Israel. When they return, they will be met with stricter security steps, Shomron said. ``We will ask the employers, in a much more serious manner, not to employ unlicensed workers, in order to safeguard themselves and others. They, too, are responsible for preventing terror attacks,'' he said. In addition, the number of Palestinians banned from traveling to Israel for security or criminal offenses - now several thousand people - will be increased, Shomron added. The upsurge in the 34-month-old Palestinian uprising, Shomron said, is linked to the Oct. 8 shooting on Temple Mount in Jerusalem, where Israeli police killed 20 Arab rioters and wounded 140. Five people have been killed and 11 wounded in subsequent Arab-Jewish street violence. ``There are situations, as it happened after the Temple Mount, in which an unusually large part of the population participates in the events. A small part had also acted individually, carrying out revenge attacks,'' Shomron said. Israel also expects an increase in cross-border guerrilla raids following the Temple Mount shootings, he said. ``It is known that following the Temple Mount, there is a greater motivation to act against Israel, to attack it from the borders and not only within the territories or the Green Line,'' Shomron said in reference to Israel's pre-1967 borders. ``We have no doubt that we can expect repeated (attack) attempts.'' Israel captured the West Bank from Jordan and the Gaza Strip from Egypt in the 1967 Middle East war. These lands are the scene of the Palestinian revolt in which at least 766 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians. Some 289 Arabs have been slain by fellow Palestinians as alleged pro-Israeli collaborators. Fifty-one Israelis also have died.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev: Iraqis Understand No Solution Through Ultimatums
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th pvs, `French officials...' to DELETE outdated material. Pickup 12th pvs, `Although the ...' ^By ANDREW KATELL
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail Gorbachev hinted today the Iraqi leadership might be softening its hard-line position on the Persian Gulf crisis, and reiterated that military force should not be used to end the conflict. The Soviet president said indications from Iraq that its position might be changing will be clarified in coming days, but he did not elaborate. Gorbachev spoke at a joint news conference with Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez on the second day of a three-day visit to Spain, the first to this country by a Soviet head of state. Emphasis on the crisis, which began with Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, was expected to continue Sunday evening when Gorbachev travels to Paris for a 24-hour visit that includes talks with French President Francois Mitterrand. In the news conference, Gorbachev ruled out using military force against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. He cited the suffering such action would cause the Iraqi people and the 3,000 Soviet specialists remaining in Iraq. ``Until the very end, we must take advantage of everything within our reach to find a peaceful solution to this problem,'' Gorbachev said. The Soviet leader's personal envoy, Yevgeny Primakov, is scheduled to go to Baghdad on Sunday for the second time in a month. Gorbachev also said there were indications there might be changes in the hard-line position within the Iraqi leadership toward the gulf crisis. ``In recent days, there are signals that in the Iraqi leadership there is an understanding that solution of problems cannot be achieved through ultimatums,'' Gorbachev said in Russian translated into Spanish. ``I may be mistaken, and the coming days maybe will bring some clarification.'' The private French television station La Cinq said Friday that Saddam had sent letters to both Mitterrand and Gorbachev expressing his readiness to discuss Middle East problems, including Kuwait. French officials denied knowledge of any letters. Although the gulf crisis was expected to figure heavily in talks, the Soviet leader hopes to come away from both Madrid and Paris with solid assurance of economic assistance to his country's collapsing economy. Among the Hispano-Soviet accords to be signed today was a $1.5 billion line of credit to Moscow for buying Spanish equipment to modernize Soviet plants making clothing, food and construction materials. Spain seeks guarantees in return from the Soviets on facilitating hard currency transfers, the major stumbling block faced by its 20 joint venture companies in the Soviet Union. Gonzalez and Foreign Minister Francisco Fernandez Ordonez plan to inform their 11 European Community partners on Soviet economic problems and the outcome of the gulf talks at the EC summit in Rome later today. In a welcoming toast at a formal dinner Friday night honoring Gorbachev and his wife Raisa, King Juan Carlos called the gulf crisis ``perturbing and a cause for serious concern.'' He went on to stress the importance of maintaining a solid international front under United Nations auspices against the Iraqi invasion and subsequent annexation of Kuwait. Both Spain and the Soviet Union back U.N. sanctions against Iraq and seek a political settlement to the crisis. Spain has sent a navy frigate and two corvettes to the gulf region in support of the U.N. trade embargo.

DOC.HEAD: Tourism Minister Backs Plan to Make Robben Island a Resort
DOC.TEXT: Tourism Minister Kent Durr supports a plan to convert the notorious Robben Island prison into a tourist resort and park, a newspaper reported Saturday. African National Congress leaders such as Nelson Mandela, Walter Sisulu and others were imprisoned on the island off Cape Town, known for its harsh winter weather. The Saturday Star said a possible feature of the resort would permit guests to stay in the Mandela Suite - the ANC leader's former cell. A group of Cape Town businessmen have proposed converting the island prison into a resort capable of accommodating 1,500 visitors at a time and including a yacht club, golf course, tennis courts and landing strip. One of the businessmen, Nick Malherbe, told the newspaper the goal was to make Robben Island a national landmark. The government has not taken any steps to date to convert the prison, which still is in operation.

DOC.HEAD: Voters Elect Four Provincial Legislatures In Test Of Right-Wing Alliance
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with 25 dead, 100 wounded in election-related violence. Pick up 5th graf pvs, `Election officials...'
DOC.TEXT: Voters returned to the polls today to elect four provincial legislatures, a test of the right-wing alliance that defeated Benazir Bhutto. Officials reported at least 25 deaths in clashes between rival parties. The provincial elections came three days after the Islamic Democratic Alliance defeated Ms. Bhutto's populist Pakistan People's Party by more than a 2-to-1 margin. That denied her a second chance to lead this predominantly Moslem country of 110 million people. The 37-year-old former prime minister accused the army-backed caretaker government of large-scale vote rigging, a charge that a team of international poll watchers rejected. Despite unprecedented security, officials said at least 25 people were killed and as many as 100 injured in clashes between rival parties, officials said. Most of the casualties occurred in eastern Punjab Province, a longtime stronghold of Ms. Bhutto's opponents. Election officials said turnout today among Pakistan's 50 million eligible voters was moderate to very light, and many polling stations were empty. They reported heavy turnout in several constituencies in Karachi, Ms. Bhutto's hometown. First results from the election were not expected before noon EDT. The legislatures of Punjab, Sindh, Baluchistan and Northwest Frontier provinces were disbanded Aug. 6, just hours after Ms. Bhutto's 20-month-old government was dismissed on charges of corruption and incompetence. More than 3,700 candidates are vying for 483 seats in the four assemblies. Ms. Bhutto's party contested the election despite calls by some loyalists to boycott. The Islamic Democratic Alliance is expected to sweep the 248-member assembly in eastern Punjab, the country's wealthiest and most populous province and a longtime stronghold. The stakes were highest for Ms. Bhutto in Sindh, her home province and political power base. Analysts say winning a majority in the 109-member assembly was Ms. Bhutto's only hope of maintaining any power. Sindh and its capital, Karachi, have been wracked by ethnic violence that has claimed nearly 3,000 lives in the past five years. Ms. Bhutto's inability to stop the relentless bloodshed was one of the reasons cited by President Ghulam Ishaq Khan for dismissing her government. About 100,000 soldiers, paramilitary troops and police have been patrolling the country's most volatile areas during this week's balloting. More than half have been deployed across Sindh. At least nine people were killed and more than 60 others injured in clashes between rival parties during Wednesday's voting for the National Assembly, the policy-making lower house of Parliament that chooses Pakistan's prime minister. Ms. Bhutto and her supporters have charged the caretaker government and her opponents of widespread vote tampering, alleging ballot boxes were switched, party workers killed and election officials attacked by armed gangs. But a 40-member observer team from the Washington-based National Democratic Institute said Friday its preliminary findings showed no evidence to support the contentions by Ms. Bhutto, who plans to challenge the figures in court. Sartaj Aziz, finance minister in the caretaker government, said Friday he hoped the observer team's observations would convince Washington to reinstitute $573 million aid package. Washington suspended economic and military aid on Oct. 1, demanding greater assurances from Islamabad that Pakistan neither possesses or wants to possess nuclear weapons.

DOC.HEAD: Negative Ads Punctuate Final Days of Gubernatorial Campaign
With AM-Campaign '90, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The California gubernatorial campaign is rushing into its final days on a tide of negative advertising, as Democrat Dianne Feinstein and Republican Sen. Pete Wilson jockey for the lead in the neck-and-neck race. Feinstein is lashing out at Wilson's record in Congress, while Wilson blasts Feinstein for negative campaigning in her attempt to succeed retiring Gov. George Deukmejian. A new Feinstein ad describes how Wilson was wheeled into the Senate on a gurney after a 1985 emergency appendectomy to cast the deciding vote to freeze Social Security benefits. The audio portion of the ad has Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., quipping that Wilson votes better ``under sedation.'' Wilson calls the ad ``the ugliest and most mean-spirited commercial of 1990.'' His campaign describes it as ``a sign of desperation'' by Feinstein. Wilson's commercials, meanwhile, feature segments of earlier Feinstein commercials accompanied by news stories describing them as fraudulent and dirty. The Los Angeles Times poll reported Feinstein ahead by 41 percent to 39 percent in September and Wilson overtaking her for a 42-41 lead in early October. Mervin Field's California Poll reports a 47-42 Wilson lead, compared with 45-42 in September, while pollster Steve Teichner found a 37-30 Wilson lead in mid-October, compared with 37-35 in early October. President Bush was in California last week to campaign for Wilson, but Wilson was in Washington as Congress put the finishing touches on the budget-deficit reduction package. Wilson, who won re-election to the Senate in 1988, had been harshly criticized by some for campaigning at home while Congress had unfinished business. There have been no major issues in the campaign to clearly differentiate the candidates. As a result, issues such as Wilson's attendance record in the Senate and Feinstein's endorsement four years ago of controversial former state Chief Justice Rose Bird have taken on significance in the campaign. Both candidatss have tried to portray themselves as political outsiders despite Wilson's 24 years as a state legislator, mayor and U.S. senator, and Feinstein's 20 years as San Francisco supervisor and mayor.
