DOC.HEAD: New Malaysian Cabinet Sworn In Before King
DOC.TEXT: Mahathir Mohamad was sworn in Saturday at the National Palace for his third term as prime minister. Along with the 64-year-old prime minister, 24 other Cabinet members and deputy ministers were sworn in. The ceremonies followed the leading National Front party's victory in parliamentary elections last week. The National Front has ruled the country since independence from Britain in 1957. Mohamad will serve a five-year term.

DOC.HEAD: Anderson's Birthday Spent In Captivity, Report Says Waite To Be Freed Soon
LaserPhotos BEI1,2
DOC.TEXT: Lebanese newspapers published birthday letters to American journalist Terry Anderson on Saturday, his 43rd birthday in captivity. One newspaper reported that fellow hostage Terry Waite will be freed soon. Seven newspapers printed birthday greetings to Anderson from his sister, Peggy Say, his youngest daughter, Sulome, and Madeleine, Sulome's mother. They published the original English text so that Anderson, who did not know Arabic when he was kidnapped, would be able to read them if his kidnappers allowed him to. The newspaper ad-Diyar, meanwhile, said British hostage Terry Waite would be freed either ``by the end of this month or within the first half of the coming November, at the latest.'' The short, front-page report attributed the information to an unnamed security source. The conservative ad-Diyar is not known to have special insight into the hostage issue, but the report was the latest predicting Waite's release since Iran and Britain agreed to restore diplomatic ties Sept. 27. Waite, 51, an Anglican Church envoy, was kidnapped Jan. 20, 1987 after leaving his west Beirut hotel to negotiate with representatives of Anderson's kidnappers. He is believed held by Islamic Jihad, the pro-Iranian group that abducted Anderson. Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, is the longest-held of the 13 Western hostages in Lebanon. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985. His birthday was marked by his colleagues as well as local and foreign journalists with a somber gathering at the Associated Press bureau. It was held in Anderson's office, which his colleagues refer to as ``Terry's Room.'' The staff sang ``Happy birthday, Dear Terry'' and blew out a candle on a white cake. The newspapers also published an Arabic translation of Mrs. Say's open letter to the captors, pleading with them to release Anderson and the other captives. ``I beg you to release Terry and the others for humanitarian reasons. Please, in honor of his birthday, give Terry and the others the gift of freedom this year,'' Mrs. Say wrote. ``His daughter Sulome, whom he has never seen, started school last month. His daughter Gabrielle has matured from a child of 8 to a young woman of 14,'' she added. Along with Sulome's hand-written letter, some papers published a pencil drawing by the child, who was born 83 days after her father's abduction. The drawing showed happy children playing. ``To Dad. I love you. Happy birthday. I go to proper school. I do work, tracing, art, math. I can write and read. I love you,'' Sulome's letter said. Former Irish hostage Brian Keenan said after his release Aug. 24 that he had spent part of his four years in captivity with Anderson, and he noted that Anderson has a photograph of Sulome and was given letters from his family published in the press. ``Terry and myself would sit through those long nights and speak with great pain and remorse and longing for his daughter,'' Keenan said. Madeleine, addressing ``My Dearest Darling Terry,'' wrote: ``Another birthday, another year, another letter. A question I ask myself every day and the answer I always want to give is `soon, soon.''' In addition to Anderson and Waite, the Westerners missing in Lebanon are five Americans, three Britons, two Germans and an Italian.

DOC.HEAD: Spark Sets Off Blaze in Hospital During Unsuccessful Attempt to Revive Child
DOC.TEXT: A fire broke out in a hospital as doctors were making a vain attempt to revive a 13-month-old girl suffering from a heart condition, authorities said. The girl died. The child, whose identity was not released, was brought to St. Louis Children's Hospital by her parents when she became ill Friday, officials said. The infant was critically ill and hospital personnel had been trying to resuscitate her for about two hours when the fire broke out when a spark from a heart-lung machine set a surgical drape afire, the hospital said. Although the girl suffered burns on the legs and arms, the fire was not believed to be the cause of death, said hospital spokesman Dave Welborn. A nurse suffered smoke inhalation and was treated at the hospital. Ten other babies in the pediatric intensive care unit were evacuated and were not injured, the statement said.

DOC.HEAD: House Approves New Deficit-Reduction Package
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 2 grafs after 7th graf pvs, bgng: For all, to UPDATE with Bush comments on bill's passage; SUBS 20th graf pvs, -The House, to UPDATE with Senate approval of clean air bill
DOC.TEXT: A nearly $250 billion deficit-reduction package of tax increases and spending restraints supported by President Bush and Democratic leaders was approved by the House early today over the opposition of most Republicans. The 228-200 vote sent the bill to the Senate, which was to consider it later in the day. The bill was supported by 181 Democrats and 47 Republicans; 74 Democrats and 126 Republicans opposed it. ``The American people have had enough of ... (being told) that somehow we can confront the deficit and it doesn't involve pain,'' Rep. Leon Panetta, D-Calif., chairman of the House Budget Committee, said in pleading for support.``The fact is that it does and that is what this package is all about.'' ``By doing this, we have reduced the debt on each of our kids by $2,000,'' said Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill. Republicans complained that the plan, which includes the second biggest tax increase in history, was being considered in the middle of the night without members even having a chance to read it. And they said the tax increases would just lead to more spending. ``Deficit reduction? It's almost an obscenity to call it that'' because the deficit would continue to rise, said Rep. Craig James, R-Fla. For all the bill's problems, said House Republican Leader Robert Michel of Illinois, ``The American people would rather have imperfect progress than perfect paralysis.'' President Bush, attending a summit of Pacific leaders in Honolulu, told reporters he was ``very pleased it passed the House.'' He said many Republican members of the House ``had understandable opposition to many of the individual provisions, but I'm very pleased that it passed. I'm hoping it will get by the Senate.'' The new bill, the heart of a plan expected to shave $496 billion off the federal deficit over the next five years, includes higher taxes on gasoline, tobacco, alcoholic beverages and certain luxury goods. It would reduce spending for Medicare by about $44 billion, curtail farm subsidies and shift a sizable portion of the federal tax burden onto the well-to-do. ``I certainly think we have the votes in the Senate to pass it,'' said Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, chairman of the Finance Committee. The measure, which was passed by the House at 7 a.m. near the end of a 21-hour work day, is so voluminous that one copy fills a box the size of an apple crate. Senate passage would send the measure to Bush, who abandoned his no-tax-increase pledge in the interest of deficit reduction. Disposal of the deficit plan and spending bills to keep the government in operation over the next 11 months would clear the way for adjournment of Congress until January. Congressional leaders continued negotiating with administration officials right up to the time the deficit bill was sent to the House floor for debate. The lingering hangups were not over the tax provisions - making up the second largest tax increase in history - but over how deeply to restrain spending on health programs. The bill would raise the 9-cent gasoline tax by 5 cents, double the tax on beer to 32 cents a six-pack, raise taxes on wine and liquor and impose a luxury tax a portion of the price of expensive cars, jewels and furs. It would raise the top tax rate paid by the wealthiest people from 28 percent to 31 percent, limit itemized deductions for people over the $100,000 income level and gradually eliminate personal tax exemptions for high-income taxpayers. The measure would raise taxes by $137.2 billion over the next five years, Restraints in Medicare, Medicaid, farm subsidies and other mandatory spending programs would raise the deficit reduction in the bill to about $240 billion. Adding cuts in discretionary spending, chiefly for the military, and interest savings due to less borrowing would raise the total deficit package to $496 billion. That is shy of the $500 billion target agreed to early in the summer by congressional leaders and the administration. The bill falls short because the gasoline tax increase was scaled back and some unpopular spending cuts were moderated. The measure is built around a plan worked out by top officials during five months of negotiation. The first version was killed in the House, principally because of even larger increases in gasoline taxes and costs for Medicare beneficiaries. As Congress began the final push toward adjournment: -The House passed, 401-25, and sent to the Senate for final action today a major revision of clean-air laws. The Senate passed the measure 89-10 and sent it to Bush. The bill would cost an estimated $22 billion a year to reduce smog, acid rain and industrial pollution. -The Senate completed action on a $268 billion defense bill that includes a scaling back of some weapons systems. The measure now goes to President Bush for his signature. -Negotiators for the House and Senate reached a compromise on a $25.5 billion foreign-aid bill. It includes Bush's request to forgive $6.7 billion of Egypt's military debt to the United States. -On a voice vote, the House completed congressional action on a measure that requires nutrition labels on packaged foods. While Congress neared completion of the massive bill to cut this year's deficit, the Treasury Department reported that the red ink for the 12 months that ended Sept. 30 totaled $220.4 billion - up 43.7 percent from the previous year. The administration is predicting this year's deficit will total a record $254 billion if the deficit-reduction package becomes law. Without the tax increases and spending restraints, which would total about $40 billion this year, the deficit would hit almost $294 billion. By the end of the next five years, the current $3.1 trillion national debt is expected to be $5 trillion.

DOC.HEAD: President Puts Aside Politics for Pacific Summit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 4 grafs after 3rd graf pvs bgng ``Today's meeting ...'' to include House passage of budget compromise and Bush comment
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is taking time out from cross-country politicking to meet with leaders of 11 Pacific island nations worried that their region could become a dumping ground for old U.S. chemical weapons. ``I think it's a good time and I think it's about time that an American president sat down with the heads of these countries out there and tell them that we are as one in our respect for and love of the Pacific,'' Bush said Friday night. Today's meeting comes during a two-day stop in Hawaii, where Bush lent a hand to Republican Rep. Patricia Saiki's bid to unseat Democratic Sen. Daniel Akaka. She stayed in Washington as the House debated the budget bill, but sent a videotape in which she thanked Bush for stopping the use of the island of Kahoolawe as a bombing range. The House passed the deficit-reduction package in a 228-200 vote at 7 a.m. EDT. Bush, who arose for an early morning swim in the balmy sunshine outside his resort hotel in Honolulu, was asked by reporters for reaction to the budget agreement. ``I'm very pleased it passed the House,'' Bush said as he shook the water out of his t-shirt and shorts. A small crowd of tourists followed as he crossed the beach to the hotel. He said many Republican members of the House ``had understandable opposition to many of the individual provisions, but I'm very pleased that it passed. I'm hoping it will get by the Senate.'' Bush came to Hawaii from a pair of campaign appearances in Southern California, where he verbally bludgeoned the Democrats who control Congress for ``age old-tax-and-spend plicies.'' He also accused them of lacking commitment to civil rights. The agenda at today's Pacific summit included discussion of the hazards involving destruction of U.S. chemical munitions at Johnston Atoll, a U.S.-held ring of islands 825 miles southwest of Hawaii. Those invited to participate included the leaders of Fiji, Nauru, Papua New Guinea, the Solomon Islands, Tonga, Western Samoa, the Cook Islands, Kiribati, the Marshall Islands, Micronesia and Tuvalu. For months, Pacific islanders have expressed concern about plans to destroy chemical weapons from American military bases in Europe and Asia at a giant new incinerator on Johnston Atoll. Two Navy ships carrying 100,000 artillery shells packed with nerve agents, the Army's stockpile from West Germany, are expected to reach the atoll next month. All U.S. chemical weapons stockpiles outside the mainland are stored either on the atoll or in West Germany. The government insists it will neither make Johnston Atoll a permanent toxic waste-disposal site nor maintain chemical weapons there. But it does intend to destroy the munitions stored there and those en route from Germany. U.S. officials have promised to carry out the operation in an environmentally sound manner, and ``as safe as humanly possible,'' according to a State Department fact sheet on the problem. The United States and the Soviet Union have agreed to destroy such weapons by 1997. Environmental groups oppose the destruction, and the South Pacific Forum, an organization of regional governments, has complained the plan could make the region ``the toxic waste disposal center of the world.'' The forum's chairman, Prime Minister Geoffrey A. Henry of the Cook Islands, said the Johnston Atoll issue would be the top theme on the summit agenda. ``It's of great importance to the people here,'' said Bob Wernet, spokesman for Rep. Saiki. The Hawaii congresswoman supports allowing the destruction of the chemicals already en route from Europe and already stockpiled on the atoll, but not allowing any stockpiles to be shipped from the mainland as of next year. She has introduced legislation in Congress to that effect. Tests of the incinerator are to end late next year, and full-scale incineration is expected to begin in 1992. The island leaders also were expected to press Bush to sign the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty, which would ban the testing, dumping and storage of nuclear weapons and nuclear waste in the region. Before leaving for Hawaii, Bush on Friday attempted to distance himself from the tax increases his administration negotiated with Congress for a deficit-reduction package. He said the legislative branch was to blame for the ``strong medicine'' Americans now have to take. Speaking at a luncheon for Sen. Pete Wilson's GOP gubernatorial campaign in Los Angeles, Bush also accused Congress of trying to embarrass him on the civil rights issue. He vetoed the sweeping anti-job discrimination bill passed by Congress, claiming its provisions would force businesses to establish minority hiring quotas. Sponsors strongly denied that, but they fell one vote short in the Senate in an attempt Wednesday to override the veto. Bush sent Congress an alternative bill that civil rights advocates said guts their legislation. Administration officials have privately claimed that Democrats want to use the veto as an election issue. Bush said lawmakers were ``sitting around up there now. They could pass it (his alternative) in 20 minutes if there was a genuine interest in civil rights and less interest in trying to embarrass the president of the United States.''

DOC.HEAD: Quakes Gets Subdued Response From Neighbors of Long Valley Volcano
DOC.TEXT: Eight years after a volcano scare incited fear, anger and economic gloom in Sierra resorts, residents are nonchalant about renewed underground lava movement that is triggering thousands of tiny earthquakes. Scientists say there is a very small chance of a volcanic eruption. But most of the quakes are too small to be felt, so ``you don't really think about it,'' said Pam Murphy, spokeswoman for Mammoth Mountain Ski Area. ``You can get hit by a car,'' she said. ``You can be in a plane crash. The chances of those are a lot higher than the chance of being killed by an earthquake or a volcano.'' ``People who are frightened left long ago. I don't believe it's a conscious concern of anyone in the community,'' said Mammoth Lakes Mayor Gordon Alper. The resort town's 4,700 permanent residents live in Long Valley, a 19-mile-long, 9-mile-wide volcanic crater known as a caldera. It is located on the east slope of the Sierra Nevada range 250 miles north of Los Angeles. The Earth's crust is being stretched apart in the region, allowing molten rock to fill half-mile-wide chambers under the caldera. The valley was created 730,000 years ago by one of Earth's most powerful eruptions, a blast that spewed 600 times more material than the May 1980 eruption of Mount St. Helens in Washington state. Eruptions somewhat smaller than Mount St. Helens' happened 550 years ago at the Inyo craters, which span Long Valley's north rim, and 650 years ago at the Mono craters, several miles north of the caldera. Despite the current activity, the probability of a major earthquake or a volcanic eruption in the area is ``less than 1 percent each year,'' said David Hill, the U.S. Geological Survey geophysicist in charge of research at Long Valley. Mono County Sheriff Martin Strelneck called such estimates ``a scientific guessing game,'' and said area residents rarely discuss the latest swarm of earthquakes, which started in May 1989. That low-key attitude contrasts with feelings of anxiety, denial and hostility when thousands of quakes - some exceeding 6 on the Richter scale - rocked the area from 1979 to 1984. During that period, subterranean molten rock pushed upward, lifting the caldera's floor. As a result, the Geological Survey issued a ``notice of potential volcanic hazard'' for Long Valley in May 1982. That warning, coupled with jarring earthquakes, damaged tourism and aggravated a recession in the once-booming real estate market. ``The community overreacted,'' Murphy said. Residents accused journalists of sensationalizing the possibility of an eruption and denounced scientists for scaring people. ``Initially we thought this was a big ploy for them to get funding from Congress,'' Alper said. The hazard notice was rescinded in 1984 after the beleaguered Geological Survey changed its warning system and seismic activity diminished, reducing the possibility of an eruption. Swarms of thousands of small quakes resumed 18 months ago and continue to rattle Mammoth Lakes, June Lake, Lee Vining and other Mono County resort towns. The temblors, most measuring 1 to 3 on the Richter scale, started beneath Mammoth Mountain. In September 1989, they shifted to the caldera, where five to 10 small quakes now happen daily. A quake estimated at 5 to 5.8 on the Richter scale shook the region last Tuesday, tumbling rocks onto Yosemite National Park's roads. It was eastern California's largest quake since 1984, but wasn't related to volcanic activity that causes the quake swarms, Hill said. Long Valley's floor continues to bulge upward as molten rock moves inside two or three chambers about four miles under the caldera, he said. The caldera floor rose about 2 feet since 1979, including 3 inches in the past year. While Long Valley ``is clearly an area that's showing unrest, large calderas can do these kinds of things over years to decades without necessarily erupting,'' Hill said. The floor of a caldera near Naples, Italy, rose 9 feet between 1970 and 1984 but didn't erupt. Comparable uplift inside a New Guinea caldera also failed to produce volcanic disaster. Nevertheless, Hill said, eastern Sierra residents are addressing the volcanic threat by developing or revising emergency plans and helping the Geological Survey prepare a new system to issue a warning if an eruption appeared likely.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev: New Signals hat Iraq Abandoning Ultimatums
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for item slugged AM-Spain-Gorbachev on digest.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MAD1,3
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev hinted Saturday that the Iraqi leadership might be softening its hard-line position in the Persian Gulf crisis. His remarks were interpreted as a sign that the Kremlin has made progress in its diplomatic initiatives in the Persian Gulf. They came a day before a Kremlin envoy was to meet with Saddam Hussein in Baghdad. Gorbachev spoke at a news conference with Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez on the second day of a three-day visit, the first to Spain by a Soviet head of state. He said there were indications there might be changes in the hard-line position Iraq has taken since it invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. ``In recent days, there have been signals from the Iraqi leadership that ... solution of problems cannot be achieved through ultimatums,'' Gorbachev said. ``I may be mistaken, and the coming days might bring some clarification.'' He did not elaborate on the Iraqi signals. A French TV station, however, reported Friday that Saddam had sent letters to both French President Francois Mitterrand and Gorbachev expressing his readiness to discuss Middle East problems, including Kuwait. The station, La Cinq, quoted Saddam as saying he was open ``to all ideas'' for resolving the gulf crisis. French officials denied knowledge of any letters. On Friday, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze reported a change in Iraq's position to his Spanish counterpart, Francisco Fernandez Ordonez. Shevardnadze said without elaborating that Iraq is ``searching for some kind of dialogue,'' according to a Spanish official. The emphasis on the crisis was expected to continue Sunday evening when Gorbachev travels to Paris for a 24-hour visit that include talks with Mitterrand. The trip coincides with Saddam's promised release of the 327 French hostages from Iraq and Kuwait. Gorbachev discussed the crisis Saturday with Gonzalez, and the two issued a joint political declaration calling Iraq's invasion ``flagrant violation of the norms of international law.'' In the news conference, Gorbachev ruled out using military force against Saddam. He cited the suffering such action would cause the Iraqi people and the 3,000 Soviet specialists remaining in Iraq. ``Until the very end, we must take advantage of everything within our reach to find a peaceful solution to this problem,'' Gorbachev said. His special envoy, Yevgeny Primakov, has met with Western and Arab leaders on such a diplomatic mission. Primakov is to meet with Saddam on Sunday. The Soviet Union and the United States, in their first major cooperation on a regional conflict, are leading the anti-Iraq coalition that has produced U.N. Security Council resolutions slapping an economic embargo on Baghdad and permitting countries to use their warships to enforce it. On Saturday, Gorbachev said Saddam may be trying to break up that coalition. If so, the Soviet leader said, Saddam is suffering from ``deep delusion.'' In Spain, Gorbachev is also seeking aid for the ailing Soviet economy as it switches from a centrally planned system to a market system. Gorbachev and Gonzalez signed an agreement under which Spain will extend $1.5 billion worth of loans to the Soviets for purchase of Spanish food and consumer goods, as well as equipment for the Soviet food, textile, shoe and clothing industries. ``We need these credits and financial resources to make ... the transition to a market less painful for the people,'' Gorbachev told reporters. He said countres that help the Soviet Union get through the transition will be rewarded in the future.

DOC.HEAD: Tracks, Highways Blocked By Foes Of High-Speed Rail Line
DOC.TEXT: About 1,000 demonstrators opposed to a planned high-speed rail project blocked train tracks and two highways Saturday, provoking fistfights with drivers and delaying 30 trains. It was the latest in a series of disruptive protests by residents of the Provence region opposed to the extension of the national high-speed rail network from Lyon to the Mediterranean. Train service on the main north-south line through Avignon was interrupted for nearly three hours, officials of the national railroad said. They said 30 trains, carrying roughly 12,000 people at the start of a major holiday week, were affected. Some of the protesters moved from the tracks to block two nearby highways for about an hour, officials said. Detours were arranged to alleviate traffic jams, but a three-mile backup was reported on one of the roads. Leaders of the protest movement say the proposed high-speed route will harm the environment and was selected before local communities were consulted.

DOC.HEAD: Kasparov Resigns Seventh Game, Tied With Karpov
DOC.TEXT: Defending champion Garry Kasparov conceded the seventh game of the world chess championship Saturday to challenger Anatoly Karpov, leaving the pair deadlocked in their $3 million showdown. Kasparov - acknowledged by chess experts to be at a disadvantage in the game at the point it broke off for the night Friday - opted to resign rather than resume play, said Phyllis Arnold, spokeswoman for the championship. The championship is now tied at 3{-3{. A player gets one point for a victory, and each player gets a half point for a tie. Each player has now won once, with the other five games ending in draws. The first player to reach 12{ points wins the championship. Kasparov, who dethroned Karpov in 1985, would retain his title if the match ended in a 12-12 tie. The first 12 games are being played in New York and the remainder will be played in Lyons, France. The winner will get $1.7 million and the loser will get $1.3 million. The seventh game was adjourned Friday night when Karpov wrote down his 44th move and sealed it in an envelope. If Kasparov had not conceded defeat, play would have resumed Saturday evening. Karpov appeared to have a significant advantage over Kasparov when the game adjourned because he had an extra pawn and was thought to be in a superior position on the board.

DOC.HEAD: Andrews Air Force Base Searches For Missing Stick Of Dynamite
DOC.TEXT: Security police at Andrews Air Force Base on Saturday were still looking for a stick of dynamite unknowingly driven off into the Maryland countryside during an anti-explosives training exercise. The dynamite, missing since Thursday evening, could easily be mistaken for a road flare and ``is considered extremely dangerous,'' said Sgt. Janice Firth, a spokeswoman at the home base for the president's Air Force One jet. She said live dynamite had been planted randomly in vehicles near a training site in an exercise for explosives-detecting dogs Thursday. However, the canine corps was beaten to the stick by a former member of the military, who, unaware the exercise was going on, drove off with two sticks of dynamite hidden under the wheel well of his Datsun pickup truck. The man, who was not identified, drove his truck throughout Prince George's County in suburban Maryland before police finally tracked him down Friday morning, Firth said. One stick that apparently fell off as the man was driving away was found near the base gate, but the other is still missing, she said. She said the 8-inch by }-inch cylinder contains {-pound of explosives and ``could be detonated by a sudden jolt, jar or drop.'' Firth said the stick has an orange wrapping labelled ``ditching dynamite.'' The spokeswoman said the training area was closely supervised and the question of how the man had been able to enter the area and drive off with a dynamite-loaded vehicle were ``being addressed.''

DOC.HEAD: Encephalitis, Satanism Worries Make Halloween Full of Tricks This Year
DOC.TEXT: As millions of children prepare their witches' cloaks and Bart Simpson masks, the traditions of Halloween are under attack this year by mosquitoes in Florida, ``prayer warriors'' in San Francisco and Detroit officials weary of their city's annual arson spree. Some educators also are taking another look at Halloween activities in the classroom, with a few Maryland schools urging parents to steer their children toward playful costumes - not gruesome ones. Attacks aside, millions of youngsters - and plenty of adults, too - will still become vampires, witches or Bart the cartoon star for a night of trick-or-treating and partying Wednesday. They'll be carrying on Halloweeen customs brought to the United States by Irish immigrants in the 1800s. In Florida, however, the customs are being moved to broad daylight this year. Because of an outbreak of St. Louis encephalitis, a disease spread by mosquitos that like to bite at dusk, health officials have urged communities to hold Halloween activities in the afternoon to reduce the risk of exposure. The city of St. Petersburg moved its evening Community Halloween Festival to Sunday afternoon, as well as a traditional haunted house, said Joel Garren, recreation division director. At Parrot Jungle in suburban Miami, 700 children and Big Brother-Big Sister escorts turned out for a Halloween party Saturday afternoon. ``The birds are very interested in it,'' said Pat Callan, general manager of the tourist attraction. ``They usually go higher on the perch because they're not sure what it is, but I think they're catching on to Halloween.'' In Kenneth City, a Gulf Coast city near Tampa, Mayor Alfred Wells canceled the city's annual Firemen's Halloween Party, usually attended by 600 children. ``I don't think it will be fair to bring any kids out at all,'' he said. But Broward County officials in southern Florida decided to go ahead with their plans, including nighttime haunted trails through parks, said Bob Harbin, assistant director of parks and recreation. There'll be mosquito repellent handy for those who need it. A Dallas televangelist is enlisting ``prayer warriors'' for a Halloween attack on what he calls the satanic forces of witchcraft, drugs and perversion in San Francisco. ``We need to reverse the curse on Halloween night,'' Larry Lea said when he announced his campaign. His daily ``Change Your Life'' television show is seen on 40 independent stations. ``This is not just kids having fun. There is actual worship of the devil.'' In medieval times, the souls of the dead were thought to return to their homes on the eve of All Saints' Day - or Halloween. Organizers of San Francico's bawdy Exotic Erotic Halloween Ball invited Lea to attend the event set for Sunday night. The ball draws hundreds of revelers who attend in various stages of dress and undress. ``We're offended by Lea's impugning San Francisco and the Bay area with all these accusations of evil,'' said Perry Mann, a producer of the ball. Several educators in Maryland have sought to dissuade youngsters from wearing anything devilish or gruesome to school. ``We try to encourage the kids to wear fun things instead of things that can be frightful and detrimental,'' Beverly L. Norwood, principal of Dundalk Elementary School in suburban Baltimore told The (Baltimore) Sun. But 10-year-old Erica Schwartz is dressing up as a vampire and doesn't think anyone should be worried about that. ``Halloween is about scary stuff,'' said Erica, a fifth-grader at Mount Washington Elementary School in Baltimore. ``It's not real.'' Children in Newtown, Conn., were dispirited after a mock seance to contact the ghost of Newtown's greatest benefactor was canceled after a protest by residents and clergy. Sylvia Vuillemenot, the children's librarian at the Cyrenius H. Booth Library, planned to dress up as Mary Hawley and materialize in front of middle-school students Friday night. ``It was supposed to be a history lesson,'' said librarian Janet Woycik. ``There's nothing in town for the middle-school kids to do.'' A few cities are trying to fight reputations for rowdy or fiery Halloween celebrations. Detroit is shifting the focus of its campaign against arson sprees that hit the city on the night before Halloween. ``No more Devil's Night,'' was the slogan of last year's effort; this year the campaign is dubbed ``My Heart is with Detroit.'' ``We're attempting to come up with a more positive image for the city,'' said Mayor Coleman Young. ``It's obvious that Devil's Night has a bad connotation.'' Devil's Night violence first erupted in Detroit in the late 1970s when residents began burning trash bins, abandoned houses and garages. The fires peaked in 1984, with 810 reported during a three-day period. Last year, city officials reported 223 fires but the Detroit Fire Fighters Association counted almost twice as many.

DOC.HEAD: Louisiana Billboards Proclaim It `The Basic Language - Latin!'
DOC.TEXT: It's not your typical topic for a roadside sign: The arrival of about 200 ancient language teachers is being heralded by billboards advertising their favorite subject. ``Want Help in English? Want Better SAT Scores? Want a Larger Vocabulary? The Basic Language - Take Latin!'' the billboards say. Lamar Outdoor Advertising donated the signs for a conference of the Classical Association of the Middle West and South at Louisiana State University, to be held Thursday through Saturday. Some 200 high school and teachers of Latin and Greek, hailing from 30 states and Canada, are expected to attend. Planned activities include presentations on Greek and Latin literature and history, and discussions of problems and methods of teaching the classics.

DOC.HEAD: Man Ordered to Pay Younger Brother $1.2 Million For Libel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Second references, Mas and Mas Canosa, are cq
DOC.TEXT: A jury ordered a millionaire to pay his estranged younger brother $1.2 million for describing him to a prospective client as an extortionist who wasn't above fraud. The Dade County Circuit Court jury ruled Friday that Jorge Mas Canosa maliciously libeled his brother, Ricardo Mas. Mas Canosa is head of the Cuban American National Foundation, a lobby group. The jury reached its decision after deliberating almost three hours. It based its decision on two letters Mas Canosa, 51, wrote to Southern Bell, the younger man's prospective client. He reportedly wrote the letters because he was angry that his brother quit a job with his construction business to establish a competing company. ``I feel fantastic,'' Mas said. ``I wasn't expecting that amount but I think it's a great decision.'' Mas, 40, said he spent $100,000 in legal fees pursuing the 3-year-old lawsuit against his brother. The jury decided Mas Canosa, who had a net worth of $9.1 million as of August 1989, should pay his brother's company $300,000 in compensation and $900,000 in punitive damages. Jury foreman Kenneth Santerre told reporters the jury felt Mas Canosa had no right to use his position as his brother's former employer to try to hurt the younger man. ``It tore my family apart,'' Mas said. ``Now I feel I've been exonerated.'' Neither Mas Canosa nor his attorneys would speak to reporters after the decision. Mas had accused his brother of libel and of depriving him of contracting work at Southern Bell. Mas had worked for his brother's company, Church and Tower, a principal construction contractor fr the phone company, until they quarreled five years ago. Judge George Orr threw out the allegation of deprivation of work since Southern Bell executives had hired Ricardo Mas even after they received the letters.

DOC.HEAD: Kids of Woman Hit By Train Claim Wrongful Death; County Unveils Safety Plan
DOC.TEXT: The 11 children of a woman killed by a streetcar filed wrongful death claims against transit officials, who announced a beefed-up saftey campaign for the newly opened rail line. Rosa Ceballos, 56, died when she was hit by a Blue Line train last month as she crossed the tracks on her way to church. Donald H. Cohen, an attorney representing Ceballos' children, said Friday they had filed claims for $2 million each against the Los Angeles County Transportation Commission, the Southern California Rapid Transit District and the state. Cohen said the plaintiffs, who range in age from 21 to 43, want to raise public awareness about the danger the trains pose. Two people were killed and four others were injured in accidents between Blue Line trains and cars last week. The 22-mile rail line that stretches between downtown Los Angeles and Long Beach opened this summer. The transportation commission announced new safety measures Friday. The measures include volunteer crossing guards, ``cyclops'' lights on trains to illuminate the tracks, and a review of existing crossing gates and warning systems along the ``This is not to say that we've done anything unsafe, this is to see what we can do as the designer to improve our safety measures,'' said commission vice president Norman Jester. ``We have more bells and whistles than anyone. The problem has been public education. We've got people driving around down crossing gates, thinking they can beat the train through an intersection,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush and Quayle Dreaming of a 50-50 Senate
With AM-Campaign '90, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 15th graf `Bush was' to include results of latest poll on Bush approval rating. Picks up 16th graf prvs, `In 1992,...' Also sent in advance Oct. 25 as b0781.
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Just a handful of votes, President Bush said almost wistfully, and Republicans could control the Senate. But it would take a full hand, five seats, to wrest it from the Democrats. And that target is almost certainly beyond GOP reach in off-year elections that Republicans hoped would be at minimum a stepping stone for 1992. That is the more likely year for a congressional shakeup, despite this election season's voter wrath at a stumbling government and worsening economy. The performance has hurt Bush's standing, but he's still not as unpopular as Congress in the public opinion polls. For a 1992 game plan to hold up, the Republicans need to add at least a seat or two to their 45 in the Senate this year - and there's at least as good a chance that they will lose seats instead. At this point, strategists in both parties expect little net change in the party lineups in Congress. A political aide to Bush hedges the bet y saying that the White House hopes to defy history and beat the pattern in which a president's party loses House and Senate seats in off-year congressional elections. Counting that way, the administration can claim to have won while losing. Limited losses in the House won't make a lot of difference, given the lopsided majority the Democrats hold there. Both sides anticipate Democratic gains in the House, probably in the range of a half-dozen seats. The White House party has not gained House seats in any off-year elections since the Democrats did it in 1934. But in the Senate, an off-year GOP loss in line with the historic pattern of three seats would cripple Republican chances of converting their minority into a majority and thus gaining a piece of the action at the Capitol during the Bush presidency. The lineup is now 55 Democrats, 45 Republicans, five seats short of the tie that would enable Vice President Dan Quayle to vote the GOP into control. Despite the improbability of it, Quayle said ``maybe we'll be lucky enough to pick up five seats and then it would be a 50-50 tie.'' ``It would be my sheer delight to preside over a divided Senate and to cast tie-breaking vote after tie-breaking vote for the programs of President George Bush,'' he added during a campaign stop Thursday in Runnemeade, N.J. Bush brought the subject up later Thursday surrounded by the Congressional Republican leadership in the Rose Garden. ``If we had more Republicans like everyone who is standing here, we wouldn't be in this fiscal mess.'' Republicans held Senate majorities for six of Ronald Reagan's eight years in the White House, gaining control with a surprise, dozen-seat gain when he was elected in 1980, losing it in 1986, when Democrats picked up eight seats in off-year balloting. This time, position is a more realistic Republican goal than control. The Nov. 6 competition is for 18 Senate seats now held by Republicans, 16 held by Democrats. GOP strategists said they were out to establish a foundation for gains into the 1990s. Eight GOP House members left safe seats to bid for the Senate, five of them against incumbent Democrats, the other three seeking to succeed retiring Republicans. Bush was riding record-high voter approval ratings; while he had no coattails in winning the White House, his popularity looked like a major off-year asset. But according to the latest Gallup-Newsweek poll, Bush's approval rate has slipped from 80 percent last January to 48 percent, the lowest rating of his presidency. Nearly two-thirds of those polled thought he was losing political influence. And Democrats who had seemed vulnerable early in the year turned out to be tough at the end. In 1992, the Democrats will have 20 Senate seats to defend, Republicans 14. Eleven of the Democrats are freshman senators, and will be up for re-election for the first time. There are likely to be retirements among senior Democrats, some with problems like Sen. Alan Cranston's savings and loan involvement. But those promising circumstances won't make much difference unless Republicans gain where history says they'll slip. Even then, the 1992 strategy assumes a strong Bush ticket, with coattails that were lacking in the 1988 elections. While he was winning the White House, the Democrats were gaining a seat in the Senate. They haven't sustained a net loss there in any election since 1980. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 25 years.

DOC.HEAD: 4-Year-Old Mauled By Dog
DOC.TEXT: A pit bull mauled a 4-year-old boy after the child's parents agreed to keep the dog at their rural home for a man who hadn't bought the insurance required to keep it in the village. Joseph Lee Haddock was released from a hospital Friday after surgery for facial lacerations, a spokeswoman said. The pit bull had been chained to a post when it attacked the boy Thursday. Officials in this southern Illinois village of about 550 passed an ordinance in September requiring owners of pit bulls to keep the dogs caged or muzzled and to carry a $50,000 liability insurance policy. The dog's owner, David McHarry, moved the dog to the home of his friends, the Haddocks, to avoid violating the ordinance, Village Clerk Ken Ledbetter said. McHarry said he was uncertain whether he could afford the insurance or could cage the dog as securely as the ordinance required. McHarry, upset over the attack, said he had planned to give the dog away. He said it would be put to sleep. ``I'm sorry it happened,'' he said. ``It tears me up.''

DOC.HEAD: Shooting Mars Election Campaign in Georgian Republic
LaserPhotos TBL1,2
DOC.TEXT: The shooting of an opposition politician on the eve of the first multiparty elections in Soviet Georgia has created an atmosphere of fear and acrimony in this republic. Gia Chanturia, leader of the National Democratic Party, said he was shot Friday afternoon as he left a meeting of politicians who are boycotting Sunday's elections. ``I was saved by a miracle,'' said Chanturia, showing a reporter and photographer his left arm, wrapped in a blood-soaked bandage. Chanturia accused the powerful leader of the Round Table non-Communist opposition, Zviad Gamsakhurdia, of ordering the shooting on instructions from Communist Party bosses. ``I don't know exactly who shot me, but I know who could have done it,'' he said, referring to Gamsakhurdia. He said he believed he was shot ``because someone wants to start a civil war,'' but did not elaborate. Gamsakhurdia denied he was responsible for the shooting. ``This is a provocation, an attempt to sabotage the election,'' he said Saturday. ``It`s done by those parties and forces who don't want these elections to be held.'' His coalition and the Communist Party are leading contenders to win a plurality in Sunday's election for the 250-seat Georgian Supreme Soviet legislature. The plethora of parties makes it unlikely a single group will win a majority. Chanturia is among Georgian opposition leaders who are boycotting the vote. They were elected to the National Congress earlier this month intending to form a shadow government to pressure faster change in the republic. All parties participating in Sunday's election, including the Communist Party, say Georgia should leave the Soviet Union. The political debate is over the duration of the ``transition'' period o national independence, and the degree of economic and political cooperation the republic should maintain with the Soviet Union. Georgia's desire for independence became almost a foregone conclusion after April 9, 1989, when Soviet soldiers killed 19 people in a pre-dawn attack on a pro-independence demonstration in downtown Tbilisi. On Saturday, candidates stood atop a bus using bullhorns to address crowds on Independence Square - formerly named Lenin Square. Even the Communist Party has tailored its rhetoric for the pro-independence mood. ``The position of the Communist Party of Georgia is that all the republics should be free,'' said Vazha Gurgenedze, the Communist Party's secretary for ideology. Gurgenedze, himself a candidate, said that even a Communist-dominated legislature would declare independence, allow the free sale of private land and conclude economic agreements with the other 14 Soviet republics. Gurgenedze acknowledges his platform might be more radical than that of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who wants all 15 republics to sign a new treaty of union and remain in the Soviet fold. ``We think the Communist Party will receive a mandate, 40 to 60 percent of the vote. I can't really predict,'' he said. Gamsakhurdia predicted that his Round Table coalition would get up to 70 percent of the vote if the elections were fair. He dismissed a poll released last week showing the Communist Party winning 32 percent of the vote, Round Table 21.5 and the rest of ballots divided among other smaller parties. ``I know the man who prepared this poll, and he is a KGB agent,'' Gamsakhurdia said Saturday. ``The Communists are preparing a falsification.'' ``We are receiving signals that they are violating the election law, they are calling people and frightening them into voting Communist, and the Communists are preparing too many ballots,'' he said, raising the possibility that some will be improperly completed. Gamsakhurdia was cheered at an evening rally when he accused Communist Party authorities of failing to tell Georgia's 3 million eligible voters where polls would be located Sunday. Gurgenedze, the Communist Party secretary, said the elections would be fair. ``It's new for us. In previous elections, everything was decided beforehand,'' he said. An American professor specializing in Georgian politics, Victor Peppard of the University of South Florida and Tampa, said the vote marked a milestone in Soviet politics because for the first time, there is an independent election commission. ``Also, for the first time, there are independent parties,'' he said. The formation of new political organizations became possible this year after the Communist Party agreed to give up its constitutionally guaranteed monopoly. ``Here the opposition already has power, largely based on Gamsakhurdia and his ability to call strikes, rally thousands of people in the streets and shut down rail lines,'' Peppard said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Takes Morning Dip In Pacific
DOC.TEXT: Tourists out strolling on balmy Waikiki Beach just after dawn Saturday morning were surprised to see that among the swimmers was President Bush. Bush, accompanied by security agents, went for a dip in the waters behind the Hilton Hawaiian Village resort hotel, where his entourage was staying for a two-day political and diplomatic visit to Honolulu. CNN cameraman Dan O'Shea, with the travelling press corps, said he was out for a swim himself when someone floated by. ``I looked over and it was him,'' said O'Shea, who promptly leaped out of the water and ran to get his camera. Along with UPI photographer Joe Marquette, he waded back in, and Bush did not dissuade them from moving in close to record his swim just off the shore. Several dozen tourists, along with press photographers and reporters, gathered on the beach by the time Bush emerged in a dripping T-shirt and baggy shorts. Bush's Secret Service agents, some caught by surprise by his sudden Pacific plunge, sweated in their suits and ties as they urged onlookers to move back up the beach to the coconut trees. Bush appeared in good spirits after news from Washington that a budget agreement had finally passed the House. ``I'm very pleased it passed the House,'' Bush said. When asked if he was glad the long, laborious budget talks were over, he said, ``That's for sure.'' As he crossed the beach, with the throng of onlookers in tow, Bush told them the water was fine.

DOC.HEAD: Kremlin Troops Ordered To Moldavia
LaserPhoto BUC1
DOC.TEXT: The Kremlin ordered troops to Moldavia Saturday to try to prevent ethnic violence between Moldavian youths and a Turkish Christian minority demanding independence, Tass reported. Negotiations continued Saturday with the republic's Gagauz minority, but no progress was reported, the official news agency said. A day earlier, the republic declared a state of emergency in part of southern Moldavia. The situation is ``highly tense and fraught with unpredictable consequences,'' the national government said in a statement reported by Tass. It said it was sending troops in to ``increase security'' in the republic. The Kremlin also said the troops were going in at the request of the Moldavian government and representatives of the Gagauz people. It did not say how many troops were sent. The Gagauz, descendants of 19th century Turkish immigrants, have declared sovereignty from Moldavia - which is itself trying to break free of the Soviet Union. The unrest was the latest to flare in the Soviet Union's ethnic and nationalist conflicts. It could further complicate President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's effort to hold the country together with a new union treaty and win the republics' support for his plan to create a market economy. Tass said volunteer brigades of Moldavians, some armed with sticks and metal rods, were defying the state of emergency and jamming roads leading to the southern Moldavian districts of Komrat and Chadyr-Lunga. Similar groups also were reported on the streets of the capital, which also sent police to the disputed areas. Earlier reports said some weapons and explosives had been confiscated from Gagauz separatists. No violence was reported. Tass said phone lines to the region were cut. A Tass correspondent in the Moldavian capital of Kishinev, Alexander Tanas, said by telephone Saturday evening that a band of ethnic Russians from Kishinev also had set out for the area. They were hoping to help defend the Gagauz against Moldavians, but were stopped by authorities and ``persuaded'' to turn back, he said. The Communist Party newspaper Pravda said Friday that the republic was ``on the brink of civil war.'' Moldavian officials said earlier that the state of emergency would be enforced by Interior Ministry troops under their control. The Kremlin's order Saturday for additional troops indicated more help was needed. The Moldavian legislature imposed the two-month state of emergency Friday after buses carrying thousands of Moldavians set out to try to block voting by the Gagauz for a new, autonomous government. Gagauz officials said later Friday they were prepared to postpone the election in order to avert conflicts. It was not clear whether they were held. The state of emergency restricts movement in and out of the area and bans rallies. The Moldavian parliament also voted to abolish local government bodies in the region and replace them with committees appointed by the republic. About 150,000 Gagauz live in the southern corner of Moldavia, a largely agricultural republic between the Ukraine and Romania. They make up about 3 percent of the republic's 4.3 million people and claim 11 percent of its territory. The Gagauz speak a Turkic language and traditionally work as shepherds and farmers. They have complained of discrimination by the Moldavian majority, objecting in particular to a law making Moldavian the republic's official language. In neighboring Romania, meanwhile, hundreds of people demonstrated in Bucharest Saturday for reunification with Moldavia, which was annexed by the Soviets during World War II. Flag-waving demonstrators, including some opposition party leaders, marched up the capital's main boulevard shouting nationalistic slogans. They carried banners and wore badges that read ``Bessarabia and Romania - one beating heart.'' Moldavia is known to the Romanians as Bessarabia. Moldavia is the latest of several Soviet republics to face separatist movements and ethnic conflicts, which threaten to splinter the country and derail Gorbachev's reforms. Ethnic violence previously has broken out in Armenia, Georgia, Azerbaijan and Uzbekistan. Interior Ministry troops also were sent to those areas after the violence. All but one of the 15 Soviet republics have declared some form of autonomy from Moscow. The only holdout is Kirgizia, a Central Asian republic, and its legislature is expected to declare sovereignty soon.

DOC.HEAD: Policeman Shoots Two People When Neo-Nazis, Leftists Clash
DOC.TEXT: Leftist demonstrators Saturday clashed with neo-Nazis shouting ``Heil Hitler!'' a news agency said. One of the policemen called to the scene reportedly wounded two rioters. A policemen was also injured by rioters hurling stones, and three teen-agers were arrested, the Germany news agency ADN said. It said the officer who wounded the rioters fired in self-defense when confronted by attackers carrying iron bars, sticks and signal flares. It did not say if the two people wounded were neo-Nazi marchers or their opponents. The clashes began after nearly 150 neo-Nazi youths left a discotheque in Leipzig, about 100 miles southwest of Berlin, and marched through the city shouting Nazi salutes and slogans hostile to foreigners, ADN said. The group was confronted by anti-Nazi youths. Police separated the two groups, but one patrol car came under attack by a group of between 30 to 50 youths, ADN said. One policeman ``was forced to make use of his firearm,'' it said. Groups of neo-Nazis have made a growing number of appearances in what used to be East Germany. Last weekend, about 350 neo-Nazis marched through Dresden, about 120 miles south of Berlin, shouting slogans against foreigners.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf of Los Angeles-dated item on Goldberg to DELETE incorrect reference to Goldberg starring in ``Bagdad Cafe'' movie.
DOC.TEXT: Actress and comedian Whoopi Goldberg was named winner of the Excellence Award of the sixth annual Women in Film Festival. The award honors her life work and adds her name to a list that includes Sally Field, Julie Andrews and Kathleen Turner. Goldberg, known for the current hit film ``Ghost'' as well as ``The Color Purple,'' was to receive the award during a tribute Saturday night at the Directors Guild of America. Goldberg, 41, also is starring as the hotheaded, softhearted owner of television's ``Bagdad Cafe.''

DOC.HEAD: Klan Loses Appeal on Permit To March Along Constitution Avenue
By LeROY TILLMAN
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: The District of Columbia will not have to allow the Christian Knights of the Ku Klux Klan to march along a major Washington thoroughfare during a rally here Sunday, a federal appeals court ruled Saturday. A three-judge panel of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia vacated an order by a lower court judge that would have allowed the Klan to march along Constitution Avenue from the Washington Monument grounds to the U.S. Capitol, said Mark Langer, an aide to the court's clerk. Police had said the Klan could march along only four blocks of the avenue. U.S. District Judge Louis F. Oberdorfer earlier this week had ruled in favor of a suit brought by the American Civil Liberties Union, which claimed the Klan's constitutional rights were being violated by the police limits. D.C. officials refused to issue the Klan a permit to march along Constitution Avenue, saying they could not adequately insure the safety of the marchers over such a long route. Police urged the organization to instead travel from the monument grounds to the Capitol mostly along the grassy Mall. ACLU legal director Arthur Spitzer said he would not comment on the appeals court order. He said no decision had been made on whether to appeal to the Supreme Court. The last time the Klan attempted to march in Washington was on the Labor Day weekend when they were met by several hundred counterprotestors who massed along the parade route. District Police had to escort 44 Klan members to the Capitol grounds where they held their rally. The counterdemonstrators, All Peoples Congress, had vowed to try to stop Sunday's march as well. Permits filed by the Klan with the National Park Service and the U.S. Capitol Police indicated that between 50 to 300 of its members were expected to participate in Sunday's events. Officials of the Smithsonian museums said they would remain open regular hours on Sunday, but the National Gallery of Art on the east end of The Mall near the Capitol will be closed. D.C. Administrator Carol B. Thompson issued an appeal on Saturday for the public to stay away from the Klan activities to allow police and other authorities ``to do their jobs effectively.''

DOC.HEAD: Palestinians To Be Allowed Back into Israel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 17 grafs to UPDATE with further quotes from Arens, more jobs for Jews, criticism of plan; picks up 11th graf pvs, `The current ...
DOC.TEXT: Israeli authorities announced they are lifting their ban Sunday on entry by Palestinians from the occupied lands, but they said there will be new security restrictions. More than 1.7 million Palestinians in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip have been confined to the territories since Wednesday, following a wave of Arab-Jewish street violence that left five people dead and 11 injured. ``As of tommorrow, the Arab inhabitants of Judea, Samaria (the West Bank) and the Gaza district will be permitted to re-enter the state of Israel,'' the Defense Ministry said in a statement Saturday. But it said, ``the right to enter Israel will be denied from those taking part in hostile activities.'' It did not elaborate. Defense Minister Moshe Arens said Arabs might be locked out of Israel again if violence persists. ``This is one of the means designed to bring about the cooling of the tempers, an understanding among the Palestinian population that repeated slayings will only worsen the Palestinian tragedy,'' he said. The previous restrictions prevented up to 150,000 Palestinian laborers from going to their jobs in Israel, where they form much of the blue-collar work force. It was not immediately clear how many would be affected by the new restrictions. At present, several thousand Palestinians have been banned from traveling to Israel for security or criminal offenses. They carry special orange identity cards. Arens has also ordered the strengthening of supervision over those going to work in Israel and new measures to ``prevent any illegal stay in Israel,'' the ministry said. Thousands of Palestinian laborers employed in Israel have no work permits. The majority of Palestinian workers, even those who have the licenses, are required to return home for the night, unless they have another permit allowing them to stay. But hundreds of them, notably in the Tel Aviv area, violate the regulations to spend the night near their workplaces, staying at rented apartments or in dormitories. Israel's army chief of staff, Lt. Gen. Dan Shomron, said Saturday the authorities ``will ask the employers, in a much more serious manner, not to employ unlicensed workers, in order to safeguard themselves and others. They, too, are responsible for preventing terror attacks.'' The absence of Palestinian workers since Wednesday has led to an increase in work offers for Jews. Employment Service officials reported 10,000 openings last week, six times more than normal. Arens' decision to lift the closure was immediately criticized by some Israeli hard-liners, including members of his own Likud bloc. ``This is a very high risk. I don't think it's right for a total Israeli population to expose itself every day to more than 5,000 terrorists, murderers, who come under the perfectly legitimate cover of employment,'' said Menachem Milson, the former military governor of the occupied territories. Arens said no one could guarantee Israeli safety. ``It's not a new problem ... and to speak realistically, we will face this problem in the future,'' he said on Israel Television. The current upsurge in the 34-month Palestinian uprising broke out after the Oct. 8 shootings on the Temple Mount in Jerusalem, when Israeli police killed 20 Palestinian rioters and wounded 140 others. An Israeli board of inquiry last week found that the police fired in self-defense, but criticized commanders for failing to anticipate the violence and accused police of firing indiscriminately at one point. Israel expects an increase in cross-border guerrilla raids in the wake of the Temple Mount shootings, Shomron said on Israel radio. ``It is known that following the Temple Mount (events), there is a greater motivation to act against Israel, to attack it from the borders and not only within the territories or the green line,'' Shomron said, referring to Israel's pre-1967 borders. ``We have no doubt that we can expect repeated (attack) attempts.'' Israel captured the West Bank from Jordan and the Gaza Strip from Egypt in the 1967 Middle East war. These lands are the scene of the Palestinian revolt, in which at least 766 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians. During the uprising, 289 Arabs have been slain by fellow Palestinins as alleged pro-Israeli collaborators. Fifty-one Israelis also have died.

DOC.HEAD: Bushnell Nominated as New Ambassador to Costa Rica
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Saturday nominated foreign service veteran John A. Bushnell as ambassador to Costa Rica, succeeding Deane Hinton. Bushnell has been deputy chief of mission to Panama since 1989. Prior to that he worked in various State Department jobs, and at foreign posts in Colombia, Switzerland and Argentina. The White House announced the nomination as Bush attended a one-day summit with leaders of several small Pacific nations. The nomination requires Senate confirmation. Costa Rica, the longest-standing democracy in Central America, has been a steadfast and close ally of the United States and a leader in promoting peace efforts on regional conflicts involving its neighbors.

DOC.HEAD: Fish From Tokyo Released Into Seine
DOC.TEXT: A hundred multicolored fish from Tokyo were released into the Seine river Saturday to mark the first anniversary of a friendship pact between the Japanese capital and Paris. The fish, flown to France from Tokyo's Sumida river, were released in a ceremony presided over by Paris Mayor Jacques Chirac and his counterpart from Toyyo, Shunichi Suzuki. A year ago, the two cities agreed to exchange scientific and technological expertise in a campaign to clean up the two rivers. After watching the yellow, orange, white and black carp swim away, Chirac and Suzuki visited a traditional, wooden Japanese boat donated by Tokyo to Paris. It is to serve as an informal cultural center for visitors wishing to learn about Japan.

DOC.HEAD: Victims Of IRA Attacks Mourned
DOC.TEXT: A Roman Catholic bishop denounced the IRA as followers of Satan during a eulogy Saturday at the funeral of a man forced to drive a bomb into a military checkpoint. ``They may say they are followers of Christ, some of them may even still engage in the hypocrisy of coming to church, but their lives and their works proclaim clearly that they follow Satan,'' said Bishop Edward Daly. Daly spoke at the funeral of Patsy Gillespie, 42, who was forced to drive a van loaded with explosives into a military checkpoint outside Londonderry. The explosion Wednesday morning killed Gillespie and five British soldiers. Gillespie was a civilian kitchen assistant in the army's Fort George camp in Londonderry. In its claim of responsibility for the attack, the Irish Republican Army branded him a collaborator. The predominantly Roman Catholic IRA is seeking to drive the British out of northern Ireland and unite it with the mainly Catholic Republic of Ireland. Gillespie's wife, Kathleen, said the family's home had been taken over by armed men Tuesday night and her husband taken away while the rest of the family was held hostage. The IRA used similar tactics in setting off a bomb the same morning at a checkpoint in Newry. One soldier was killed. A third attack in Omagh failed and the driver escaped injury. At the funeral Saturday of the soldier killed in Newry, the Rev. Anthony Doran said 21-year-old Cyril Smith died because he had helped the driver and then ran back to warn his comrades. Smith ``gave his life by running back into danger for his friends,'' the Catholic priest said. Londonderry was a flash point of the ``troubles'' that erupted in Northern Ireland in the late 1960s, leading to a revival of the IRA as the self-proclaimed defenders of the Catholic minority. The city remains one of the IRA's strongholds. Daly, for years a stern critic of the IRA, said the outlawed organization had ``descended a step lower to use people's lives to launch their vile attacks.'' ``Everyone is now at risk from these evil people with their foul and obscene actions. They corrupt everything and every person they touch,'' Daly said. ``We weep for the Gillespie family this morning. We weep for the families of the soldiers who died and we weep for our own city, a city we all love deeply. ``We weep because we have among our citizens men who are capable of planning and carrying out and even attempting to justify such evil.'' Gillespie died on his oldest son's birthay. His wife and three children -Patrick, 18, Kieran, 16, and Jennifer, 12 - wept at the graveside. Among the 60 wreaths was one from the Kings Regiment, which lost five soldiers in the attack. The death toll in Northern Ireland rose to 63 with the killing Friday night of Tommy Casey, a member of the IRA's legal political wing, Sinn Fein. Protestant guerrillas were suspected in the killing.

DOC.HEAD: A Bad Week in Angry, Fearful Israel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with border to be reopened; picks up 11th graf pvs, `The latest ...
DOC.TEXT: Israel has had an ugly week. Street violence between Arabs and Jews left five dead and 11 injured. The government closed the pre-1967 borders in an attempt to separate the Jews of Israel from the Arabs of the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. For most Israelis, these are strange and unsettling times: Arabs knifing Jews in public, Jews beating one of the assailants to death, police rounding up Arabs and sending them home. More than 110,000 Arabs were cut off from their jobs in Israel by the sealing of the ``green line,'' as Israelis call the borders that existed before the 1967 Middle East war. The border was to reopen Sunday, although the Defense Ministry said additional measures would be taken to make sure Palestinians planning violence did not get through. It said the border might be closed again if violence persisted. The decision to seal the ``green line'' was not a simple one for Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's government. The green line vanished long ago from Israeli maps and road signs. According to Shamir's nationalist doctrine of Greater Israel, it no longer exists. The roadblocks and long lines of sullen, protesting Arabs say otherwise. ``The green line is firm and abiding,'' wrote Zeev Schiff, respected military commentator for the newspaper Haaretz. ``It is as if a wall has gone up,'' said Nidal Abu Yehyah, a fifth-generation Palestinian grocer in Jerusalem. Israeli authorities said the closure was a security measure of no political significance. The closure's effect were felt immediately. Arabs lost wages and Israel lost its blue-collar work force. Restaurants were short of waiters, construction sites were idle, streets went unswept. The latest cycle of violence began Oct. 8, when Israeli police fired into a stone-throwing Palestinian crowd on the Temple Mount, known to Arabs as Haram es-Sharif. Government investigators said 20 Palestinians were killed. It provoked a spate of Arab attacks, beginning with a Palestinian who stabbed three Israelis to death in a rampage through a Jewish neighborhood of Jerusalem last Sunday. According to police, the attacker said he was taking revenge for the Temple Mount killings. More attacks followed: two unarmed women soldiers knifed at a crossroad in northern Israel; two Israelis hit on the head with an 11-pound hammer by their Arab employee in a workshop. The soldiers' attacker died of brain injuries inflicted by civilians who caught him. That night, shots fired at a car near the Gaza Strip killed an Arab occupant. Tel Aviv police reported 1,700 calls from Jews informing on Arabs who disregarded orders to leave Israel. The owner of a large office block in Jerusalem said Jewish tenants want him to fire his Arab cleaners and car park attendants. At the United Nations, the Security Council voted a second condemnation of Israel over the Temple Mount killings, this time for refusing to let it investigate. Israel's own commission of inquiry largely supported the government version of events. It said police were being stoned by rioters and fired to defend theselves and the Jews worshiping at the adjacent Western Wall. Arabs dismissed the report as a whitewash. The knife attacks, incited by Moslem fundamentalist leaflets urging the killing of Jews, have spread fear that the 34-month old Palestinian uprising has entered an ominous new phase. Yossi Sarid, a dovish member of Parliament, accused Shamir of paralyzing the peace process, and said: ``If there is no movement . . . the blood that is spilled will be on his head.'' Speaking on Israel television, Sarid added a warning to Palestinians: ``What is happening now, knifemanship instead of statesmanship, is cutting the ground from under their feet. ``Soon, there will be no moderates in Israel. If people go out of their minds worrying about a child who hasn't come home, if the fear reaches our doorsteps, there will be no more moderates.'' Jewish and Arab doves have welcomed the closure of the green line. They see it as a step toward weaning the Arabs away from economic dependence on Israel and building a Palestinian state. They agree with Amos Oz, a leading Israeli novelist and peace activist, who wrote Friday in the newspaper Yedioth Ahronoth: ``Anyone who chooses life over death has to understand that these two nations urgently need to separate.'' For Zionist idealists who believe the Jewish state should run on Jewish labor, the border closure is well timed. Unemployment is increasing rising, worsened by thousands of job-seeking Soviet Jewish immigrants. What could be more sensible, they ask, than giving these Jews the Arabs' jobs? Sarid feels Israel has an opportunity to foster a homegrown Palestinian economy that will set the 1.7 million Arabs of the West Bank and Gaza on the road to statehood. Dr. Adel Samara, a West Bank economist, agrees. He says Palestinians have been demanding independence for 23 years without laying the groundwork for it. ``I could see in the new ban on workers a positive chance for us to use our economic resources and face a new situation without the workers' income from Israel,'' he said in an interview. Zvi Elpeleg, former military governor of the West Bank, believes there already is a de facto Palestinian administration, run by leaders of the uprising. This leadership decides when shops will open, which Palestinian police can continue serving the Israeli government, on what days Palestinians can sell their produce in Israel, he said, adding: ``There are wide areas in which the Israeli government is no longer relevant.''

DOC.HEAD: Organized Crime Figures Indicted on Bingo Money-Laundering Charges
DOC.TEXT: Six reputed organized crime figures from Miami, Chicago and New York were indicted on charges of laundering illegal profits through a commercial bingo parlor and conspiring to torch a competing bingo hall. Prosecutors said the six supplied convicted gambler Stephen Paskind, who owns Bingo World, with more than $1 million to launder from Illinois and Florida. Paskind was named as an unindicted co-conspirator in the 14-count indictment unsealed Friday. The laundered money came from loan-sharking, gambling, robbery and interstate transportation of stolen property, the indictment alleges. ``We consider this a very significant case considering the people involved,'' said Greg Bernstein, assistant U.S. attorney. ``Bingo halls for profit are a very easy place to launder money.'' Indicted were Dominic Peter ``Large'' Cortina, 65, of Chicago; Donald John Angelini, 70, of Elmhurst, Ill.; Sam Frank Urbana, 65, and Izaak Martin ``Red'' Silber, 78, both of Miami; Angelo ``Gus'' King, 64, of West Hollywood, Fla.; and Ettore ``Eddie'' Coco, 82, of New York. Prosecutors would not say why Paskind was not indicted, but Florida law enforcement officials have testified he was an informant on organized crime there. Bernstein said Urbana and Cortina were indicted in Florida last year on federal racketeering charges. Cortina, a convicted gambling kingpin, was believed by authorities to be an organized crime leader in Chicago. Angelini, a close associate of Cortina, is serving a federal prison sentence on a gambling charge. Coco is reputed to be a semi-retired leader of the Lucchese crime family in New York. All six were indicted on charges that include conspiracy, hiding income from the Department of the Treasury, money laundering and interstate travel in aid of racketeering. Federal prosecutors allege that Paskind approached Cortina, Angelini and Urbana in 1986 as financial backers in the construction and operation of Bingo World. Urbana and a Miami man traveled to New York to obtain Coco's ``approval to operate Bingo World in the state of Maryland,'' offering him a share of the profits in return, the indictment alleges. In the arson conspiracy case, Paskind, King and Angelini allegedly met in 1988 with two other men to discuss Bingo World's competitor, Bingo Palace. Paskind allegedly met with King in Florida in September 1989 to ``discuss the arson at Bingo Palace.'' Paskind allegedly paid $20,000 to an arsonist named ``Tommy'' to set a fire at Bingo Palace on Oct. 5, 1989. A sprinkler system halted the spread of the blaze, but damage was serious enough to prevent the scheduled reopening of the business. The indictment outlines a series of transactions in which illegal profits allegedly were funneled to Paskind by some of the others and deposited into personal and Bingo World accounts in Florida and Maryland in sums under $10,000. The intent was to thwart Internal Revenue Service requirements that banks report cash transactions exceeding $10,000, authorities said. Stephen Bronstein, a Maryland accountant who manages Bingo World, said Friday its operators had no comment. Bingo World remains open, pending appeal of an Anne Arundel County order shutting it down because of Paskind's alleged association with organized crime figures.

DOC.HEAD: Newsweek Poll: Bush's Approval Rating Hits Low of 48 Percent
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's approval rating has slipped to 48 percent, its lowest point during his presidency, in a poll conducted for Newsweek by the Gallup Organization, the magazine said Saturday. Asked whether they approve or disapprove of the way Bush is handling his job, 48 percent approved, down from 57 percent in the Newsweek poll Oct. 19. Those who disapproved totaled 36 percent and those who didn't know made up 16 percent in the poll reported in Newsweek's Nov. 5 issue. Asked about Bush's handling of U.S. economic conditions, 56 percent disapproved and 33 percent approved, Newsweek said. Only 19 percent said they trust Bush most to set the course for the nation's economic policy. The other choices in the poll were congressional Republicans (21 percent) and congressional Democrats (36 percent). Newsweek said Gallup interviewed 753 American adults by telephone Thursday and Friday in a sampling that generally should have a margin of error no larger than 4 percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: Bishops Affirm Celibacy Rule
DOC.TEXT: A worldwide gathering of bishops, affirming celibacy in the priesthood, on Saturday urged Pope John Paul II to make it clear that the controversial rule won't be changed. The pope was quick to take up the invitation. He told the bishops that although there is a shortage of priests in some parts of the world, ordaining married men is not the solution. ``This isn't a solution to take under consideration and the problem needs to be addressed by other means,'' such as help from dioceses which have enough priests, the pontiff said. The Vatican requires celibacy for priests in Latin rite churches. The church believes that forsaking marriage and sexual relations means more time for priestly duties and less opportuity for distractions. Exceptions have been made for men who converted to Roman Catholicism after their marriage. In addition, some Eastern rite Catholic churches permit married men to be priests, and that practice was left intact in a recent revision of the rites' laws. The month-long assembly, or synod, was convened by the pope to discuss problems in training priests in the Roman Catholic church, which in recent years has seen several scandals involving sex and a drop in vocations in developed countries, such as the United States and in Western Europe. At least three bishops at the synod called for changes in the celibacy rule, but Vatican officials said the requirement was not up for debate. ``Some have asked ... to consider the ordination of `viri probati,'' John Paul said, using a Latin term for `married, spiritually mature'' men. He said media reports suggesting there might be a change in the celibacy rule were misleading. ``The possibility of a recourse to the `viri probati' is too often evoked in the context of propaganda systematically hostile to priestly celibacy. Such propaganda finds support and complicity in some mass media,'' the pope said. Some bishops echoed the pope's view. ``Some candidates (for the priesthood) think, via the mass media, that there will be a change'' in the celibacy rule, said Archbishop John Foley, a U.S. prelate who heads the Pontifical Council on Social Communication. ``We have to be honest, to remove every doubt, not to give a false impression,'' Foley said at a briefing for reporters following the synod's last working session.
