In what was seen as an attempt to keep the issue alive during the synod, a Brazilian cardinal revealed in an interview with an Italian Catholic magazine, that in the 1980s Pope John Paul II had approved the ordination of two married men in Brazil on condition the men abstain from sexual relations with their wives and live in separate households. Asked if the bishops' recommendation to the pope meant ``debate was closed'' on celibacy, Cardinal Lucas Moreira Neves said the synod's affirmation ``was a very spontaneous expression'' of the bishops' thinking. ``There was no lobby to reaffirm celibacy'' Neves said. The synod also suggested that young men considering the priesthood spend a year of reflection - either before joining a seminary or at some point during seminary studies - to explore their desire to become a priest. ``A lot of young people live in confusion about their faith,'' said Archbishop Jan Schotte, secretary-general of the bishops' synod. The extra time would ``let candidates learn what it is all about.'' Also recommended was better preparation of seminary instructors and continued education for priests. The practice of holding synods, or advisory assemblies, on specific subjects was taken up following the Second Vatican Council of the early 1960s, which was marked by liturgial reforms and moves toward better relations with other faiths.

DOC.HEAD: The Face of Congress To Be Decided in Key State Races
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Deletes 14th graf, ``There are xxx to remove references to total number of legislative seats at issue; Also sent in advance Oct. 24 as b0772.
DOC.TEXT: The partisan makeup of the House for the next decade rests largely with voters in a dozen states this year. As they choose governors and state legislators, these voters will be picking the power brokers for major redistricting battles. The arcane redistricting process draws little attention from voters. But national political parties are pouring millions of dollars and advice into state legislative races that often are ignored in Washington except in years ending in zero. Redistricting occurs once a decade after the Census Bureau completes its decennial head count. The population figures are used to redistribute U.S. House seats among the 50 states and to redraw congressional district lines. Some 19 House seats are expected to shift as a result of the 1990 Census. Most of them will move from the Democratic-leaning Northeast and Midwest to the more conservative South and West, where Republicans have enjoyed success in congressional and presidential elections but lag behind Democrats at the state level. Democrats enter the redistricting process with a decided edge and hope gains this year will serve as a springboard to 1992, when the party will try again to wrest control of the White House from the GOP. Republicans for most of the 1980s touted their ``1991 Plan'' as the means of escaping their nearly 40 years as minority party in the House. But the GOP now finds itself scrambling to defend its major redistricting power bases against formidable Democratic challenges. Already, the GOP is threatening to press legal challenges to partisan plans it expects the Democrats to craft. ``We're in position this year to successfully defend most if not all of our redistricting strengths and then peel off a few if not more from the Republicans,'' said Tim Dickson, executive director of the Democratic Party's redistricting arm, Project 500. At stake is nothing less than control of the House through the year 2003; even modest Democratic gains would cement Republicans as the minority party for the foreseeable future. Party operatives say new computer analyses that mix Census demographics with voting records will allow anyone with a monopoly on redistricting to fashion no-lose districts. ``You can slice up a state and preordain the results with incredible accuracy,'' said Ben Ginsberg, the Republican National Committee's chief counsel. The Republicans hoped for big gains after 17 seats shifted from the Frost Belt to the Sun Belt after the 1980 Census. But Democrats controlled much of the map drawing and ended up with a net gain of three seats. The shifting is called reapportionment, the Census Bureau term for deciding how many of the 435 House seats go to each state. Once that's done the states - in most cases their legislatures - take on the task of redistricting, literally redrawing the lines of each congressional district. There are 6,144 legislative seats up for election in 46 states. There are no legislative races this year in Virginia, New Jersey, Mississippi and Kentucky. After years of exhaustive research, the parties have narrowed their targets to a handful to a dozen races in each of the major redistricting battlegrounds - primarily states that are gaining or losing seats. Fourteen of the shifting seats - and their accompanying electoral votes in presidential elections - will be gobbled up by California, Florida and Texas. In those states, Republicans now control the governor's office but face stiff challenges this year. At the legislative level in those states, only control of the Florida Senate appears in question; Democrats enjoy sizeable advantages in both chambers of the Texas and California legislatures and in the Florida House. Republicans are mounting an aggressive effort to pick up the four seats they need to control the Florida Senate, which would give the GOP a voice in redistricting should Republican Gov. Bob Martinez lose his re-election bid. Democrats are cautiously optimistic they will retain their edge. The fight in the state destined to be the biggest redistricting loser, New York, focuses on the state Senate, where Democrats need a net gain of four seats to win a monopoly on redistricting. ``If that happens what you will see is blatant political gerrymandering,'' said the RNC's Ginsberg. He won't get an argument from Democrats on that point. ``The process is inherently political,'' said Democratic National Committee redistricting guru Mark Bohannon. ``It was designed that way, to benefit winners.'' President Bush has visited New York to help the GOP's state Senate effort, and Gov. Mario Cuomo is working hard for the Democrats. New York likely will lose three of its 34 House seats. Democrats also are spending heavily in hopes of gaining redistricting monopolies in Pennsylvania, Indiana and Michigan. They hope to capture the senates in Pennsylvania and Michigan and both chambers in Indiana, where the GOP has two-seat majorities in the House and Senate. With the Ohio gubernatorial contest leaning Republican, Democrats also are targeting the Ohio Senate, where they need a gain of three seats to win total control of the state legislature. The party has realistic shots at those goals but faces uphill odds in trying to erase slim GOP majorities in both chambers of the Arizona legislature and the Colorado House. Democrats find themselves playing defense in the Florida Senate contests as well as in Illinois, where Republicans need to gain two seats to capture the Senate. Republicans also are trying to take over the lower chambers in Pennsylvania and Oregon, needing a gain of three seats in each state. The Pennsylvania, Michigan, Illinois and Ohio contests are particularly important because each of these states is likely to lose two congressional seats. Control over redistricting will decide which incumbents get squeezed. The other likely losers are Massachusetts, New Jersey, West Virginia, Kentucky, Iowa, Louisiana, Kansas and Montana. Those eight states will lose one seat each, according to preliminary Census data. The redistricting winners are led by California, which should gain seven seats and see its House delegation grow to 52. Florida's expected gain of four would bring its House delegation to 23. The likely pickup of three seats by Texas would swell its representation in the House to 30. Together, these states would supply 24 percent of House members and hold 105 Electoral College votes - 38 percent of the 270 needed to win the White House. The other gainers, expected to pick up one seat each, likely will be Virginia, North Carolina, Georgia, Arizona and Washington. Heading into the elections there were just four states - Idaho, Kansas, New Hampshire and South Dakota - in which Republicans have outright control over state government and none of them are considered major redistricting battlegrounds. Democrats, on the other hand, hold the governor's office and control both legislative chambers in 15 states and at least two of the three seats at the redistricting table in 23 others.

DOC.HEAD: Elliott Roosevelt, Son of FDR, Dies in Scottsdale At 80
DOC.NOTE: Eds:LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with cause and place of death and to DELETE incorrect reference to Normandy Beach. Picks up 7th graf, `He flew ...'
DOC.TEXT: Author Elliott Roosevelt, who served his father, President Franklin Roosevelt, during World War II and later wrote a best seller about it, died Saturday in Scottsdale. He died of congestive heart failure at his home, said Patricia Roosevelt, his wife of 30 years. Roosevelt, 80, was a World War II Air Corps general as well as author and lecturer. He was also a former mayor of Miami Beach, Fla., and a Democratic National Committeeman from that state. His business career included ventures in advertising, radio station management and ranching. Roosevelt was born Sept. 23, 1910, in New York City. He attended Groton and Hun preparatory schools as well as Columbia University. In World War II, Roosevelt commanded the multinational aerial reconnaissance wing that played a key role in the Allies' 1944 D-Day landings in Normandy, France, as well as the invasions of North Africa and Sicily. He flew 89 missions during, was wounded twice and was decorated for valor by the United States, France, Morocco and England. Roosevelt launched his writing career in 1946 with the publication of the best-selling book, ``As He Saw It,'' which detailed his experiences as aide to his father at five historic wartime summit conferences. He later wrote a trilogy of books about his parents and in 1983 wrote ``The Conservators,'' a statement of his philosophy about survival of the planet. Roosevelt lived in the Phoenix area in the late 1950s and returned to Arizona in 1989, settling in Scottsdale. He is survived by his wife, Patricia; a brother, James; eight children; 21 grandchildren; and three great-grandchildren. Memorial services will be held Tuesday in Scottsdale.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING TO CORRECT CODING
Iraqis Have Numerical Edge, But U.S.-Led Force Has Other Advantages
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Nearly three months after the conquest of Kuwait, Iraq's armies hold a large numerical edge over the multinational force arrayed against it in the Saudi desert. But those numbers may start evening up soon. And even now, commanders and analysts say they believe Saddam Hussein's forces are inferior in terms of training, weapons - and possibly morale. Those could be key factors if war erupts. ``The Iraqi armed forces are large,'' Air Chief Marshal Sir Patrick Hine said last week. ``On the other hand, we have many advantages.'' Hine is the joint commander of British forces in the region. ``We have total maritime supremacy and the allied air forces are more capable overall than Saddam's. And then you've got the high quality of American, British and other ground forces here. It's by no means all in his favor,'' he said. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said last week that up to 100,000 U.S. troops could be added to the 220,000-member American force deployed in the gulf region. U.S. troops make up the bulk of the multinational force of about 300,000 troops. They confront an estimated 430,000 Iraqis in Kuwait and southern Iraq. In addition to a troop-strength edge, Iraq has an advantage in terms of some weaponry. Iraq overwhelms the allied forces with 5,500 main battle tanks, including about 1,000 high-quality, Soviet-designed T-72s. An estimated 3,000 tanks are deployed in Kuwait and southern Iraq, including all the T-72s. By the end of October, the United States will have deployed about 700 M1 Abrams tanks to the region. It is also transferring several hundred advanced M1A1 tanks with 120mm guns from storage in Germany to replace some of the older M1s. Brtain has sent its 7th Armored Brigade, the ``Desert Rats,'' with more than 120 Challenger tanks and 45 Warrior armored fighting vehicles. But the numbers alone don't tell the whole story, analysts say. ``You can't (only) compare equipment with equipment,'' said Don Kerr, an analyst at London's International Institute for Strategic Studies. Training, maintenance and morale are also key factors, he said. If it came to battle, he said, ``the strategy would be to hold the Iraqis static in position and let the aircraft and helicopters go at the tanks.'' There's little question that the allied air strength is superior in quality, numbers and readiness. Saddam has 500-plus combat aircraft, including Soviet-supplied long-range fighter-bombers and advanced MiG-29 interceptors, spread around an estimated 25 airbases. Among the 700 tactical aircraft ranged against Iraq are 430 from the U.S. Air Force, including 22 Stealth fighter-bombers and 38 long-range bombers. Also, the armada of Western warships in the region dwarfs Iraq's small navy. As for Iraq's arsenal of missiles and chemical weapons, military analysts have said they would appear to have limited military use since the missiles have low accuracy and it is doubtful whether Iraq actually has workable chemical warheads for its missiles. That leaves only chemical artillery shells and aerial bombing to deliver the chemical weapons. If it comes to war, the Iraqis could have the advantage of a relatively unified command system facing an allied force of units from many nations. But Kerr said the U.S. Central Command headquarters could set strategic objectives while giving a certain amount of tactical flexibility to individual units from the various nations. In any combat that erupts, Iraqis would initially be defending Kuwait, not their own soil. That could be a factor in undermining morale and willingness to fight, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Why the People Hate the Government - Some Theories
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf pvs, bgng: Rep. Bill, to CORRECT spelling of Navajo
DOC.TEXT: Stephen W. Schneider, in a letter-to-the-editor to The Dallas Morning News, suggests that officeholders running for re-election should have ``Inc'' placed after their names on the ballot. ``Inc'' would stand for ``incumbent,'' but if voters took it to mean ``incompetent,'' well, that's ``an understandable conclusion,'' writes Schneider sardonically. Rep. Bill Richardson, D-N.M., was home for the weekend taking part in a parade at a Navajo Reservation when someone - he figures it was a federal employee unhappy about the government's budget impasse - called out, ``You're playing with our lives.'' For the first time, Richardson said, he heard the most dispiriting sound a politician can hear. He was booed. ``It's not comforting to be an elected official these days,'' said Rep. Jim Leach, R-Iowa. Americans seem to be growing more and more hostile toward government - viewing it more as their enemy than their servant. The evidence is everywhere. Oklahomans, getting even, voted to bounce legislators out of office - good, bad or indifferent - after they've served 12 years. Similar term-limitation propositions are expected to get heavy votes in California and Colorado on election day. On Oct. 6, the day President Bush shut down the government in a budget impasse with Congress, former Ku Klux Klansman David Duke got 44 percent of the vote in Louisiana against three-term Democratic Sen. J. Bennett Johnston. Duke got nearly 60 percent of the white vote, even though the establishment of both political parties was against him. His showing has been interpreted as a disgust-with-Washington vote. Congressional votes to raise Congress' pay last spring produced an outburst of outrage. One poll found that 57 percent of the American people don't believe the government represents people like them. Some observers contend that suspicion of government can be healthy. Healthy or not, it's certainly not new. The founding fathers were suspicious of government and wrote a cumbersome system of checks and balances and limited powers into the Constitution. Individual presidents have been the targets of national scorn, even assassins. But for all the alleged throw-the-rascals-out sentiment within the body politic, for all of newspaper reader Stephen Schneider's disgust with officeholders, most incumbents get re-elected. In 1988, 404 of 408 incumbents were returned to the House by the voters. Bruce Buchanan, political scientist at the University of Texas, said voter turnout is a better thermometer of the public mood. When people are disenchanted with government, he said, they don't vote. Turnout has been lower in the 20th century than it was in the 19th, lower in the 1980s and 1990s than in the 1950s. ``Now only about half the electorate shows up,'' he said. So something sour is going on. Government that is supposed to be for, of and by the people increasingly is looked upon as impersonal, nosy, self-serving, bloated, wasteful, incompetent, corrupt and unhelpful. After all, two presidents ran on that premise. Jimmy Carter promised to change government: he would produce ``a government as good as the people.'' Ronald Reagan would ``get the government off your back.'' Politicians, said Buchanan, have a responsibility to encourage belief in the system. Running against government, he said, ``is like eating the seed corn.'' Buchanan breaks the disenchanted into these groups: -The Archie Bunker Types. These are the Louisianans who are not racists but still voted for David Duke. ``They are fed up with a government that seems interested in everyone except them. They regard affirmative action programs as aimed against them.'' -The Cynics. An even larger group, ``they regard government as increasingly self-serving and irrelevant to them and their lives.'' -The Turned-Off. They believe in government, but are appalled by manipulative political campaigns that consist of content-less advertising and preening. ``They listen to gubernatorial candidates in Texas and California, and decide that what they are talking about has nothing to do with what the one who wins will have to do.'' - The Indifferent Young. ``They're 18 to 24, and all of this is utterly irrelevant to them. They don't care about politics. They don't read the paper. They are ignorant of the process.'' ``Put them all together,'' Buchanan said, ``and you have a big group who don't vote, don't pay attention and who get mad.'' John Gardner, former cabinet member and founder of Common Cause, a citizen group that seeks to reform government, blames the mix of money and politics. He thinks America is becoming aware of how ``campaign money is corrupting our political system.'' Rep. Mike Synar, D-Okla., agrees. ``We've got too much money in politics,'' he said. ``The individual voters feels his money or vote doesn't count.'' Willard Wirtz, secretary of labor in the Kennedy and Johnson administrations, believes ``confidence in government has diminished for almost 25 years now.'' ``It probably started when people discovered they weren't being told the truth about the Vietnam war,'' Wirtz said. ``It developed with Watergate and the discovery that their president was a crook. Then both Carter and Reagan seemed to have, in very different forms, a contempt for the processes of government.'' Constance Berry Newman, who as director of the Office of Personnel Management is the chief personnel officer for the government's 3 million civilian employees, has a few theories of her own. For one thing, she said, people don't realize what they're getting from the government for their taxes. People eat food that has been tested by government, drive on government-built roads, send their kids to government-operated schools without a second thought, she said. Then, people blame government when they have a run-in with the Social Security bureaucrat or the IRS. Second, she said, ``We are down to problems in this country that can only be resolved by some group giving up something for another. For a long time we solved problems by putting new money on the table. It didn't have to be taken from someone else. We were borrowing it, in fact. ``Now all the problems have to be resolved at the expense of something else. That brings about resentment. People making those tradeoffs become the enemy. They're policymakers and elected officials. They're government.''

DOC.HEAD: Union Warns Chrysler Corp. in Strike Letter
DOC.TEXT: The United Auto Workers is threatening Chrysler Corp. with a strike at midnight Monday unless substantial progress is made on a new contract, union and company officials said Saturday. The warning, in a letter the union gave Chrysler on Friday, puts the pressure on negotiations that began in mid-July, but UAW spokesman Bob Barbee would not say if the letter increases the likelihood of a strike. Chrysler is the only one of the Big Three automakers yet to reach a new three-year agreement with the UAW, which represents about 63,000 active Chrysler workers. The union wants to negotiate a contract with Chrysler similar to those reached with General Motors Corp. in September and with Ford Motor Co. earlier this month. Among the major issues between the UAW and Chrysler are health-care and retiree benefits. The company said it may not be able to afford provisions on health care and pensions that are in the so-called pattern agreement with GM and Ford. The union is using those contracts as models for the Chrysler contract. Chrysler was expected to announce Monday a third-quarter loss likely to wipe out $251 million the company earned during the first two quarters of this year. The union letter technically clears the way for a strike against Chrysler, but also gives negotiators, who met Saturday, another couple of days to work out a contract. The union could agree to extend the deadline on a day-to-day basis, could strike or could continue working under an informal extension agreement. Clarence Cobb, a member of UAW Local 7 in Detroit, said it was time for a strike against Chrysler. ``The heat should have been turned up a long time ago,'' he said. ``They should have stuck them a long time ago.'' Local 7 represented workers at a Chrysler assembly plant that the company shut down in ebruary. Cobb and more than 2,000 other laid-off workers are waiting for Chrysler to complete construction of a new plant so they can return to work. Until then, Cobb is living on $380 a week in unemployment benefits and his wife's salary as a city court worker in Detroit. ``I'm living week-to-week. I'd be up a creek if my wife wasn't working,'' said Cobb, who worked for Chrysler for 24 years before being laid off. Negotiations continued in subcommittees, which focus on specific areas of a contract. In addition, UAW President Owen Bieber and Chrysler Vice President Anthony St. John have met with key negotiators occasionally over the past few days. After the UAW pattern agreement was ratified with GM workers, it took just six days for Ford and the union to reach agreement. Talks between the union and Chrysler are moving slower. The Canadian Auto Workers union and Chrysler Canada Ltd. reached an agreement last week that mirrored a pattern contract the union had negotiated with GM and Ford Canadian subsidiaries.

DOC.HEAD: Winds Stir Great Lakes, Sunny Skies Prevail
DOC.TEXT: Strong wind stirred up the Great Lakes on Saturday and chilled temperatures in the Midwest. Michigan got a spot of rain and sunny skies prevailed over much of the United States. Strong winds accompanying a cold front in the Great Lakes, the Mississippi Valley and the Plains cooled afternoon temperatures to the lower 40s in Minnesota and produced wind chill readings there as cold as the upper teens. Evening rain was expected in the Midwest. Blustery winds also blew in Alaska and New England, where midday temperatures dipped as low as the 30s. Morning winds in Juneau gusted to 60 mph. Sunny and dry weather prevailed across much of the nation. Clouds were primarily confined to the northern tier states. Northern Michigan got showers. Temperatures were as high as the 70s and 80s in the southern Plains. Afternoon readings were mostly in the 60s across the Southeast. The northern Plains and Mississippi Valley had temperatures in the 40s, along with the northern Atlantic Coast. In the West, midday temperatures ranged from the 40s in the northern Rockies to the 70s and 80s in parts of California. Hollywood and Lakeland in Florida set record lows for the date, Hollywood with a reading of 57 degrees and Lakeland with a reading of 46 degrees. The morning cold spot in the Lower 48 was 15 degrees in Saranac Lake, N.Y.

DOC.HEAD: Party Official Admits Transferring Money; Says Gysi Didn't Know
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with Gysi withdrawing resignation offer; picks up 9th graf pvs, `The party's ...
DOC.TEXT: An official of the former East German Communist Party said Saturday that party chairman Gregor Gysi was kept in the dark about illegal money transfers abroad, the ADN news agency reported. Gysi, 42, offered to step down as the party's leadership met in an emergency session to discuss the implications of the financial scandal. But he withdrew the offer after the 95-member party board gave him a unanimous vote of confidence. Two officials in East Germany's former Communist Party have been arrested for allegedly funneling about $70 million in party funds out of the country and into accounts in the Soviet Union. On Saturday, Karl-Heinz Kaufmann, a former Communist official from the city of Halle, told ADN he transferred the $70 million to accounts belonging to a Soviet company. But he said Gysi was not aware of the action. In a speech to the party board, Gysi confirmed that he had been unaware of the transfer. He said many party members had signed appeals for him to remain as chairman. The scandal appeared likely to hurt the party's chances in national elections for an all-German parliament on Dec. 2. It also cast doubt on Gysi's political future. After last year's popular revolt which swept the Communists out of power, the party purged most of its Old Guard, renamed itself the Party of Democratic Socialism, or PDS, and elected Gysi as chairman. But as successor to the Communists, the PDS has been viewed with suspicion by the traditional German political parties. The party's deputy chairman and treasurer, Wolfgang Pohl, and its financial director, Wolfgang Langnitschke, earlier admitted funneling the money to accounts belonging to a Soviet company. They were arrested Friday. A party statement said the two officials acted without the knowledge or approval of the party leadership. Pohl said he was trying to protect party funds from being seized by the government. Berlin police raided the party headquarters on Oct. 19, seeking evidence on the illegal money transfers. The party said at the time that money had been paid to the Soviets, but only to cover old debts and pay for the living expenses of students it was sponsoring in Moscow. However, Gysi went to Moscow on Thursday and was told that the Soviet Communist Party did not request the funds. Kaufmann was quoted by ADN as saying that he and Pohl transferred the money because of the ``imminent threat of expropriation'' of party funds by the government. ``We wanted to keep Gysi and Modrow clean,'' Kaufmann was quoted as saying. Hans Modrow was East Germany's last Communist premier and guided the country until its first free elections in March. Both Gysi and Modrow are among the 24 PDS deputies who hold temporary seats in German Parliament. When the two Germanys united on Oct. 3., 144 former East German lawmakers were given seats in the parliament until the December elections. ADN said it spoke to Kaufmann on Saturday in Moscow, where he had been staying for the past few days ``in connection with the multimillion-deal.'' According to ADN, Kaufmann told the agency he transferred the money to the Berlin accounts of the Soviet company Putnik, from where the money was moved to Putnik's accounts in other countries, among them the Netherlands. Putnik also gave PDS false receipts that claimed the money went into construction work and student fees, ADN quoted Kaufmann as saying. Kaufmann told ADN his own company in Halle, Putnik, and two other German firms had been planning to use the money to start a trading company. Kaufmann claimed that two Dutch banks also had been involved in the project. The banks were not identified in the ADN report. ``We wanted to create jobs for many old comrades who are now unemployed,'' Kaufmann was quoted as saying. But German television said Putnik was a front company. Kaufmann told ADN he does not feel he has done anything illegal. Late Friday, Berlin police again searched PDS headquarters in an attempt to determine if there was evidence of more financial iregularities. Party spokesman Hanno Harnisch said police took away several hundred pounds of documents.

DOC.HEAD: Iwo Jima Spotlights Preparations For Kuwait Landing
DOC.TEXT: The commander of the USS Iwo Jima said Saturday that Marines aboard his ship have completed drills for a landing operation in case of a military showdown to drive Iraq from Kuwait. ``We are at a very high state and level of readiness,'' Capt. Michael S. O'Hearn told reporters aboard his ship, calling in Bahrain to allow its 1,700 Marines a break after the exercise. The IwoJima is one of 18 amphibious assault vessels deployed to the multinational air, sea and naval buildup that followed Saddam Hussein's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Thirty-seven other U.S. Navy units are in the Persian Gulf, the Arabian Sea and the Red Sea as part of Operation Desert Shield, which involves more than 200,000 U.S. military personnel. O'Hearn said Saddam had developed elaborate defensive constructions, including minefields. But the Navy has no reports of mines in the waters of the Persian Gulf, he said. ``Up in Kuwait where he's dug in, he has put mines there, but as far as the waters south of Kuwait, I am not aware that he has put any mines there,'' O'Hearn said. In any case, the Iwo Jima would not land until minesweepers had cleared out such obstacles, he said. The ship, carrying 30 Marine helicopters and a landing team of about 1,700, is named for the February 1945 battle in which three Marine divisions defeated a 20,000-member Japanese force on Iwo Jima island. The Iwo Jima was stationed off Lebanon in 1983 during a U.S.-led multinational operation to supervise the Israeli withdrawal from that country. ``I would love to see this worked out in a peaceful fashion, where we could get Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait and back to his borders, and do it without the loss of life,'' said O'Hearn, a native of Manitowoc, Wis., whose family lives in Norfolk, Va., where the ship is based. ``Any man who has seen war once wouldn't want to see it again,'' he said. O'Hearn was decorated for helicopter gunship missions during the Vietnam war. ``On the other side, myself and my crew are ready to fight if necessary. I definitely think we would give him a very good licking,'' he said. President Bush has said he wants to give international trade sanctions time to pressure Iraq out of Kuwait. But he has not ruled out using military force.

DOC.HEAD: Government Seeks to End Road Blockades With Lower Gas Price Hike
DOC.TEXT: The government Saturday agreed to cut in half a 70 percent gasoline price increase, prompting some cabbies to lift protest blockades that have caused nationwide gridlock. Shortly after the pact between officials and the demonstrators was announced on state television, taxi drivers moved vehicles that blocked one of Budapest's bridges over the Danube River. But it was not immediately clear whether the 35 percent price increase will be supported by all the thousands of protesting cabbies and truck drivers whose vehicles have clogged the Hungarian streets and highways since the initial price hike was announced Friday. Cabs and trucks were parked across roadways or abandoned in their lanes. Some motorists caught in the traffic jams late Friday spent the night in their cars, but protesters Saturday opened some roads to border crossings and Budapest's international airport. Earlier Saturday, a crowd gathered in front of Parliament to rally in opposition of the gas price increase. ``Go home!'' Interior Minister Balazs Horvath shouted through a bullhorn. ``The government wants order. We will keep order; we urge you to keep order too.'' But police did not attemptto break up the roadblocks, and at least some officials seemed supportive of the protest. Budapest Police Chief Sandor Barna said he would obey a ``lawful order to restore order.'' ``But if it is contrary to my conscience, I know what I will do - resign,'' he added. The blockades followed a government announcement that premium gasoline would increase from 59 cents a liter to $1 a liter, or about $3.80 a gallon. Under the 35 percent hike, the price per gallon would be about $3. Similar hike were planned for other gasoline grades. The average monthly net income in Hungary is around $150. The government said the price increases were needed because of reductions in Soviet shipments and higher oil prices following the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. The protest represented the most serious sign of discontent with the worsening economic situation as Hungary tries to move to a more capitalist system. Elections last spring ended four decades of one-party Communist rule. Hungary's more than $20 billion debt is the highest per capita in the former Soviet bloc. Meanwhile, unemployment and a housing crisis continue to grow. Before the smaller price hike was announced late Saturday, Austrian, Czechoslovak and Yugoslav border officials reported traffic out of Hungary was reduced to a trickle. The Hungarian-Romanian border was closed to vehicle traffic. In the capital city of Budapest and other major cities, few cars moved except emergency vehicles and food supply vans. Budapest's subway was the only public transportation operating, and all but one of the Danube bridges had been blocked. The river cuts across the capital. Not all truckers participated in the protest. State television showed some arguing with their colleagues in an attempt to get through. But the mood of the people in Budapest and elsewhere appeared to back the protesters. Shoppers lining up for bread and milk in anticipation of shortages joked with some of the protesting truckers brewing coffee over field stoves. Several groups of youths set up picnic tables on one of the jammed bridges laden with food and drink. ``The air will never be this clean again,'' one of them told state television. In Bonn, German Chancellor Helmut Kohl said a group of experts would travel to Hungary on Monday to discuss ways of improving energy supplies, according to a statement released by Germany's federal press office. Kohl said he will urge the European Common Market to help Hungary. ``Germany will continue to give friendly support to Hungary on its way to democratic stability and economic improvement,'' Kohl's statement said. It gave no details. Hungary's decision last year to let thousands of East Germans leave the country for the West helped begin the revolution that led to the Oct. 3 unification of the two Germanys.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Request Security Council Suspension to Explore Gulf Peace
DOC.TEXT: In a last-minute turnaround, the Soviets asked the Security Council on Saturday to postpone a vote on another condemnation of Iraq. Diplomats said the Soviets hope peace overtures will develop over the weekend. The Security Council members were already seated at their circular table, documents in hand and ready to vote on the 10th anti-Iraq resolution since the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, when Soviet Ambassador Yuli Vorontsov rushed up to confer with U.S. Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering. They met privately with the French, British and Chinese ambassadors, and then the Soviets requested a suspension of the vote until Monday. As is the case for any of the five permanent council members, the Soviet request was granted without debate. The postponement is ``because of the overtures'' being pursued by various top Soviet, French and Iraqi officials this weekend, said Yemeni Ambassador Abdalla Saleh al-Ashtal. Chinese U.N. Ambassador Li Daoyu said the Soviets asked for the delay to avoid complicating a meeting Sunday between Iraqi President Saddam Hussein and the top Soviet Middle East expert, Yevgeny M. Primakov. Saddam has indicated interest in French President Francois Mitterrand's proposal that an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait could set the stage for a broad Middle East peace settlement. Such a settlement would involve a Mideast peace conference that could lead to a homeland for the Palestinians, Mitterrand told the U.N. General Assembly in September. However, the French president said it all depends on Iraq's unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait. In Madrid, at a news conference Saturday with Spanish Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez, Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev suggested the Iraqi leadership might be softening its hard-line position in the Persian Gulf crisis. His remarks were interpreted as a sign that the Kremlin has made progress in its diplomatic initiatives. A French TV station reported Friday that Saddam had sent letters to both Mitterrand and Gorbachev expressing his readiness to discuss Kuwait. The station, La Cinq, quoted Saddam as saying he was open ``to all ideas'' for resolving the gulf crisis. French officials denied knowledge of any letters. Gorbachev travels to Paris on Sunday for talks with Mitterrand. The Security Council was just moments away from voting Saturday to hold Iraq liable for abusing the human rights of Kuwaitis and foreign hostages, and for economic losses caused by its invasion of Kuwait. In nine previous resolutions, the council has isolated Iraq with an economic embargo and permitted U.N. member countries to use flotillas of warships in the Persian Gulf to enforce it. The council also has demanded that Iraq unconditionally withdraw from Kuwait and release all foreign hostages. The new resolution invites nations, companies and individuals to document their damage and losses for the Security Council, although it does not establish a system for making claims against Baghdad. It demands that Iraq stop taking hostages and ``mistreating and oppressing Kuwaiti and third-state nationals.'' The resolution also moved toward establishing Iraq's responsibility for war crimes, inviting nations to collect information on abuses of civilians contrary to the Fourth Geneva Convention of 1949. The convention, which Iraq signed, protects the rights of civilians in wartime or in military-occupied territory, outlawing summary execution, torture, deportations and hostage-taking.

DOC.HEAD: Corsican Separatists Claim Responsibility for Bombing
DOC.TEXT: A Corsican separatist group Saturday claimed responsibility for bombing a kitchenware factory. The blast caused extensive damage but no injuries, police said. About 10 masked gunmen overpowered the factory director and three employees Friday night in Aubagne, near Marseille, then set off the explosives. The four captives were tied up, driven away from the factory, then released, police said. The kitchenware company is a subsidiary of Societe Nationale Corse Mediterranee, a major operator of ferries between Corsica and the French mainland. On Saturday, a communique was sent to the press claiming responsibility for the attack on behalf of the Corsican National Liberation Front. The front has carried out scores of bombings in Corsica in recent years as part of its campaign to end French rule over the Mediterranean island. But Friday's bombing was the first on the mainland claimed by the group since a series of attacks on banks and airline offices in southern France in March 1986. The communique said the kitchenware company earned 75 percent of its revenues from boats serving Corsica ``without reinvesting anything on the island.'' It described the Societe Nationale Corse Mediterranee as ``one of the instruments that keeps Corsica in a state of dependence.'' The communique demanded that the company relocate in Corsica. The bombing occurred the day after a visit to Corsica by French Interior Minister Pierre Joxe, whose proposal for new, semi-autonomous administration on the island has been rejected by separatist leaders.

DOC.HEAD: Venezuelan Army Conducts Huge Sweep of Gold Miners
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers raided illegal gold mines in the Amazon jungle and arrested more than 300 people, mostly foreigners, Foreign Minister Reinaldo Figueredo said Saturday. Most of the illegal miners detained in last week's raids were taken to Puerto Ayacucho, a jungle outpost on the Orinoco River about 400 miles south of Caracas, where they were to be tried on charges of damaging the environment, authorities said. Since last year, the federal government has made more than 1,000 arrests in attempting to staunch an invasion of miners crossing the unmarked jungle border between Brazil and Venezuela. The mining process, which uses mercury, has been blamed for poisoning rivers and for the deaths of several Yanomami Indians in Venezuela's isolated, largely roadless Amazonas territory. The government is trying to protect the estimated 14,000 Yanomami living in Venezuela, possibly the most isolated and largest primitive tribe remaining on earth. Defense Minister Hector Jurado Toro said about 800 soldiers were involved in the sweep. The troops dismantled mining operations and detained everyone who did not manage to escape into the jungle, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Polls Show Labor With Wide Lead Over Tories
DOC.TEXT: The opposition Labor Party swept to a 16-point lead over the Conservatives in two new opinion polls, and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's personal popularity slumped further. A survey by the respected Mori firm to be published in the Sunday Times, and a new Harris poll in The Observer on Sunday show the Conservatives have lost ground over the past month. The Sunday Times poll showed Mrs. Thatcher's personal approval ratings had dropped by seven points to 29 percent. Sixty-six percent of those polled expressed ``dissatisfaction'' with the prime minister. In contrast, 45 percent of those polled approved of Labor Party leader Neil Kinnock, while 42 percent expressed ``dissatisfaction'' with Kinnock. Mrs. Thatcher, who has led Britain since 1979, is expected to call the next general election sometime next year. Labor has been leading the Conservatives in the polls for months. Recently, the government regained a little ground after it announced entry into the European Exchange Rate Mechanism and interest rates were cut by 1 percent. But the recent polls indicate the gains were temporary. The Sunday Times poll of 1,043 voters, conducted October 24-25, asked people how they intended to vote. The poll showed 49 percent favored Labor, up four points over last month; 33 for the Conservatives, down five points from last month; 14 percent for Liberal Democrats, up two points; 2 percent for Green Party, down 1 percent. Other parties gained the remaining votes. The Harris Poll, which surveyed 1,043 voters between October 24-25, found similar results in voting intentions. No margin of error was provided for either poll.

DOC.HEAD: Major Kerosene Spill in Hudson River, Coast Guard Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with comment from Coast Guard officer. Picks up 5th graf, Petty Officer ...'
DOC.TEXT: Coast Guard crews took advantage of favorable weather Saturday to contain 164,000 gallons of kerosene that spilled into the Hudson River when a barge ran aground on a reef. The barge, carrying about 30,000 barrels of kerosene or 1.26 million gallons, ran aground and sprang a leak Friday night about one mile south of Marlboro and 60 miles north of New York City, said Bill Falk, a U.S. Coast Guard spokesman in New York. The cause of the accident was not immediately clear, but high winds and choppy seas may have contributed, Falk said. The barge hit a known underwater hazard called Diamond Reef, which lies about 5 feet below the surface, said Coast Guard Chief Petty Officer Alan Burd. Barges can di 3 to 9 feet below the water when carrying a full load, he said. ``It was a known hazard and it was marked with a buoy,'' Burd said. Petty Officer Howard Holmes said strong winds were keeping the kerosene along the river's eastern shore. ``The weather is very much in our favor,'' he said. ``We're not chasing oil all over the river.'' An overflight by Coast Guard helicopters Saturday morning determined that the kerosene was concentrated at Brockway, about 2 miles to the south, and had drifted as far south as the Newburgh Bridge, another half a mile downstream. A sheen, possibly linked to the spill, was reported on the river's surface at a water treatment plant in Poughkeepsie, five miles north of the spill sight, said Peter Doshna, regional spill coordinator for the state Department of Environmental Conservation. Environmentally-sensitive areas were blocked off with containment booms soon after the spill, Holmes said. They included Wappinger Creek, less than a quarter of a mile from the spill site, Fishkill Creek and Constitution Isle. The kerosene, usually used as a solvent and for fueling lamps and furnaces, posed no threat to riverside residents, Falk said. About two dozen Coast Guard and contracted workers used absorbent pads, vacuum trucks and about 3,000 feet of containment boom in the cleanup effort. The barge's New York City-based owner, Hygrade Operators, hired a private company to help out. No charges had been filed against Hygrade by Saturday, Holmes said. Aiding in the cleanup was the rapid dissipation rate of the oil, Holmes said. ``We expect 30 to 50 percent of the product to evaporate or dissipate within the first 24 hours,'' he said. ``In a 48-hour period, we expect 70 to 80 percent to dissipate.'' The barge, named Hygrade 42, was traveling from New York City to Rensselaer, N.Y.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Agree to be Patient in Search for Life on Mars
DOC.TEXT: Scientists searching for life on Mars agreed Saturday that they must be patient and focus on learning more about the environment of the cold, dry planet. ``If we're going to find life on Mars, it's not going to be just sitting around in the dust someplace,'' said John D. Rummel, who directs life biology research for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. ``We're going to have to find places on Mars that are more likely to contain life forms than you would find at random,'' he said. Rummel was among two dozen scientists from North America, the Soviet Union, Europe and Japan who attended the International Symposium on the Biological Exploration of Mars at Florida State University. Three speakers cautioned that it was too soon to conduct direct life experiments on Mars, but Rummel said most of the scientists agreed the planet should be studied for insights that could lead to a discovery of life on the planet. ``Mars is not considered by many people to be a lifeless planet,'' Rummel said. Ten years ago, the landings on Mars during the Viking missions detected no signs of life on Mars, the most Earth-like planet in the solar system. Scientists believe the planet was once more hospitable for the evolution of life than it is now. Conditions grew harsher, primarily drier and colder. Rummel said some scientists believe that signs of life, either past or present, might be discovered deeper under the surface, near heat sources where water might be found. The latest data from Mars came from unmanned Soviet missions in 1988. The United States plans to send a spacecraft to orbit Mars in 1992 and the Soviets plan a 1994 mission that would land an unmanned robotic rover vehicle and balloons to explore the planet's surface. On Earth, scientists are studying volcanoes, ocean bottoms, lakes and rocks in Antarctica and Siberian permafrost to see what kinds of life can survive under Martian-like conditions. E. Imre Friedmann, a Florida State researcher who organized the meeting, said there's a good likelihood that life once existed on Mars. ``You cannot really express it numerically, you cannot quantify it, but it is certainly good enough to justify serious effort to verify whether or not this is really the case,'' Friedmann said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Calls on Allies to Stay United in Gulf Crisis
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Saturday called on West European leaders meeting at a summit to keep Iraq from dividing them by exploiting their desires to see the release of foreigners held in Iraq and Kuwait. Bush telephoned Italian Premier Giulio Andreotti shortly before the start of a summit of the 12-nation European Community, the first meeting of the leaders since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Bush ``spoke of the need for solidarity ... and strong cohesion, also regarding the hostages,'' said Italian spokesman Pio Mastrobuoni. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has been making separate offers to European countries to release foreigners who are being held as ``human shields'' at strategic locations in Iraq. Mastrobuoni said Italy did not want to give Saddam any inkling there might be ``a break in solidarity.'' ``We are solid and he is failing,'' said a British official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. German Chancellor Helmut Kohl said Western nations wanted the hostages released but all of them - and not just Europeans, according to spokesman Hans Klein. Saddam has recently allowed small groups of hostages to leave, some after visits to Baghdad by prominent figures. Iraqi has said it is freeing all French hostages. French spokesman Hubert Vedrine said the release of the French hostages was decided unilaterally by the Iraqis and did not affect French solidarity with the anti-Iraq coalition. British officials said they expected the summit participants to release a statement on the Persian Gulf. But Vedrine doubted it would differ greatly from previous community statements on the issue. The leaders put off until late evening a discussion of a dispute over a proposal in world trade talks for cuts in farm subsidies. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said the community's failure to endorse a plan for crop subsidy cuts ``was bad for its reputation, bad for world trade, bad for our relations with the United States and bad for developing countries.'' Kohl's spokesman said the German leader and Bush talked several times in recent days about the trade dispute, and Bush also spoke to Andreotti on the issue, stressing the need for a quick agreement. At issue is a community proposal for 30 percent reductions in subsidies for major crops over a 10-year period beginning in 1986. Some cuts already have occurred. The community's failure in six attempts, most recently on Friday, to approve the package has threatened the Uruguay Round of international trade negotiations. The talks are an ambitious effort to revamp the world trade system. The farm cuts have run into opposition from Germany, France and Ireland, which are worried about the impact on millions of their farmers. Mrs. Thatcher has used the dispute to bolster her argument that the community is not yet ready to move quickly to a political merger and an economic and monetary union of the 12 nations.

DOC.HEAD: Mormon Tabernacle Choir Announcer Off the Air
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT Kinard's age to 50 sted 61.
DOC.TEXT: The Mormon Tabernacle Choir's announcer, heard by millions nationwide on the group's radio show, has been placed on medical leave and could lose his job, a Mormon church official said. Sources at the station told The Associated Press the leave for J. Spencer Kinard, 50, was prompted by allegations he lied about his relationship with a 24-year-old TV anchorwoman, Jennifer Howe. Choir president Wendell Smoot said Kinard is on medical leave, but refused to comment on the alleged relationship. Howe, who's married, denies there's a relationship. Kinard, also married, won't comment onwwhat he calls rumors. Kinard's future with the CBS Radio Network's longest-running program, where he has been announcer since 1972, rests with the Mormon Church's governing First Presidency, choir president Wendell Smoot said. ``The matter is under review by the brethren,'' Smoot said Friday. ``They are the people who called Spence, and if they release him that's their decision to make.'' Kinard is news director at the Mormon-owned KSL Television in Salt Lake City as well as announcer of the choir's 61-year-old radio program, ``Music and the Spoken Word.'' Howe works at KSL TV. Kinard said he had been given leave from both jobs for ``stress-management problems.'' He declined to address ``rumors'' about Howe, who also is on leave from her job. ``Right now I have been to some doctors,'' Kinard said Friday.``Everyone agrees there is a stress issue. I'm dealing with that and I expect to be back. And that's all I can say about it.'' Kinard's departure was triggered by a staff meeting Oct. 19 in which he admitted exercising poor judgment but said he had done ``nothing immoral,'' according to sources who attended. KSL executives would not respond to questions about Kinard's relationship with Howe or his future with the station. ``Our concern is just for Spence Kinard and his truly stressful situation,'' said Jack Adamson, president of KSL Inc., flagship of church-owned Bonneville International Corp. But station sources said officials warned Kinard not to be alone with Howe in April after reports the two were seen together in the station's basement parking lot late one night in February. At the staff meeting, Kinard denied being with Howe that night, although three staff members reported seeing them, sources said. He also said it was ``pure coincidence'' he and Howe returned to Salt Lake City on the same flight from Oakland, Calif., last month. From her parents' home in Dallas, Howe said her relationship with Kinard was professional and not the reason her husband of 13{ months, Brad Goode, filed for divorce on Oct. 1. Goode is an anchorman at rival station KTVX. Howe said Friday that her relationship with Kinard was professional. ``He's my boss. He's my employer. I think of him as a friend,'' Howe said. ``I'm not having an affair with him.'' Howe said she was disliked by her colleagues because of her youth and her rapid rise in July from reporter to co-anchor of the noon newscast. She said she intends to fulfill the remaining 13 months of her contract, but added her future is ``a bit up in the air.'' KSL weather forecaster Kent Norton was scheduled to act as announcer for the Sunday choir broadcast for the second week.

DOC.HEAD: Rushdie Says He Wants Reconciliation With Islam
DOC.TEXT: Salman Rushdie says he is optimistic that he can work out a reconciliation with Moslems, but an Iranian leader says the death sentence against the Indian-born author of ``The Satanic Verses'' can never be lifted. ``I have to hope that the atmosphere is gradually changing. I think there's various signs that it might be,'' Rushdie told CBS News correspondent Mike Wallace in an interview for Sunday's edition of ``60 Minutes.'' In a separate interview, Rajei-Khorrasani, a powerful leader in Iran's parliament, said the death sentence cannot be lifted ``because it is a religious fact, which remains there forever.'' Rushdie, 43, a Bombay-born British subject, has been in hiding under police guard since Feb. 14, 1989, when Iran's spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, declared his novel an affront to Islam and ordered Moslems to kill him. Khomeini died June 3, 1989. Iranian clerics offered a $5.2-million bounty for Rushdie's assassination. Among parts of the ``The Satanic Verses'' many Moslems find offensive are a scene in which prostitutes are given the names of the prophet Mohammed's wives, and implications that Mohammed wrote the Koran, the Moslem holy book. Rushdie said he never meant to insult the Moslem world. ``If I'm accused of calling the prophet's wives whores, I didn't do it,'' he said. ``I'm not this kind of creature with horns and a tail that's been painted,'' he said. ``There is actually very little in `Satanic Verses' that hasn't been, in fact, quite commonplace discussion in the Moslem world for hundreds of years.'' Wallace said he met with the author at a police officers' club on the outskirts of London.

HONOLULU (AP) Here is the text of President Bush's remarks at a news conference Saturday in Honolulu. PRESIDENT BUSH: Let me start with a statement, and then be glad to take some questions. But I've just been informed that the United States Senate has just passed the House-Senate conference report on the budget. And this completes congressional action on an agreement to reduce the federal deficit by over $490 billion over the next five years. This budget blueprint represents corrective action on a pattern of federal spending gone out of control. We have put on the brakes and the process has sometimes been painful. But I will sign this legislation because for the first time, it makes significant and long-term cuts in federal spending that should have a positive impact on America's economic future. All political points of view have sacrificed to bring this agreement about, and needless to say, I don't like raising taxes and never will. But there is a price to divided government and that means that I have had to compromise on items that I feel strongly about in order to do what I think is best for the country and that is to reach an agreement. At the same time, we've cut federal spending programs and applied some self-discipline, a step that also may not be popular, but the essential ingredient which has produced bipartisan agreement is that we must get the deficit down, get interest rates down, and keep America moving. And I might add, I am told that the final enforcement provisions are very, very strong, so that we're guarding against more spending - out of control spending next year and into the future covered by this agreement. In addition, I am pleased that many of my proposals on child care are incorporated in this budget reconciliation bill. The legislation provides tax credits, grants and vouchers that puts choice in the hands of parents rather than in the hands of bureaucrats. So I'm very pleased about the child care provisions, something I've been fighting for. I intend to sign the agreement. And I will also review closely the various appropriations bills to make sure that they conform to this new spending agreement. We've made the tough decisions and now it's time to move on. And I am pleased that the Congress also has passed historic Clean Air Act amendments which will reduce acid rain, urban smog, and toxic air pollution. We proposed this far reaching environmental cleanup legislation some 15 months ago with the hope that this initiative by the administration would break the logjam that had prevented a Clean Air bill from being passed previously. This is an important milestone in preserving and protecting America's natural resources. And I look forward to signing the bill. I want to conclude by thanking everyone involved, including the bipartisan leadership in Congress for their tireless efforts in forging and passing the new budget agreement. The Speaker, Minority Leader Bob Michel, the Majority Leader Dick Gephardt, Senator Mitchell and Senator Dole have all had to compromise some and they stayed with it long, long hours trying to hammer out this agreement. And so I want to take this opportunity to thank them. I'll be glad to take a few questions and then we got to head on. Q: Mr. President, you signed onto this budget agreement and your - your negotiators negotiated with Congress, including the tax increases that you vowed you wouldn't do when you ran for office. Are you prepared now to give it a sound endorsement and urge Republican candidates to go out and sell it to the voters as well? PRESIDENT BUSH: No. Q: Are you going to turn your back on it and blame the Democrats for the tax increases that you agreed with? PRESIDENT BUSH: I'm going to say, ``Look, I've reluctantly signed this. There are things in it that if I control both houses of congress, wouldn't be in it''. But that - and I think the Democrats will be saying the same thing. I notice some of them saying yesterday that they felt we ought to have higher income tax rates. One of the things I'm glad on is - glad about is that we've held the line on income tax rates. A handful of the wealthiest went up and 10 times that many of the upper middle income came down. Some went from 28 to 31, others came down from 33 to 31. There are certain things in it that I can strongly advocate. There are some things in it I had to gag and digest. And so that's the approach I'm going to be taking, and I expect everyone else will, too. Q: Mr. President? PRESIDENT BUSH: Yeah. We'll just go right around the corner. Yeah, Laurie? Q: You say it's time to move on. Do you have any fear, or do you think expectation that the whole - the atmosphere of the last couple of weeks is going to haunt you in the election? PRESIDENT BUSH: No. I don't think so at all. Sometimes the president has to make a tough call. This is one of them. And I'll be right out on the campaign trail advocating the election of more Republicans to the Congress, and we wouldn't have been in this mess if we had that. Q: Mr. President, how can you go out now and blame Democrats, criticize Democrats, when in fact they more than Republicans helped you get this budget package which you supported passed?

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Postpones Iraq Vote, Gorbachev Says Iraq Might be Softening
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with Security Council delaying vote, Bush call to European allies for solidarity; MINOR EDITING; no pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DHA1, MAD3
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail Gorbachev indicated Saturday that Iraq may be softening its stand on Kuwait, and the Soviets forced the U.N. Security Coucil to delay an anti-Iraqi vote in a bid to let peace moves develop over the weekend. Speaking in Madrid, Spain, Gorbachev said the coming days might bring clarification of a change in Iraq's position. The Soviet president's envoy, Yevgeny Primakov, was to meet Sunday in Baghdad with Saddam Hussein. In New York, as the assembled U.N. Security Council members prepared to demand that Iraq pay war reparations, Soviet Ambassador Yuli Vorontsov rushed to the side of his U.S. colleague, Thomas Pickering, and requested a 48-hour delay on the resolution vote. The delay was granted. Vorontsov said later that the postponement would allow Primakov's talks with Saddam to take place in a less tense atmosphere. In Baghdad, French officials announced that most Frenchmen held by Iraq would be allowed to leave Sunday. Iraqi officials granted 301 French nationals permission to leave but expressed reservations about seven others, they said. The officials said negotiations were being held to secure exit permits for the seven, who are accused by Iraqi authorities of breaking their contracts and abandoning work at a government guest palace under renovation. Vorontsov's intervention came after Security Council members had agreed to adopt a resolution holding Iraq liable for war damages and economic losses caused by its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. ``We will have a massive vote in favor,'' the British Ambassador to the United Nations, Sir David Hannay, had said earlier. But the council postponed the vote until Monday. The new resolution would be the Council's 10th to condemn Iraq since Saddam's forces invaded Kuwait in a dispute over oil, land and money. It invites nations, companies and individuals to document damages and losses, but does not establish a system for recovering the money. Kuwaiti U.N. Ambassador Mohammad A. Abulhasan estimated that Iraq has less than $800 million in assets in the United States. Shortly after the invasion, many nations, including the United States, froze both Iraqi and Kuwaiti assets. The resolution further demands that Iraq stop taking hostages and ``mistreating and oppressing Kuwaiti and third-state nationals.'' It invites nations to collect information on abuses of civilians contrary to the Fourth Geneva Convention of 1949. The convention, which Iraq signed, protects the rights of civilians in wartime or in military-occupied territory, outlawing summary execution, torture, deportations and hostage-taking. Finally, the draft resolution says Iraq must allow the immediate provision of food, water and basic services to diplomats and foreigners in missions in Kuwait City. After Saddam annexed Kuwait, making it Iraq's 19th province, he ordered the missions moved to Baghdad. He surrounded them with troops and cut off services such as water and electricity. The U.S., British and French embassies are the last Western holdouts. At least 210,000 U.S. troops and another 100,000 from other nations have been deployed in the gulf against Iraq's estimated 460,000 soldiers stationed in southern Iraq and Kuwait. But Gorbachev reiterated Saturday that military might should not be used to force Iraq from Kuwait. ``We shouldn't rush in a direction of the conflict that leads to military methods of solution,'' Gorbachev said at a joint press conference in Madrid with Spanish Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez. The Soviet leader, on a three-day visit to Spain, indicated Iraq might be softening its hard-line position on the gulf crisis. ``In recent days, there have been signals from the Iraqi leadership that ... the solution of problems cannot be achieved through ultimatums,'' Gorbachev said. He added that ``the coming days might bring some clarification.'' The French television network La Cinq reported Friday that Saddam sent the French and Soviet leaders letters offering to discuss Middle East problems. It said Saddam told the two leaders he was open ``to all ideas'' in resolving the gulf crisis. French officials have denied knowledge of any such letters. Gorbachev travels to Paris Sunday for a 24-hour visit that includes talks with French President Francois Mitterrand. The gulf crisis was expected to top the agenda. French officials on Saturday received the final go-ahead from Iraqi officials for the freedom flight of most French nationals held in Iraq. An Iraqi Airways jumbo jet was to carry the Frenchmen home late Sunday. Besides the seven that Iraq has balked at freeing, French Embassy sources in Baghdad said 19 citizens had not signed up for the departure. They said efforts were under way to locate them. Iraq has refused to allow most Western men to leave Iraq and Kuwait, and many are being held at strategic installations to deter a Western attack. Iraq's National Assembly said Tuesday that French citizens would be allowed to leave. Baghdad said the gesture was in appreciation for Mitterrand's statements suggesting that any solution of the gulf crisis be linked to a solution of the Israel-Palestinian problem. Western analysts, however, have interpreted Saddam's move as an effort to divide the world alliance against him. To guard against such divisions, President Bush on Saturday called Italian Premier Giulio Andreotti, who was playing host to the first summit of the 12-nation European Community since Iraq's invasion. Bush asked Andreotti and the other leaders to hang together in their stand against Iraq. A British official said Saddam should not be lulled into believing there might be a break in solidarity. ``We are solid and he is failing,'' said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: Bolivia Halts Extradition of Drug Suspects Pending New Treaty
DOC.TEXT:
Bolivia will stop extraditing suspected drug traffickers to the United States unless an extradition treaty is expanded to include drug violations, a government official said Saturday. ``We have no plans for further arrests and extraditions to the United States of Bolivian citizens without an extradition treaty,'' said Gen. Lucio Anez, commander of an special anti-drug force. President Jaime Paz Zamora's administration was criticized by opposition parties and others after Thursday's extradition of Erlan Echeverria, who has been indicted on drug-trafficking and other charges by a federal grand jury in Miami. ``Echeverria has been the last,'' said Anez, calling the extradition ``a political decision.'' He said there is ``a list of extraditables,'' or suspected drug dealers, wanted for trial in the United States. He did not elaborate. Bolivia, one of the top coco leaf-growing areas along with Peru and Colombia, has a 89-year-old general extradition treaty with the United States, but it does not include drug trafficking among the extraditable charges. President Bush and Paz Zamora agreed to a new treaty in Washington in May, but the document has not been signed. Anez said the new treaty ``is under discussion,'' but he did not give further details. U.S. officials have praised increased coca leaf eradication efforts in Bolivia, where cocaine production has risen following crackdowns on major cartels in neighboring Colombia. Earlier this year, Bernard Aronson, U.S. assistant secretary of state for Latin American affairs, estimated at least 99,000 acres of coca crops are growing in Bolivia.
Echeverria, who was handed over to U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration agents, was a close aide to Col. Luis Arce Gomez, an interior minister under Bolivia's former military regime who was extradited to the United States last year. Arce Gomez - dubbed the ``minister of cocaine'' by DEA officials - is presently jailed near Miami awaiting trial. Paz Zamora ordered the extradition of Arce Gomez, although he still faces charges in Bolivia for human rights violations under the regime of Gen. Luis Garcia Meza. Colombian President Cesar Gaviria in September modified his nation's year-old extradition policy with a pledge that suspected cocaine traffickers who surrender to Colombian authorities will not be extradited. Gaviria, however, said the decision does not apply to those captured by police. Colombia, the main supplier of cocaine to the United States, has extradited several suspected top-level traffickers. But Pablo Escobar, head of the Medellin cartel, remains free. The cartel, named for the Colombian city where much of its activity is based, has demanded an end to the extraditions. Officials in Colombia blame the cartel for more than 500 deaths this year, including the assassinations of three presidential candidates.

DOC.HEAD: Tragedy Eclipses Seven-Race Breeders' Cup
LaserPhotos NY35,NY36,NY37
DOC.TEXT: Tragedy eclipsed the Breeders' Cup on Saturday with the deaths of two horses and the injuries of two toppled jockeys. A 3-year-old filly named Go for Wand, fighting to keep the lead in the Distaff, snapped her right front ankle and crashed to the track just a stride inside the sixteenth pole. Go For Wand was later destroyed behind screens to shield the crowd from her distress. Jockey Randy Romero, who took a heavy tumble, was removed from the track in an ambulance, but returned later to ride in the $3 million Classic. Bayakoa went on to win her second straight Distaff and was greeted in the winner's circle by her tearful trainer, Ron McAnally. ``I can't cope with this,'' McAnally said. ``It's like my wife said, `They give their lives for our enjoyment.' '' A horse named Mr. Nickerson dropped dead on the turn during the running of the Sprint. No cause of death was immediately determined. Shaker Knit fell over Mr. Nickerson, but escaped serious injury. Chris Antley, who was aboard Shaker Knit, suffered a broken right collarbone. Some blamed the deaths of the horses on the track. Others blamed the roughness of the sport itself. The day ended with Unbridled bursting between horses about 50 yards from the wire to win the Classic, the world's richest horse race.

DOC.HEAD: HONOLULU: supported passed?
DOC.TEXT: PRESIDENT BUSH: Hey listen, that shows that I don't like everything in the package. I mean, if I were all that enthusiastic about it you'd have seen more Republicans voting for it. So nobody got it exactly the way he or she wanted. But that's - now it's behind us. As soon as I sign it, that's behind us. And I hope it will have the effect of bringing interest rates down. But the philosophy of holding the line on spending and holding the line on taxes is my philosophy. And I will be clearly advocating that. Q: What kind of message will you use now, then, to replace your ``no new taxes'' pledge? You know, everybody was very accustomed to that, all the Republicans. And I just want to know what slogan or rallying cry - PRESIDENT BUSH: Well, let me be clear, I'm not in favor of new taxes. I'll repeat that over and over and over again. And this one compromise that - where we begrudgingly had to accept revenues, revenue increases, is the exception that proves the rule. That's the way I'll handle it. Q: The exception that proves what rule? PRESIDENT BUSH: The rule that I'm strongly opposed to raising taxes on the American people and that we ought to do a better job of controlling spending. And I think we can. And so that's - that's the message. It's loud and clear. Q: Will you reinstate today your ``no new taxes'' pledge, perhaps ``no new new taxes?'' Do you think - remember after '86 that the Congress passed a resolution saying they wouldn't tamper with it for five years. Do you think now the line should be drawn again - and having made this compromise, you should now hold the line on taxes again? PRESIDENT BUSH: Absolutely going to hold the line on taxes, and hopefully, the big thing is to hold the line on spending so nobody'll come up and try to propose new taxes. But I noticed one of the - one of the Democratic leaders said yesterday, well, he wants to raise income tax rates. And he's going to have a whale of a fight on it. This was a one-time compromise. Yeah? Q: Sir, you really don't seem very enthusiastic about this budget deal. You don't seem euphoric, after all you and the others have been through. PRESIDENT BUSH: That's right. Q: And I might - well, I might note - PRESIDENT BUSH: You got it. Q: - that it doesn't appear to meet your own objectives. You've been insisting on a $500 billion deficit-reduction target, now only $490 billion. Plus, I understand the deal is based on rosy economic assumptions, over which there is much disagreement. How do you feel? PRESIDENT BUSH: I feel that it's been a long, arduous battle. And I feel that every once in a while the president has to do something he doesn't like, and that is to compromise. And I did that here. And, so, I'm glad it's over. And I have to say that the hours that the Democratic leaders and the Republican leaders spent working this problem have just been exhausting for everybody, including me, although they did much more of the work. So I'm glad it's behind us. And I feel good that it's behind us, but I can't be euphoric about every provision in this bill. I am very encouraged about the enforcement provisions, because they are strong. And no guy can go out and put in a - put in a new program without the offset. The guarantees of enforcement are strong, and I'm going to do my level best to see that they stay strong. So, I think - you're trying to describe mood. I'm pleased it's behind us and I will be out vigorously campaigning on the campaign trail for more Republicans who feel as I do about holding the line on taxes and about spending. And we have a difference of opinion. You have more people that wanted to increase - on the Democratic side - these permissive spending programs. So the philosophy, the fundamental philosophical underpinning - yeah, I haven't changed my view on that. And I'm sure the liberal Democrats haven't either, but we'll take that case to the American people.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
President Says Budget Distasteful, But `Good Medicine For The Economy'
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Adds 7 grafs of elaboration and additional quotes
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Saturday that, as much as higher taxes make him want to gag, he will sign a deficit restraining budget deal because it is ``good medicine for the economy.'' peaking to reporters minutes after the Senate gave final legislative approval to the five-year deal, Bush said he did not expect Republican candidates to say they like the package as they near Election Day Nov. 6. ``A lot of the members feel as I do, they were gagging on certain provisions,'' he said. ``But I'm glad that it's passed. ``Parts of it are good,'' he said. ``No, I can't say this is the best thing that's happened to us since sliced bread or the elimination of broccoli.'' But, he said, ``I am convinced this is good medicine for the economy.'' As to how the defection of many Republican members of Congress reflected on his leadership, he said, ``If I were all that enthusiastic about it (the budget package) you'd have seen more Republicans voting for it. ``Now that's behind us, as soon as I sign it,'' he continued, ``and I hope it will help bring interest rates down.'' On another matter, Bush said he U.S. military buildup in the Persian Gulf is continuing, but declined to say whether it would result in additional 100,000 troops being sent as widely reported last week. Asked about the prospects for offensive military action, Bush declined to state the reason for the additional troops, but said, ``The purpose is to make clear to (Iraqi President) Saddam Hussein that his aggression will not stand.'' He said he will make further decisions after consulting with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and other top advisers after his return to Washington on Monday. Asked whether Saddam is softening his position, Bush said, ``As he sees the U.S. forces moving,'' in conjunction with other nations' forces, ``he has taken another look, because we are deadly serious.'' Bush reiterated that any conditional withdrawal by Saddam from Kuwait ``is unacceptable.'' He said he also spoke Saturday to Egypt's President Hosni Mubarak about the Middle East situation, and that Mubarak also was firm on unconditional withdrawal. On other subjects, Bush: -Said he plans to sign the sweeping Clean Air Act just passed by Congress. -Dismissed as ``pure unadulterated gossip'' reports that various members of his Cabinet and top staff would be leaving or changing jobs. ``Not that I've ever heard of,'' he said. He called it ``sheer mischief'' and asked, ``Who writes this stuff?'' -Refused to say whether he wanted Ed Rollins, a GOP political strategist and co-chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee, to be dismissed because he recommended that Republican congressional candidates feel free to distance themselves from the president's decision to compromise on taxes for the sake of getting a budget agreement. He said that talking about such matters would divert him from more important business. ``I get diverted if you try to get me into some little staff matter,'' he told reporters. The president, taking an approach he has voiced on the campaign trail in recent days, said the budget agreement ``represents corrective action on a pattern of federal spending gone out of control.'' Bush said he did not expect Republicans, many of whom voted against him on the budget, to like it or try to sell all aspects of it when campaigning. ``There are certain things in it that I can strongly advocate. There are some things in it that I had to gag and digest.
