And so that's the approach I'm going to be taking, and I expect everyone else will too,'' he said when asked whether he would attack the Democrats as architects of the package. Despite the tax increases in the bill, he said, ``one of the things I'm glad on is obviously we've held the line on income tax rates'' against Democratic pressure to hike them higher. ``All political points of view have sacrificed'' to get the agreement, he said. However, he praised the enforcement measures in the package. On the Persian Gulf, Bush was asked if there appeared a chance for a negotiated settlement of the standoff with Saddam. Bush reiterated there is nothing to negotiate and that Iraq should comply with the United Nations resolution demanding Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait and restoration of the Kuwaiti government. ``I'm hopeful there will be a peaceful solution to this question, but there can be no preconditions,'' he said. Further, Bush said it appeared the U.N. economic sanctions were having an effect and that Saddam was taking note of the massive multinational military force deployed against him.

DOC.HEAD: HONOLULU: American people.
DOC.TEXT: Q: Can you really tell the American people, with all your heart, that this is a good deal? PRESIDENT BUSH: Parts of it are good. No, I can't say this is the best thing that's happened to us since sliced bread or the elimination of broccoli. It is - it's got some good things in it. But if it were doing it my way, or the Republican leader in the Senate's way, or the Republican leader in the House's way, it would be very, very different. But I think it is good that we have a $490 billion - I'd like to have seen $500 billion - but it's a lot of money, $490 billion enforceable deficit-reduction program. And that part, that overall part I am enthusiastic about. But how we got it, I reserve the right to be as critical as the next person on that. Q: Mr. President, do you think it was proper for the Republican Congressional Campaign Committee to recommend that the party's candidates distance themselves from the president on this? PRESIDENT BUSH: Oh, I want everybody to be right with me on everything I do. Q: Is the architect of that strategy, Ed Rollins, history as far as you're concerned? PRESIDENT BUSH: That is inside the beltway - I know how people love that. They thrive on it. I don't. And you know, ever since I got out around the country not one person has sidled up to me and asked me about that particular incident. And I'm going to keep my sights set on the big picture and not accommodate you when you want me to go back into that. I understand it - I understand it because people thrive - what was that Laurie? Q: Is he out? Is he out? PRESIDENT BUSH: I'm not discussing it, because we'd divert me from the major goal which is to elect more Republicans to agree that - as I do, hold the line on taxes and spending, get people back to work in this country, by getting interest rates down, and empowering people not programs and bureaucrats. So it - I get diverted if you go try to get me into some little staff matter. Q: Conspicuously missing from that list of leaders that you recited, Mr. President, was the name of Newt Gingrich. Some people have suggested that you could have gotten a better deal if he had not led the Republican revolt a couple of weeks ago. Do you think that he should remain in his leadership position because of his actions?
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Officer Reassigned After Paddling Allegations
DOC.TEXT: A police officer accused of paddling two high school students for skipping school has been reassigned, pending an investigation. Police say Ronald C. Flanagan, a patrol officer in the department's southwest division, will work in a desk job until the investigation is concluded, a spokesman said Friday. Two 16-year-old students at Kimball High School alleged that Flanagan struck them each five times Wednesday morning with a paddle. The students said the paddlings occurred in a school office after they were found wandering on a nearby street. Dallas police do not have authority to paddle students, said police spokesman Ed Spencer. Flanagan, 26, has an unlisted telephone number and could not be reached for comment Saturday. School district policy prohibits non-school personnel from administering corporal punishment, said Kimball principal Roosevelt Vaughn.

DOC.HEAD: Publisher of Ojai Valley News Resigns to Join Beacon
DOC.TEXT: Darrow ``Duke'' Tully, editor and publisher of the Ojai Valley News, is resigning to become president, publisher and chief executive officer of Beacon Communications, the newspaper said Saturday. Tully also is resigning as supervisor for other Wick Communications newspapers. The resignation is effective Jan. 11, 1991, the Ojai Valley News said. Walter Wick, president of Wick Communications, said a replacement had yet to be selected. Beacon, based in Acton, Mass., publishes 16 newspapers in the Boston area with a combined circulation of 150,000. It is a wholly owned subsidiary of Chronicle Publishing Co. of San Francisco. Tully became publisher of the Ojai Valley News in August 1987. During his tenure, the paper expanded its publication to three times a week in this town, 70 miles northwest of Los Angeles. Previously, he was publisher of the Phoenix Gazette and the Arizona Republic. He resigned in 1985 after admitting he fabricated a heroic military record that included service in Vietnam and Korea. Tully joined Wick Communications as editor and publisher of The Williston (N.D.) Herald.

DOC.HEAD: Nationwide Protests Against New Federal Tax Hikes, Spending
With AM-Congress Rdp Bjt
By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: Demonstrators protesting higher taxes and government spending rallied Saturday in cities from Georgia to North Dakota to voice their displeasure about the deficit-reduction package approved by Congress. Outside Chicago's federal plaza, some of the more than 100 demonstrators waved brooms and carried signs reading ``Time for a Clean Sweep'' of lawmakers endorsing higher taxes. ``Congress should cut its own budget,'' declared Jordan Rosner, 26, of Chicago. About 70 demonstrators also carried signs protesting federal spending policies at a rally in Lafayette Park across the street from the White House. President Bush was thousands of miles away in Hawaii. The nationwide protest was organized by the Council for Citizens Against Government Waste, a Washington-based coalition endorsing limited government spending and a hold on federal taxes. The ``Taxpayer Action Day'' was planned for more than 160 cities Saturday, as Congress gave final approval to a deficit-reduction measure that raises taxes by $137 billion. At many demonstrations, however, the turnouts were less than what had been anticipated. In Bismarck, N.D., about 50 people gathered at the state capitol steps to vent their anger at Congress and at a federal budget they said doesn't solve the country's financial problems. ``A popular theme these days is to throw all the rascals out,'' said John Gosbee, an organizer of the rally. He chided Congress for increasing the gasoline tax by a nickel at a time of soaring gasoline prices. In Georgia, protesters sarcastically mimicked Bush's 1988 campaign pledge not to raise taxes. ``President Bush, read our lips: No new taxes,'' they shouted at several of the rallies. Only about 20 people gathered in the tax protest outside the Georgia Capitol in Atlanta. Rob Schuler, president of the Georgia Taxpayers Action Committee, blamed the poor turnout on competition from Georgia Tech's homecoming game against Duke University. The Citizens Against Government Waste sponsored a rally at the state capitol in Austin, Texas, and about 200 protesters gathered in downtown Dallas, some carrying signs, ``Throw the spenders out of office.'' ``It's going to take a major revolution in American politics to change the system, to change the way we are headed,'' said Mike Ryan, Dallas County chairman for Taxpayers Action Day. Rallies also were held in a number of other Texas cities, including San Antonio and Houston. The demonstrations came as Newsweek magazine released the results of a poll by the Gallup Organization showing Bush had slipped to the lowest approval rating of his presidency. The poll showed 48 percent of the people interviewed approved of Bush's handling of his job, down from 57 percent on Oct. 19.

DOC.HEAD: Xavier Cugat, Big Band Leader, Dead At 90
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, ````Coogie,'' as ...' to FIX spelling of club to Cocoanut Grove sted Coconut; SUBS 9th, `That was..' to locate club in Los Angeles sted Hollywood
DOC.TEXT: Xavier Cugat, the Spanish-born band leader who introduced the tropical beat of the rumba to millions of Americans, died Saturday. He was 90. Cugat died of heart failure in a Barcelona hospital, doctors Jorge Rius and Jaime Pujadas said in a statement. He had checked into the hospital Oct. 8 with a lung infection and failure of his left ventricle. ``Coogie,'' as he became known to millions of Americans and Europeans, became a star in the early 1930s playing Latin dance music at the Cocoanut Grove club in Los Angeles and later at the Waldorf Astoria in New York. Cugat and his band, the Gigolos, were featured in several popular Hollywood movies in the 1940s and 1950s. Born Jan. 1, 1900, in San Cugat del Valles near Barcelona, Cugat began as a violinist at age 12 with the Havana Symphony in Cuba, where his parents moved when he was 4 to escape political persecution. He had first appeared with the Cuban orchestra six years earlier as a guest performer. Later, the 12-year-old musician, with his violin under his arm and ``not a penny in my pocket,'' went to the United States. He became a U.S. citizen three years later. Unable to find much work as a classical musician, he made his way to Hollywood, where he drew caricatures of movie stars for the Los Angeles Times. Rudolf Valentino told Cugat that the actor had to dance the tango in a silent film and asked the musician to put together a band to accompany him. That was the beginning of Cugat and his Gigolos. Thanks to Valentino, they got an engagement at the legendary Cocoanut Grove in Los Angeles' Ambassador Hotel. That engagement led to others at Al Capone's Chez Paris in Chicago, the Hotel Chase in St. Louis and more than a decade at New York's Waldorf Astoria. Cugat's career as a band leader stretched from the big band era in the 1940s to the 1960s. He played the violin and directed the band with his bow. ``I learned very early that everyone in the United States specialized in something,'' Cugat explained in a 1986 interview, ``so I decided to specialize in tropical music - we called it the rumba abierta then. Today they call it salsa, but it's all basically the same thing.'' His splashy, tropical Hollywood films like ``Neptune's Daughter,'' in which he starred with Esther Williams and Red Skelton in 1949, made his name a household word. Cugat had a history of heart ailments and high blood pressure. He was hospitalized in Los Angeles before he gave up his band and returned to Spain in 1978. But despite further heart problems and hospitalization, he formed a new 16-piece band at the age of 86 and began touring Spain. Cugat was married and divorced five times. His wives were Cuban Rita Montaner, Mexican Carmen Castillo, Chicago-born Lorraine Allen, Brooklyn-born Abbe Lane and Spaniard Charo Baeza, known professionally as Charo. ``If I had it to do all over, I'd marry the same ones,'' he said. ``We always divorced for our careers. You cannot play the violin in Philadelphia when your wife is in Rome making a movie with Marcelo Mastroianni.'' Cugat had no children but raised dogs and wrote two books - ``I, Cugat'' and ``My Wives.''

DOC.HEAD: HONOLULU: his actions?
DOC.TEXT: PRESIDENT BUSH: Remember the - remember, what was the give and take in the debate when Ronald Reagan said, ``There you go again, trying to get me caught up in something devisive.'' Newt Gingrich stood out there in the White House - I'm not sure you were there that day - and strongly endorsed Republican unity, and that's exactly what should happen. So please don't ask me to relive the agony of a budget agreement that I am glad is signed and is now behind us. Yes? MR. : (Inaudible) - final question. Q: Well, do you feel that the Republican Party has been badly hurt by this - PRESIDENT BUSH: No. Q: And aren't you sorry that - PRESIDENT BUSH: Never - (inaudible). Q: - and aren't you sorry that you couldn't have gotten more Republican votes? PRESIDENT BUSH: Not particularly sorry - not gotten votes, because a lot of the members feel as I do. They were gagging on certain provisions. But glad that it's passed. And I think if the bill this - this compromise had been perfect from a Republican side you'd have seen - obviously had many, many more votes. So I think those that didn't vote against it on both sides had problems with it. Some on the Democratic side were saying, ``We want to raise income tax rates on the American people more''. That's literally what they wanted to do. They called it ``soak the rich''. But, what they meant was when that bill that they passed in the Congress for that indexing went after every working man and woman in this country. And that's the old tax and spend view. And some of them didn't feel it went far enough. Some on our side didn't like anything to do with revenues. That's more along my line of thinking. So I think it - I think that's history now, but I have no rancor about it. I'm just glad it's passed, I wish it had been passed when we had the - the summit agreement and we'd have been much further along. But I don't - and back to your first part of your question, no, I sense strong enthusiasm for Republican candidates. And I think we've been caught up in a bit of inside smoke screen here. But let's see now how we do. I'm going to be out there working my heart out for Republican candidates who feel as I do, that we ought to hold the line on taxes and we ought to curtail spending. Q: Are we (headed for?) a recession? PRESIDENT BUSH: I hope - the economy's sluggish. And there's no question about that. And I am convinced, whether I like every paragraph of this or not, that this is good medicine for the economy, particularly if the Federal Reserve Board now follows up with lowering interest rates. You know, that is what's needed and I'm not here to - to do anything other than to state that - that principle. But I listen carefully to Alan Greenspan's testimony and I was - I was encouraged that interest rates might come down. Better than any program is getting these rates down so economic growth gets - gets stimulated. Q: You said you were going to review the appropriations. Has that process begun, and are you certain that the appropriations bills that have been passed are not raising spending levels at the same time that you're claiming to have cut some and - for deficit reduction? PRESIDENT BUSH: No, I'm not sure of that, Jessica. And I - the process is under way, of course. But I'm not certain that there is (sic) no breaches of the spending goals. Yeah? Q: Sir, if I could just switch to the Gulf - PRESIDENT BUSH: A couple more and then I've got to go. We've got a very interesting meeting with these Pacific chiefs of state. It's a fascinating and long overdue meeting and I'm learning from them, and I am giving them as best I can right from the shoulder, the American view, the importance of the Pacific. And I - I know that given the budget summit at some and the interest that - that that has stimulated, that attention hasn't been focused elsewhere. But this is - this is a very important meeting, and I'd say historic - with these small countries, but all friendly to the United States, and all very important to the United States. So I've got to get back down there in just a minute. Did I cut you off, Sandy? Q: No, sir. PRESIDENT BUSH: You've got a follow up then? Q: Just switch to the gulf crisis for a moment. Secretary Cheney indicates we may send as many as 100,000 new troops in and a lot more tanks. What's the purpose, sir, if it's not to - to take offensive action and get engaged in combat with Iraq? PRESIDENT BUSH: Hold it, just a minute. (Chuckles.) Power outage here. We have not announced what we are going to do in terms of additional troops. We have been still - as everybody around the world knows - still moving forces. The purpose is to make clear to Saddam Hussein that his aggression will not stand. And what I do in the future will be determined after I have a discussion with Dick Cheney and the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs, General Scowcroft, and Secretary Baker, which I expect we'll be doing, looking for help with Brent when we get back. And maybe we'll have more to say about that then. But I believe - I believe a couple of things on this. One, I think Saddam Hussein really felt that nobody was going to move against his aggression in Kuwait. I also believe that he really intended to threaten Saudi Arabia, else why did he move all his armor south to the Saudi border? I think as he sees the US forces moving in conjunction with many Arab country forces, in conjunction with many European country forces in land and on the sea, that he's taken another look. Because we are deadly serious. And I want to see these economic sanctions work. I - I was - I'm not too good at the emotional side of it, but when you talk to the parents of these - and spouses of our kids half way around the world, it makes a real impact on you. Remember when I got off the plane at the marine base and they - they were saying, ``Take care of my husband'', and yet, ``We back you 100 percent''. So, there's - I don't think that's a conflict exactly, but I want to take care of every young man and woman that's serving the United States, half way around the world. But they want, and I want to see that Saddam's aggression is unrewarded and indeed repudiated. And so the moving of US force up to now has sent a strong signal to him. We have the finest, most highly motivated, best trained, best equipped armed forces in the world. And they're right there. They're right there in substantial numbers, land, air, and sea. Now, Mr. Saddam Hussein, get out of Kuwait with no condition. And this talk of some condition, that is unacceptable not just to the United States, but to the other countries around the world. I just got off the phone talking to - (audio break) - it is encouraging. I am told that he now sees that he's up against a substantial force that clearly could prevail in any battle. And so I'm hopeful that there will be a peaceful solution to this question. But there can be no preconditions. There can be no - there can be no rewarding of aggression. Yeah?
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: PRECEDE BATAVIA, N.Y.
Gun Salute, Flag Raising Marks Hostage's Birthday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with birthday activities in Lorain, Ohio. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Lebanon-Hostages
DOC.TEXT: The birthplace of hostage Terry Anderson marked the hostage's 43rd birthday Saturday with a flag raising, a gun salute and two renditions of ``Happy Birthday.'' About 40 people, including 12 of Anderson's cousins, turned out at City Hall for the gun salute and flag ceremony, then walked to a park to join 500 others. Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, was abducted by Moslem extremists in Beirut on March 16, 1985. He is the longest-held of the 13 Western hostages in Lebanon. Anderson was born in Lorain and grew up in Batavia, N.Y., where supporters decided against cake and singing to mark his birthday because of the crisis in the Persian Gulf. ``This year because of the new crisis it just seemed inappropriate,'' said Anne Zickl, an organizer of past celebrations for Anderson in Batavia. In Lorain, Anderson's cousins, including the Rev. Edward Jones Jr. of San Mateo, Calif., placed a large yellow ribbon on the City Hall flagpole in Anderson's memory. The group then walked to nearby Veterans Memorial Park and joined 500 people gathered for the city's annual Halloween parade. The crowd sang ``Happy Birthday.'' The band from Southview High School, near Anderson's birthplace, played the song again. ``We wanted to get it real loud the second time,'' LaVriha said. He read the crowd a letter from Anderson's sister, Peggy Say. She thanked Lorain residents for their support of Anderson and expressed hope for a prompt resolution of his ordeal. ``My thoughts and prayers are with you as we mark another birthday for Terry Anderson - his sixth in captivity,'' she wrote. In years past in Batavia, a town of about 16,000 people 35 miles east of Buffalo, residents gathered at a mall to eat birthday cake, listen to music and sing ``Happy Birthday'' for Anderson. No organized events were held Saturday. The threat of war between the United States and Iraq over Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait made this year's events for Anderson more solemn, organizers said. A bust of Anderson sculpted by artist Louis Dlugosz was placed Friday in Batavia's City Hall, alongside a scrapbook of local events held in Anderson's honor over the past six years. Residents signed the scrapbook as they viewed the bust at City Hall, where they picked up small yellow ribbons and bumper stickers reading ``Bring our hostages home from Lebanon.'' A group called the ``Friends of Terry Anderson'' held a spiritual service Wednesday. A mass Sunday was to be dedicated to Anderson and other hostages in Lebanon.

DOC.HEAD: Two Suspects In Assassination Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to ADD police attribution on shootout, government statement linking suspects to Jihad group, sources saying others involved, MINOR EDITING. Picks up 12th graf pvs, `Ministry sources...'
DOC.TEXT: Police shot and killed two men Saturday, and security sources said the victims were Moslem extremists who took part in the assassination of the parliamentary speaker earlier this month. A third suspect and two policemen were wounded in the afternoon shootout at Cairo University, police said. A fourth suspect was captured by police, the sources said. Police were led to the men by a Moslem extremist, arrested Wednesday, who confessed to particating in the slaying Oct. 12 of Parliament Speaker Rifaat el-Mahgoub, his driver and bodyguards, the sources said. As speaker of the People's Assembly, el-Mahgoub was second in line to the presidency after President Hosni Mubarak. A government statement issued late Saturday said the suspects are members of the Jihad group, an underground Moslem extremist organization linked to the Oct. 6, 1981, assassination of President Anwar Sadat. The group is also believed responsible for riots after the Sadat slaying in the southern city of Assiut which left 87 people dead and 156 injured, including many policemen. The extremists were trying to overthrow the secular government and establish a theocratic regime. But security sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said some of the suspects belonged to Salvation From Hell, an extremist group that tried in 1987 to assassinate two former interior ministers and a journalist close to Mubarak. Since el-Mahgoub's assassination, authorities have detained more than 1,000 people - mostly Iraqis or Palestinians - for questioning. The government suspected that agents sent by Iraq killed the speaker, possibly in league with Egyptian Moslem extremists, to punish Egypt for leading Arab opposition to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Security sources only recently began concentrating on Islamic militants after concluding that bombs found where el-Mahgoub was shot were similar to those used by fundamentalists in previous attacks. One government source said the arrested suspect led police Friday to a hideout, where they captured five men he had identified as accomplices and weapons and ammunition similar to those used in the Oct. 12 ambush. Police said the arrested suspects set up a meeting at the university with other suspects, and the police set a trap. ``They had pistols,'' an officer said of the suspects. ``They opened fire on the forces. ... The forces exchanged fire with them. There were only slight injuries among the forces.'' Ministry sources said the suspect detained Wednesday was among those arrested after the attempted 1987 assassinaion of former Interior Minister Hassan Abu-Basha. The man escaped during his trial, the sources said. They said the hideout where the five men were arrested Friday night was an apartment in a poor, crowded neighborhood in the Giza district southwest of Cairo, where many Moslem fundamentalists live. Shortly before the shooting Saturday, Egypt's prosecutor-general banned local publication of information related to developments in Mahgoub's killing.

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Threatened to Punch President Sentenced to 21 Months
DOC.TEXT: A man convicted of threatening to punch President Bush in frustration over a tuition battle with a vocational school was sentenced to 21 months in prison. Eugene R. Hains, 43, was sentenced Friday and ordered to undergo psychiatric treatment at a federal prison in Butner, N.C. Hains was convicted Aug. 29 of threatening the president. He had faced a maximum penalty of five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. Hains was upset over a dispute involving a Southern California vocational school, where he paid tuition with his veteran's benefits. After he withdrew from a course, he fought with school administrators for return of his fees. He sought government help. In a letter to a Los Angeles television station's consumer advocate, Hains threatened to ``come after'' the president if his demands were not met. The letter was turned over to the Secret Service. When an agent questioned Hains about the letter in April, Hains told the agent he would ``punch (Bush's) lights out'' if he ever got close to him. Hains' attorney, Robert Leen, characterized his client's statements as ``ramblings of a frustrated citizen.''

DOC.HEAD: HONOLULU: aggression. Yeah?
DOC.TEXT: Q: There are two points to my question. There are some people who are saying that the U.S. continues to send in even more troops because the U.S. has underestimated the Iraqi troop strength. That, coupled with yesterday apparently in Spain, President Gorbachev apparently said he notes a softening on the position of Saddam Hussein. Do you have any reason to believe there has been a softening? Has Mr. Gorbachev told you something you'd like to share with us? Has that softening manifested itself in any way? PRESIDENT BUSH: I have not noticed a softening but I've heard more - you know, kind of little threads of, talk of, quote, ``negotiation'', unquote. That's all. I mean, maybe that's what President Gorbachev is talking about, but he has not shared with me any feeling of a softening of - of public opinion. But, what was the first part? I didn't - I'm afraid I didn't - Q: Has the U.S. underestimated, perhaps, the troop strength of the Iraqis? Is that why we're continuing to send in more troops? PRESIDENT BUSH: No. I think it's true that Saddam Hussein beefed up his armor and his forces in Kuwait from the original deployment; he then has stepped that up by pouring more armor in. I'll never forget the day when he said, ``Well, we're taking our people out of Kuwait.'' And they had one forlorn-looking soldier in the back of the truck waving goodbye, the truck heading north, and then he had all his armor moving south. And so it was a sheer fraud. And he moved a heck of a lot of armor down against the Saudis. And so I - I'd leave it there, but I think that when you see a lot of force there, why, the free world and those of us that are allied together are going to say, ``Wait a minute, we're not going to - we're going to do what we've got to do to protect American life, or Egyptian life'', or in this instance, Syrian life, or Saudi life. And that's why you're seeing a substantial movement of U.S. force. And forces of other countries. I keep repeating this because it's a very important point. It is not the United States versus Saddam Hussein, it is the United States, big majorities in the Arab world, and the United Nations versus Saddam Hussein. And that point - I keep making it, because he is still trying to - trying to divide and weaken this strong coalition. And he's failing. He is failing miserably because all these countries are united against his brutal aggression. Yeah, Rita, and then Jessie. I've - I'm recanting because that wasn't very kind. Go ahead. Q: Just back on the budget for a minute. What do you think it says about your leadership and your ability to lead the party that you couldn't get more Republicans to stay with you and vote with you on this very important issue of the budget? PRESIDENT BUSH: I learned a lot from Ronald Reagan, with whom I worked closely, and watched, and learned. And in 19 - what was it, '82? When we had that big tax bill, I think we got fewer votes than we did today, and he went right out and did beautifully what he - what he felt in his heart he should do and say, ``Look, I'm against increasing taxes and the American people know this.'' And he went right on about his business and that agreement brought interest rates down, and we all went forth and said, ``Wait a minute, every once in a while when you don't control Congress you don't get to do it exactly your way.'' And so I understand Republicans defecting from a package that they don't like, that a president, to make something happen, once in a great while, has to make a significant compromise. And that's what I did, and I think the American people understand that. They know that I'm trying pretty hard, and they know that I have their interest at stake when I want to see interest rates down, and more jobs for the working man and woman in this country, and that's the way I'd handle that one. Now, the last one, Jessica, and then I am leaving. Q: Well, there's Conventional Wisdom, and Periscope, and other information from our weeklies that suggest there's a cabinet shakeup in all of that, that the budget director's going to be going to a financial firm, that the chief of staff will be going to the campaign trail, that Skinner will come to the budget, all kinds of things. Anybody else resign? Or retiring? PRESIDENT BUSH: Jessica, you know something, I don't know who writes these columns - Periscope. I mean, you talk about sheer mischief and the ones I've seen - you go back and look at them. Somebody ought to go - not you all, you do your job asking questions. So I wish I were in the case to ask every - all the knowledgeable people here, who writes this stuff? I mean, if there's all that going on, I don't know about it. No! We - our cabinet - Q: (Inaudible.) PRESIDENT BUSH: Not that I've ever heard of, and maybe I'd be the last to know. But I don't think so. I think I'd be the first to know, and I'd know it way ahea of Periscope, whoever he is, whoever she may be. And it is pure unadulterated gossip that comes out of these columns. It is not serious coverage. So - so, you know I can't - I haven't even seen this. I guess they didn't dare show it to me because I've been a little irritable lately trying to get this job done. But - I'm going to finish my diatribe here. Huh? Q: Why would you be irritable? PRESIDENT BUSH: Things aren't going exactly the way I want them done. I wish we could have got this deficit down without touching revenue. I wish that we could have got it done without all this inside the beltway furor. Because it's diverted me from major things - major objectives. Q: Do you feel abandoned by Republicans - (inaudible)? PRESIDENT BUSH: No, no, no. I feel happy about Republicans. I'm glad this is behind us. And I wish we had more of them. No matter what little philosophical wing of the party they're from, more of them, all of them would be better than what I face when I try to get stuff done from the Democrats. I mean, that's what it's all about. Q: (Inaudible) - strategists, aides to Clayton Williams in Texas who say he's losing points because you've come to Texas and you're campaigning for him. How do you feel about that? PRESIDENT BUSH: I feel they're lying. (Laughter.) Otherwise, why has he invited me back? And I feel that my son, who I talk to who talked to somebody high up, tells me that the - Williams is doing very well. So please go to Texas and find out, and take a look at how - whether the President can help a candidate in Texas or not. Please don't get it from some ``Periscope'', if I might - now wait just a minute here. I have a major national announcement here. Linda? Sorry. No, I'm glad to be in the place from whence you cometh. And I might say, let me use this, seriously, to thank the people in Honolulu - your home, I believe - that - for this wonderful hospitality. And again, I want to end on a nonpartisan note. I - I hope that you will record that this is a very important meeting. The United States - we're caught up in Iraq, worries about Saddam Hussein and the new developments in Eastern Europe, and my desire to help lift the debt off countries in South and Central America. But we never should neglect our friends. And we are a Pacific power. And this meeting - some of these leaders come from very small countries, but they are properly proud of their sovereignty, they are concerned about the very problems that I fight, whether it's environmental or economic growth, or revenues, and for me it's been a wondrous day. And I think it is very important that a president demonstrate, in this instance to the people of the Pacific, that we are not going to neglect our friends no matter how pressing the business of the world might be from other quarters. Thank you all.
DOC.HEAD: End AM-Bush-Text 5 takes
Jesse Jackson, David Duke in Flap Over One-On-One
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with executive producer of Jackson show saying Duke may appear; EDITS to conform. Pick up 7th graf, `The theme ...'
DOC.TEXT: State Rep. David Duke may appear after all on ``The Jesse Jackson Show'' in a flap over whether Jackson will interview the former Ku Klux Klan leader one-on-one, spokesmen for the two said. Jackson was scheduled to tape the interview with Duke, who was elected to the state House last year, in Washington on Wednesday for broadcast Nov. 3 on his nationally syndicated talk show. Duke spokesman Marc Ellis said producers of the show told Duke on Thursday that instead of a solo interview, he would be part of a panel discussion about President Bush's veto of civil rights legislation. ``The Jesse Jackson-David Duke debate that we'd agreed to earlier was to have been much more broad-ranging,'' Ellis said Friday. Randy Douthit, executive producer of the show, said Saturday he had talked to Ellis and Duke might still appear. ``We might have Jesse do a one-on-one with him,'' Douthit said. Valerie Scott, a spokeswoman for the show, said most of Jackson's interviews are panel discussions. The theme of the Nov. 3 episode will be racism, she said. Duke, who disavows his white-supremacist past but campaigns against programs such as affirmative action, was an unsuccessful candidate for the U.S. Senate this fall.

DOC.HEAD: White House Calls For Peace in Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: The White House, reacting to reports of atrocities and massacres in Lebanon, issued a call for peace Saturday and said, ``Now is not the time to settle old scores.'' The statement, issued during a visit here by President Bush, reiterated U.S. calls for the disbandment of all militias and the removal of all foreign forces from Lebanon. ``For 15 years we have argued against violence in Lebanon,'' said White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. ``Now is not the time to settle old scores. Now is the time for healing. The United States has made this point to Syria as well as to the various Lebanese parties.'' White House deputy press secretary Roman Popadiuk said the statement was issued as a result of reports of atrocities in East Beirut. ``We have not been able to confirm these reports,'' he said. ``However, the seriousness of these reports and the history of violence in Lebanon, we do have concern.''

DOC.HEAD: General Powell Tells Fifth-Grader War Wouldn't Cancel School
DOC.TEXT: Sheena Jennings had an important question about the Persian Gulf crisis that she didn't want to address to the enlisted men and women, as her elementary school classmates were doing. She wrote her letter to Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. ``I pretty much wanted to ask him, `If there is a war, do we have to go to school?''' said 10-year-old Sheena, a fifth-grader at Sutter Elementary School. To Sheena's surprise, the general wrote back last week. ``With respect to your question about whether you have to go to school if there's a war, the answer is yes,'' Powell wrote. ``But let's you and I and everyone else we can get to help us, pray hard that there isn't any war.'' Sheena said in her letter that she didn't like school much. ``School was very hard for me, too,'' Powell wrote. ``I always wanted to be doing something else. But as I look back, I realize that school was very important for me.'' ``If you know anyone who is thinking about dropping out,'' he continued, ``please use your effective talents to persuade them not to.''

DOC.HEAD: Right Leading Bhutto's Coalition in Second Election
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with right holding lead in latest returns. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A right-wing coalition was leading Benazir Bhutto's party in early returns of provincial elections Saturday, threatening the ousted prime minister with her second defeat in a week. At least 33 people were killed and about 50 injured in clashes between rival parties. It was the bloodiest election day in Pakistan's 43-year history. The legislative elections in Pakistan's four provinces - Punjab, Sindh, Baluchistan and Northwest Frontier - were considered a test of strength for the Islamic Democratic Alliance, a loose-knit, right-wing coalition of 18 parties that won national elections Wednesday and will form the next government. With more than half of the 483 provincial races decided, Ms. Bhutto's Pakistan People's Party had lost nearly every race in Punjab, the largest province. Her party was also in danger of losing its majority in Sindh, Ms. Bhutto's home province. In elections Wednesday for the National Assembly, the policy-making lower house of Parliament that chooses the prime minster, the Islamic alliance defeated Ms. Bhutto by a 2-to-1 margin, denying her a second chance to lead this Moslem country of 110 million people. The 37-year-old former prime minister accused the army-backed caretaker government of vote rigging, but a team of international poll watchers said they found no evidence to back up that claim. The elections were scheduled after Pakistan's president dismissed Ms. Bhutto on Aug. 6, accusing her 20-month-old government of corruption and incompetence. The four provincial legislatures were disbanded hours after her government was dismissed. Election officials said turnout among Pakistan's 50 million eligible voters was moderate to light Saturday, with many polling stations empty. They reported a heavy turnout in Karachi, the biggest city and Ms. Bhutto's hometown. More than 3,700 candidates were vying for the 483 seats in the four assemblies. The Islamic alliance won 90 seats in the 248-member assembly in Punjab, Pakistan's most populous state, while Ms. Bhutto's party got only two. In Sindh, Ms. Bhutto had won 30 seats in the 109-member assembly; the Islamic alliance had won 4 and its ally, the Mohajir Qami Movement, took 20. The Mohajir Qami Movement represents Moslems who immigrated to Pakistan during the 1947 partition of the Indian subcontinent. It once was aligned with Ms. Bhutto but later withdrew its support, saying she reneged on promises. The Islamic Alliance captured 18 seats of the 83 seats in the Northwest Frontier, holding a slight edge over a left-wing regional party. Ms. Bhutto's party had four seats. Twenty of the 42 seats in the Baluchistan assembly were divided among the alliance, the People's Party and two smaller parties. The rest went to regional ethnic and religious parties and independents. For Ms. Bhutto, the stakes were highest in Sindh, her provincial home and power base. Sindh and its capital, Karachi, have been wracked by ethnic violence that has claimed nearly 3,000 lives in the past five years. Ms. Bhutto's inability to curb the bloodshed was one of the reasons cited by President Ghulam Ishaq Khan when he dismissed her. About 100,000 soldiers, paramilitary troops and police have been patrolling the country's most volatile areas during this week's balloting, half of them in Sindh. Gunmen ambushed a car taking the son of caretaker Prime Minister Ghulam Mustafa Jatoi to vote in Sindh province, but Murtaza Jatoi ran safely into a polling station, officials said. Police later detained suspects, who were not identified. The younger Jatoi on Wednesday defeated Ms. Bhutto's husband, Asif Ali Zardari, for a seat in the National Assembly.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Clean Air
DOC.TEXT: Here are major provisions of the clean air bill.

-Requires a 15 percent cut in smog-causing emissions from automobiles in six years and 3 percent annually after that until federal air quality standards are met. Cities must achieve federal air standards within five to 17 years, except the Los Angeles area, which is given 20 years. -Mandates cuts in smog-causing emissions from factories and thousands of businesses through new control equipment.

-Requires reductions of 30 percent in unburned fuel and 60 percent for nitrogen oxides in automobile exhausts by 1998, cuts smoke and soot emissions by 50 percent from urban buses. -Requires new, larger canisters on automobiles to capture fuel vapors. -Establishes a gradual introduction of alternate-fuel vehicles for fleets, and annual production of 300,000 such vehicles for private use annually beginning in 1999 under a pilot program in California. -Sets up sale of cleaner gasoline blends in nine cities with worst smog problems. Compliance likely through ethanol blends or other ``reformulated'' gasoline. Also requires sale of gasoline with increased oxygen in cities failing carbon monoxide standards.

-Requires ``maximum achievable control technology'' to reduce the release of 189 toxic chemicals, many of them carcinogens, by 90 percent by 2000. -Requires further controls to assure ``an ample margin of safety'' from exposure to cancer-causing industrial emissions. The environmental Protection Agency must develop urban air pollution control programs to reduce cancer risks by 75 percent over five years. -Creates a chemical safety board to investigate chemical accidents and requires new monitoring and reporting of accidents.

-Reduces annual sulfur dioxide emissions from coal-burning electric power plants by 10 million tons in two stages by the year 2000. Reductions in release of nitrogen oxides, also a precursor of acid rain, also are required. -Allows utilities to buy and sell ``pollution credits'' to reduce the cost of emission controls at dirty plants. Utilities that already operate clean plants can use credits for emissions in new plants to allow for growth.
-Gradually forbids manufacture and import of chemicals that cause depletion of protective ozone layer high in the stratosphere and requires recycling of these chemicals after 1992.
DOC.HEAD: PENALTIES
DOC.TEXT: -EPA may assess up to $25,000 a day in civil penalties for violators. Corporate executives who knowingly pollute and significantly endanger health may be subject to criminal prosecution.
-Allows for $250 million over five years to help workers who lose their jobs because of tougher air pollution controls and can demonstrate need.

-White House estimates: $11 billion cost a year to the economy by 1995 and between $22 billion and $25 billion by year 2005. -Industry estimates: $35 billion to $60 billion a year by 2005. -Current air pollution controls cost the economy $32 billion a year, according to government estimates. The American Lung Association estimates clean air will eventually reduce health care costs by $50 billion a year.

DOC.HEAD: Top Afghan Commander Predicts Attacks
DOC.TEXT: A top Afghan rebel commander Saturday rejected any political settlement in his country's civil war and vowed to launch attacks to break a two-year military stalemate. ``Under no circumstances are we willing to share power,'' said Ahmad Shah Massoud. The 37-year-old commander was speaking to a group of foreign journalists at a walled compound outside the frontier town of Peshawar. Speaking through a translator, Massoud said ``our strategy for the war is not to start from one point but to attack different weak points of the enemy.'' The U.S.-backed mujahadeen gurrillas began their anti-government campaign 12 years ago. They fought for nine years against both Soviet military and Afghan government troops. Since the Soviets withdrew in February 1989, Afghan President Najibullah has made significant political gains by distancing himself from his Communist roots and embracing Islam in the predominately Moslem nation of about 9 million people. The rebels, whose leaders are headquartered in Peshawar, reportedly control most of Afghanistan's mountainous rural regions, while government soldiers control the major cities. Massoud repeated a call for elections in rebel-held territory by te end of March 1991. The mujahadeen leadership has been promising elections for almost two years but so far has failed to take any significant steps. Massoud's military threats could disrupt talks between Washington and Moscow on a settlement of the conflict, which has left 1.5 million people dead and 5 million refugees in Pakistan and Iran. After several rounds of talks, the United States and Soviet Union are expected to announce a final agreement by the end of the year. The United States is reportedly ready to allow Najibullah to participate in elections, providing he cannot influence their outcome by remaining in control of key ministries. In the past decade, Washington has supplied the mujahadeen with nearly $1 billion worth of weapons, including Stinger anti-aircraft missiles. The Kremlin sends $500 million worth of military and humanitarian aid to Kabul every month. Massoud met recently with other top rebel leaders to work out strategies, but he offered little evidence to indicate the commanders would be able to to work together. Some of the rebel groups have been involved in bitter feuding.

DOC.HEAD: Unarmed Apartment Dweller Shot by Police Searching for Prowler
DOC.TEXT: A police officer who entered an apartment Saturday in search of a prowler fatally shot the man who lived there as he walked from his bedroom. Terry Barnes, 26, who was unarmed, was shot once in the head, police said. The name of the officer involved was not disclosed. He was placed on paid leave pending the results of a department investigation. Police Chief Steven Bishop said the shooting was a tragedy but defended the 32-year-old officer and another officer who entered the unlocked apartment. ``This is a tragic chain of events that is regrettable for Mr. Barnes' family and for this officer,'' Bishop said. ``The officers were reacting appropriately to a number of circumstances which together led them to that apartment.'' The officers were responding to a prowler report about 3:30 a.m. at an apartment complex, police said. At the first apartment they visited, two men reported hearing someone in their living room and seeing a man run out the door, which had been kicked in, a police statement said. While the officers investigated, two other people contacted them and reported seeing someone running through another apartment building in the same block. The officers went to that building, entered Barnes' apartment, announced themselves as police officers and began looking for the prowler, the statement said. The officer who shot Barnes, a two-year veteran of the force, pulled the trigger after he opened a bedroom door and saw Barnes coming toward him, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Singh Holds Rally to Contain Rebellion in His Party
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister V.P. Singh called his supporters to a rally Saturday as he attempted to contain a rebellion by party members who want him to resign. In a speech to 2,000 loyalists on the lawn of his home, Singh gave no indication he was ready to step down. He pledged his Janata Dal party would champion the downtrodden, as he said it had done since he took office in December. Environment Minister Maneka Gandhi quit Singh's Cabinet on Friday, accusing the prime minister of failing to keep his pledge of honesty and efficiency. Four Parliament members once considered close to Singh called on him to step down. Singh faces a no-confidence motion in a special session of the legislature Nov. 7. Barring a last-minute compromise or a political realignment, he seems certain to lose. Singh has been in trouble since Tuesday, when a Hindu-Moslem dispute over rights to a holy site ballooned into the worst political crisis of the 10-month-old government. He was elected largely on the votes of the middle and educated classes who were disenchanted with the Congress government led by Rajiv Gandhi. As prime minister, Singh adopted policies aimed at expanding support with the poor, alienating many of those who put him in power. He also opposed construction of a Hindu temple at Ayodhya, where a Moslem mosque stands. That alienated the right-wing Bharatiya Janata Party, and without its support Singh's coalition no longer has a majority in Parliament. At least 93 people died last week in rioting between Moslems and Hindus and police efforts to quell the disturbances. Police on Friday night clamped a curfew on Ayodhya and on the neighboring town of Faizabad. Hindu fundamentalists have vowed to build a temple at the site which they say is birthplace of Lord Rama, a Hindu god. However, the mosque has stood there for 460 years. Police said they have detained 51,000 people in Uttar Pradesh state and seized more than 35,000 tribal spears and other weapons from Hindus on their way to Ayodhya, 300 miles southeast of New Delhi.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Discusses Environmental Concerns With Small Pacific Nations
DOC.TEXT: President Bush promised disgruntled Pacific island leaders Saturday that their pristine ocean will not become a permanent dumping ground for chemical weapons or other wastes. They, in turn, told him that good will toward Washington had ``begun to dry up.'' Bush asked the leaders for their understanding and support for U.S. plans to destroy huge stockpiles of chemical weapons already stored or en route to a giant new incinerator on Johnston Atoll, a U.S.-held ring of islands 825 miles southwest of Hawaii. The president met for more than two hours with the leaders of 11 remote and economically vulnerable countries. Speaking on behalf of the leaders at the close of the meeting, Prime Minister Geoffrey A. Henry of the Cook Islands said they all wanted the Johnston facility closed, ``but we know of course that cannot be done.'' Standing alongside Bush, Henry also spoke of a ``huge gulf of misunderstanding or misinformation'' between the islanders and the United States on the problem of global warming. Expressing skepticism about scientific reports minimizing the problem, Henry said, ``We'd love to read or hear what they tell you.'' Two Navy ships carrying 100,000 artillery shells loaded with nerve agents from the U.S. Army's stockpile in Germany are expected to reach the atoll next month. The weapons have become a major environmental issue throughout the Pacific. The South Pacific Forum, an organization of regional governments, claims that the use of Johnston Atoll could make the region ``the toxic waste disposal center of the world.'' In his closing remarks, Bush said the Pacific islands ``have a special place in the minds and hearts of the American people.'' However, Henry portrayed a different picture, saying the United States was ``too concerned with the problems of other places and you weren't as interested in the problems of the people of our region.'' Henry said Bush had ``begun to replenish the pool of good will that has begun to dry up since the last war, the good will between Pacific Islands and the United States of America. ... Don't allow it to dry up.'' Several dozen demonstrators staged a noisy protest about 100 yards from East-West Center where the leaders gathered. ``Don't Make our Pacific Your Cesspool,'' read a large sign in the crowd. There also were protests against U.S. involvement in the Persian Gulf. In advance of the meeting, President John Haglelgam of Micronesia said Bush needed to allay fears of tiny Pacific countries that the United States ``is ignoring them.'' Opening the session, Bush said the United States will destroy the toxic weapons ``only under extremely stringent environmental controls and protections.'' He said the Johnston facility would be used to destroy only the 300,000-piece stockpile already on the island and the weapons being shipped from Germany, along with any obsolete munitions found in the Pacific islands. That would rule out using the facility for chemical weapons stored on the U.S. mainland. ``Once that destruction is completed, we have no plans to use Johnston Atoll for any other chemical munitions purpose, or as a hazardous waste disposal site,'' Bush pledged. He acknowledged that the whole issue `has caused many of you deep concern. Our ability to move ahead and destroy chemical weapons is a significant step toward disarmament and peace.'' Tests of the incinerator are to end late next year, and full-scale incineration is expected to begin in 1992. The United States and Soviet Union have agreed to destroy such weapons by 1997. The State Department has issued a statement saying opposition to the incineration project ``must be weighed carefully against the long-term benefits both to world peace and the environment that will result from the total destruction of chemical weapons and a permanent ban on their acquisition and use.'' Conferring with Bush were the presidents or prime ministers of Fiji, Nauru, Papua New Guinea, Western Samoa, Cook Islands, Kiribati, the Marshall Islands, Micronesia and Tuvalu. Tonga and the Solomon Islands also sent lower-ranking representatives. On another front, Bush reminded the leaders that the crisis in the Persian Gulf has increased energy costs for the Pacific islands. ``The gulf crisis underlines global interdependence, making it imperative that all countries, large and small, join forces to work for peace and democracy throughout the world,'' he said. Bush also said that the Overseas Private Investment Corp., a government supported organization that helps private interests invest in foreign countries, will establish a $200 million venture capital fund and environmental investment fund called the Asian-Pacific Growth Fund, and a $100 million Environmental Investment Fund for sustainable natural resource development. He also said the OPIC would lead a group of American investors to Pacific Island countries next year, that the United States wants to negotiate an extension of the South Pacific Fisheries Treaty and that the State Department's Agency For International Development will set up four development assistance programs for private sector development, emphasizing agricultural and marine resources. Aside from environmental concerns, the Pacific leaders fear that U.S. development assistance will be cut back. They also wanted to press Bush to embrace the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty that bans the use, testing, dumping and storage of nuclear weapons and nuclear waste in the region. The administration has refused to submit the five-year-old treaty to the Senate. The two-hour summit and luncheon were squeezed into a four-day campaign trip featuring partisan attacks blaming Democrats for the nation's budget problems and the need for higher taxes.

DOC.HEAD: William Paley, Founder of CBS, Remembered as Programming Genius
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 graf after 13th graf, `Paley worked ...' to UPDATE with comments from Frank Sinatra. Picks up 14th graf, `The grandson ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY7; LaserColor NY10
DOC.TEXT: William S. Paley, who cultivated a fledgling radio network into the $3 billion-a-year communications conglomerate CBS Inc., was remembered by colleagues Saturday as a brilliant pioneer in broadcasting. They recalled his programming genius for both high art and mass-entertainment programs, as well as a deep commitment to the news. ``Anyone with means can collect Picassos and Gauguins, but it took a Bill Paley to collect Jack Bennys and Jackie Gleasons, Lucille Balls and Mary Tyler Moores and, at the same time, Ed Murrows, Eric Sevareids, Charles Collingwoods and Walter Cronkites,'' said Don Hewitt, executive producer of ``60 Minutes.'' Paley, 89, died Friday night in his Manhattan home. The cause of death was believed to be a heart attack brought on by pneumonia, CBS said in a statement Saturday. Paley bought a handful of struggling radio stations in 1929 for $400,000 and built them into one of the world's most powerful communications companies. For more than 50 years, he controlled the Columbia Broadcasting System as president or board chairman of its radio and television networks and its film, publishing, recording and other subsidiaries. ``The pioneer era in the history of broadcasting dies with William Paley,'' said Cronkite, a former CBS anchorman. ``He understood, as have few others, the necessity of giving broadcast news a liberty to perform without commercial or political interference.'' ``He was a giant of 20th century business, a man committed to excellence,'' said Dan Rather, Cronkite's successor at CBS News. ``Among his many accomplishments was being present at the creation of broadcast journalism. He remained passionately interested in news up to the time of his death.'' Fred Friendly, who was president of CBS News from 1964 to 1966, worked for Paley for 16 years. ``A lot of the fun and the glory, the nobility that he possessed, has sort of vanished in the throes of profits,'' he said. Frank Stanton, president emeritus of CBS Inc., said Paley was a programming genius. ``Call it skill, inspiration or luck,'' he said. ``It takes all of them, and he had all of them in abundance. Moreover, he had the resources and the courage to implement his ideas.'' Paley worked more than a decade past normal retirement age, giving final approval to all major policy decisions. ``It's like having a child,'' he once said. ``It's pretty hard to jerk yourself away from that entirely.'' Frank Sinatra credited Paley with giving him his ``first real break'' in broadcasting. Paley heard Sinatra singing at a club and put him on a CBS radio show that brought him to the attention of band leader Harry James. ``Harry offered me a job singing with his orchestra and everything skyrocketed from then on,'' Sinatra said in a statement. ``If it wasn't for Bill Paley, I don't know when I would've gotten a break. He was one of the best friends I'll ever have.'' The grandson of a Russian lumber magnate, Paley was born in Chicago on Sept. 28, 1901. He studied at Western Military Academy in Alton, Ill., and the University of Chicago before receiving a bachelor of science degree at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School in 1922. Upon graduation, he joined his father's firm, the Congress Cigar Co., as vice president and secretary. Paley became interested in radio when he saw how successful radio ads were for the company's La Palinas cigar. In 1928, he bought the year-old United Independent Broadcasting Corp. with money borrowed from his father. He changed its name to Columbia Broadcasting Corp. and begin building his empire. This year, Forbes magazine estimated Paley's personal worth at $460 million. In April 1983, Paley turned the reins of CBS Inc. over to Thomas H. Wyman, who had been president and chief executive officer since 1980. Paley stayed on as a consultant, director and chairman of the board of directors' executive committee. When CBS' biggest stockholder, Loew's Corp., became unhappy with Wyman's policies, Paley teamed with Loew's chairman, Lawrence Tisch, in 1986 to retake control, Paley as chairman and Tisch as president and chief executive officer. Paley had handpicked a series of heirs apparent in his later years, and had no compunction about dumping them when he felt they did not measure up to the man they were supposed to replace. David Halberstam, author of ``The Powers that Be,'' an authoritative account of leading news organizations including CBS, commented that ``because Paley hated the idea of turning the shop over (to a successor), he failed to institutionalize the protections he had given to the newsroom ... So CBS has slipped.'' In his 1979 autobiography, ``As It Happened,'' Paley said he may not have praised his subordinates often enough. ``I like to believe, however, that they understand me and know how I feel about them,'' he wrote. Paley became a fixture in New York's high society with the help of his second wife, ``Babe,'' the former Barbara Cushing, who died in 1978. ``The man loved to enjoy life - business and private life,'' said Lewis J. Paper, author of ``Empire: William S. Paley and the Making of CBS.'' ``And he believed he could have it all - high ratings and quality broadcasting and he believed he could enjoy every material pleasure.'' During World War II, Paley served with the Office of War Information abroad and as deputy chief of psychological warfare for Gen. Dwight Eisenhower's Supreme Headquarters, Allied Expeditionary Forces. Paley divorced his first wife, Dorothy Hart Hearst, in 1947. Despite his reputed 80-hour workweeks at CBS, Paley also was a trustee of the Museum of Modern Art and was one of the nation's leading collectors of post-Impressionist masterpieces. Paley is survived by four children, two stepchildren and eight grandchildren. Funeral services will be private. A memorial service was scheduled Nov. 12 in New York.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Extends Offshore Oil Ban
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 3rd graf to update with final passage
DOC.TEXT: Congress agreed Saturday to renew for another year a ban on offshore oil drilling along thousands of miles of U.S. coastline from Alaska to New England. The moratorium on the sale of offshore oil leases was contained in the Interior Department's fiscal 1991 appropriations bill worked out by a House-Senate conference committee. The bill was adopted by both the House and Senate late Saturday. ``With this legislation, Congress continues to insist upon protection of sensitive (offshore) areas,'' said Rep. Leon Panetta, D-Calif. Congress has blocked oil development along much of the nation's Outer Continental Shelf for nearly a decade through annual moratoria on lease sales as part of Interior's budget. But this year, while the House had included the ban, the Senate version of the bill had not, causing concern among environmentalists. Oil companies have intensified their campaign for increased domestic oil production since the beginning of the Persian Gulf crisis. But the lawmakers adopted the House version that broadened the ban to include not only leases off southern Florida, California and New England, but for the first time Alaska's Bristol Bay, the eastern Gulf of Mexico off northern Florida, and along a 50-mile buffer in the Atlantic from Rhode Island to Maryland. Drilling also is prohibited off the Pacific Northwest and, under separate legislation approved earlier, off North Carolina. Last summer, President Bush announced that he was postponing, in some cases for as long as 10 years, oil and gas lease sales off the West Coast, New England and southern Florida until environmental concerns can be resolved. Environmentalists, however, had pushed for Congress to renew its ban to guard against the president backing away from his decision. The Persian Gulf crisis and subsequent embargo of Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil has put a spotlight on America's dependence on oil imports. As a result, the petroleum industry has campaigned for opening parts of the Outer Continental Shelf for oil and gas development. The leases are held by the Interior Department. ``We had been nervous about this,'' said Lisa Speer, an attorey who specializes in offshore oil issues for the Natural Resources Defense Council, a private environmental group. She said the lawmakers' decision to keep the moratorium ``was the first real test to protecting the offshore areas since Iraq invaded Kuwait.''

DOC.HEAD: Senate Sends Anti-Pollution Bill to Bush
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2nd graf Bush comment; pickup 2nd graf pvs: ``The legislation, etc.
DOC.TEXT: With AM-Congress Rdp Bjt

Ending a year-long struggle, the Senate on Saturday passed 89-10 and sent to President Bush a tougher clean air law to stem acid rain, urban smog and toxic industrial pollution. Bush, in Hawaii, told reporters he would sign the bill, passed in the waning hours of the 101st Congress. In a session-ending call to Senate leaders, he called it ``another good step for the country.'' The legislation, totaling more than 1,100 pages, will impose more stringent pollution controls on automobiles, factories, coal-burning power plants and thousands of businesses. It cleared the House on a 401-25 vote late Friday. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, called the bill ``a long overdue step to renewing our national commitment to an active, effective and aggressive program of controlling the pollutants that threaten the air we and all Americans breathe.'' ``It's the most comprehensive environmental bill of the last quarter-century,'' declared Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont. But the legislation was not without ardent critics. Sen. Steve Symms, R-Idaho, denounced the measure in a two-hour floor speech as too expensive, a threat to economic growth and unnecessary. Although the legislation carries an eventual price tag estimated at $22 billion a year or more by the year 2005, its supporters argued that to do nothing toward cleaning up the nation's air would be even more costly from higher health-care bills and related economic losses. Congress first began debating the legislation more than a year ago. Along with requiring new auto-emission controls and cleaner-burning gasoline, it establishes first-time requirements for industry to install equipment aimed at cutting the release of toxic chemicals, including many cancer-causing agents, by 90 percent over the next eight years. And it demands, also for the first time, steep reductions in emissions from coal-burning electric power plants that cause acid rain. The House approved the measures Friday after two hours of debate in which some congressmen expressed concern about the bill's cost to the economy. Nevertheless, only a few members of the House voted against it. ``This bill will be the standard by which we will judge environmental legislation in the '90s,'' Rep. Mike Synar, D-Okla., declared. Despite the lopsided House and Senate votes, the legislation is the product of months of intense bargaining, tradeoffs and compromises. Among the provisions: -Smog-producing emissions from automobiles must be cut by 30 percent to 60 percent and gasoline sold in areas with smog problems must be 15 percent cleaner toward the end of the decade. -More than 100 cities that are failing to meet federal air-quality standards will have to develop pollution-control plans to bring their air into compliance over the next five to 17 years, depending on the severity of the problem. The Los Angeles area is given 20 years. -Factories and businesses must install new technology to cut toxic chemical emissions by 90 percent over the next eight years. The requirements cover 189 hazardous chemicals including many cancer-causing agents. -Annual sulfur dioxide emissions must be cut by 10 million tons by the year 2000 to reduce acid rain. Midwest utilities that operate the dirtiest coal-burning plants will be hit the hardest. Failure to meet the new federal requirements could open polluters to civil penalties of up to $25,000 a day. Criminal penalties may be sought against corporate executives for willful release of hazardous air pollutants that pose a serious health threat. Most of the new pollution requirements would be phased in over 10 to 15 years. The requirements for cleaner-burning motor fuels and reductions in sulfur dioxide emissions from coal-burning power plants take effect by 1995. The clean air requirements are expected to have widespread effects on society. Consumers are likely to pay slightly more for automobiles as well as gasoline and, in many of the Midwestern states, more for electricity. Small businesses and huge petrochemical plants alike will have to invest in pollution-control equipment and improve the monitoring of chemical releases. Cost estimates for the new controls have varied widely. The bill's supporters have said the legislation will cost the economy about $10 billion a year beginning in 1995 and about $22 billion by the year 2005, when most of the requirements will be in effect. Industry estimates have been much higher, with some studies predicting annual costs from the legislation by 2005 of more than $60 billion. Voting against the bill in the Senate were Robert Byrd, D-W.Va.; Alan Dixon, D-Ill.; Jake Garn, R-Utah; John Glenn, D-Ohio; Orrin Hatch, R-Utah; Jesse Helms, R-N.C.; James McClure, R-Idaho; Jay Rockefeller, D-W.Va.; Paul Simon, D-Ill., and Steve Symms, R-Idaho. Sen. Mark Hatfield, R-Ore., did not vote.

DOC.HEAD: Strikers Walk, Replacements Work, Paper Printed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 10th graf, `The Daily ...' to UPDATE with Sunday edition bigger than usual but slow to hit the streets. Picks up 11th graf, `The News ...'; INSERTS 1 graf after 20th graf, `A skeleton ...' to UPDATE with strikers attacking bus carrying replacement workers. Picks up 21st graf, `The News ...'
DOC.TEXT: Rusty editors, managers and replacement workers wrote, printed and delivered the Daily News on Saturday despite the absence of 2,400 employees in a strike marked by sporadic violence. ``The Fight For The News'' read the paper's front page headline above a photo of strikers vandalizing a bus carrying replacement workers. Inside, there were ads to fill the strikers' jobs in all departments at the paper. ``New York's hometown paper is run by a bunch of out-of-towners. It's not right,'' said striker Joe Burgess, who has worked in the News art department since 1971. News management said Saturday that about 100 permanent replacements had been hired already. Striking workers were welcome to return to their old jobs at their old salaries at any time until a permanent replacement is hired for that slot, said News vice president John Sloan. ``Any employee that wants to return can do so,'' Sloan said. ``We have not fired anybody.'' For editorial employees, the weekend was a time to consider the future. Sloan has said some temporary writers and editors were recruited from other Tribune Co. newspapers for temporary duty. Besides the Daily News, the Chicago-based Tribune Co. also owns the Chicago Tribune; theSun-Sentinel in Fort Lauderdale and The Orlando Sentinel in Orlando, Fla.; the Times-Advocate in Escondido and the Peninsula Times Tribune in Palo Alto, Calif.; and the Daily Press and The Times-Herald in Newport News, Va. The Daily News normally operates with a small weekend staff and Monday's edition will show whether the picket lines outside the News Building keep the news staffers away from their desks. The newspaper's Sunday edition had 96 pages in the news section, compared with an 88-page news section last week, said Daily News spokeswoman Lisa Robinson. Its front-page story, an investigation into the state Liquor Authority, was written before the strike, she said. As of 10 p.m. Saturday, early editions had not left the News' three plants. The News published and distributed 710,000 copies of the tabloid Saturday, about 200,000 short of a normal Saturday run, Sloan said. Copies of the paper remained difficult to find in certain areas of the city and the suburbs. The Saturday paper was the first one to hit the street prepared and distributed without the unions, which began to go out early Thursday in a job action that spread to nine of its 10 unions. The News claimed to have distributed 611,000 papers on Friday, when eight unions were out. Editorial employees joined the strike Friday afternoon. ``I may be committing economic suicide, but I feel like I'm on the right side of the issue,'' said picketer John Wolf, a 24-year veteran of the News advertising make-up department. ``It's not a family paper anymore.'' Police reported 12 arrests in strike-related incidents, including one striker who allegedly attacked a replacement worker with a bat and four News employees riding in a car with a shotgun and a .22-caliber automatic. Missing from Saturday's edition were the bylines familiar to its 1.18 million daily readers. ``By Daily News Staff'' appeared on most stories that were not wire copy. The 64-page paper included some features that ordinarily run in the Sunday paper. A message to News readers asked them to bear with the paper despite the ``inconvenience ... attributable to vandalism and violence by striking workers.'' A team of four editors covered the strike for the News; they described the normally bustling city room as a ``sea of empty desks'' dotted with editors ``long out of practice as reporters.'' At stake is the future of the 71-year-old daily, which has been in a financial tailspin for the past decade. The News has lost about $115 million and seen daily circulation slip by about 700,000 since 1980. Unlike most strikes, though, there are no negotiations in progress or planned. The News plans to replace the strikers with new, permanent employees and continue to publish. Union contracts expired in March. A skeleton crew of about a dozen strikers walked outside the Daily News building on Saturday, but much larger numbers turned out the night before at News printing facilities in Long Island, Brooklyn and New Jersey. On Saturday afternoon, strikers wielding bats attacked a bus carrying replacement workers from the Brooklyn plant, said Sgt. Ed Burns. One worker suffered minor hand cuts from broken glass, and no arrests were made, he said. The News reported eight of its delivery trucks have been firebombed and another 60 have been otherwise vandalized since the strike began Thursday. Ten buses used to transport replacement workers have also been damaged. The News is the nation's second-largest metropolitan daily after the Los Angeles Times. The only union not striking the paper is the New York Typographical Union, whose 200 members have lifetime guaranteed jobs.

DOC.HEAD: Tugboats Free Stranded Dredge, Generators Sent to Isolated Island
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with quotes from tourists and residents. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Tugboats freed a dredge Saturday that knocked out the only road link to the mainland for thousands of people on North Carolina's Outer Banks. Residents and tourists on Hatteras Island faced a 30-hour wait for ferries, their only transportation to the mainland since the dredge broke free of moorings in a gale Friday and hit Herbert Bonner Bridge. The Northerly Island dredge took out a 369-foot section of the bridge and snapped power lines that ran underneath the span, leaving about 8,000 people on Hatteras and Ocracoke islands without electricity and telephone service. Generators flown in by helicopter were used to restore power to some people while utility crews worked on putting up temporary lines, expected by Sunday. The temporary lines could not be put up until the dredge was pulled from sand. It took three tugs about two hours to remove the dredge. There was a six-hour wait to get on a ferry from Hatteras to Ocracoke, where the wait for a ferry was 24 hours for the final leg to the mainland. Residents were warned to conserve water and fuel. Their predicament may seem daunting, but many consider such emergencies a way of life on the islands. ``We're running out of gas and fuel, the usual stuff,'' said Bert Austin, sheriff of Dare County, on Hatteras Island. ``The local people are used to having problems. That's part of the island's heritage.'' Gwen White, a Dare County emergency management spokeswoman, said the Hatteras Island water tank was about three-quarters full and residents should have no problem if electricity were restored soon. ``Food supplies are still perfectly good and plentiful right now,'' Ms. White said. ``As far as bringing food in the next few days, that may become a problem if the ferries can't run.'' Ferries couldn't run Friday after the bridge collapse because of high wind. The forecast called for mild weather through Sunday. There have been no reports of looting, sheriff's Lt. Almey Gray said. Ocracoke has about 3,000 permanent residents and Hatteras has about 5,000 permanent residents. As for repairing the bridge, six months is the most optimistic estimate given by state emergency management officials. People lined up for a 10-gallon gasoline ration at Dillons Corner on Hatteras. Another station in town was out of gasoline. ``Since (rationing) started, it's been a mad rush to the service station,'' said Cape Hatteras School principal Jimmy Webb. ``That's our umbilical cord,'' he said, pointing at the bridge. ``It's very inconvenient (to be cut off). But so is living in the city.'' The school's 536 students, in kindergarten through 12th grade, will return to class Monday, Webb said. Until then, the school will be used as a shelter. Red Cross workers were brought in aboard an Army helicopter to set up shop there. ``Most people that live here are ready for a month or so of siege,'' Webb said. At a National Weather Service station on Hatteras, workers relayed messages to relatives on the mainland and transmitted frequent public service messages on the radio. The station's generator has enough fuel to last at least a week, said technician Jimmy McClain. Jay Benda, from Rockford, Mich., and Karl and Kathy Gleiss, from Clarkston, Mich., waited six hours for the ferry from Hatteras to Ocracoke. The three were dismayed when told to expect a 24-hour wait at Ocracoke, where traffic was backed up for 10 miles. The three friends have been coming to Hatteras every year since 1988 for windsurfing at Canadian Hole on the Pamlico Sound. ``We're happy 'cause we got to sail three-fives,'' Gleiss said, referring to a small sail used in strong wind.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Liver Failure Killing Dolphins
DOC.TEXT: Liver failure may be killing thousands of dolphins in the Mediterranean Sea, The Sunday Times quoted scientists as saying. The report said studies on some of the 10,000 striped dolphins estimated to have died in the past three months found that all had suffered acute liver damage. Researchers, however, were not certain if the problem was linked to pollution, natural toxins in algae or a disease similar to hepatitis. The disease was earlier believed by some scientists to be caused by the morbilli virus that killed thousands of seals in the North Sea two years ago. The Sunday Times reported morbilli has been found in 60 percent of the dolphins examined. ``But its absence in the remaining 40 percent has raised a question mark over the real cause of death,'' the newspaper said. Two researchers quoted in the article suggested there may be other reasons for the deaths of the dolphins, which have been found in Spain, France, Italy and North Africa.
